items.title: Reporting Special Interest Group (SIG)
items.summary: The Special Interest Group (SIG) – Reporting drives improvements to reporting systems and tools across the University of Auckland.

content.value: Purpose
The Reporting SIG works under the Research Management and Administration Community of Interest (RMA CoI) to:
Identify and define improvements to reporting systems and tools that enhance the monitoring of research performance, research services, and research risks,
Make recommendations to the Research and Innovation (R&I) Steering Committee and implement improvements to reporting systems and tools,
Ensure key members of the RMA CoI are consulted in the identification, definition, and implementation of improvements to reporting systems and tools as approved by the R&I Steering Committee,
Maintain a list of improvements (in process, declined, and completed) to reporting systems and tools and publish the list for viewing by the RMA CoI,
Develop, maintain, and publish informational and training materials, as needed, relating to improvements to reporting systems and tools.
Identification of Issues and Improvements
The SIG’s membership meets the third week of every month (as available) to review reporting issues and improvements collected throughout the year.
Issues and suggestions for improvements are welcome from across the University of Auckland and can be submitted to the SIG via using the form in Service-Now:
Submission Form
(after clicking on the link, navigate to the ‘Research Finance Reporting’ option listed).
Please note, submissions will be reviewed by the SIG membership to determine whether the request can be pursued.
Work Undertaken
Major issues and improvements addressed by the SIG are tracked and will be available for viewing below (once available).
Please note - minor items are not included; however, a full view of all issues and improvements is available upon request.
If you have any questions about the status of issues and improvements being addressed by the SIG please contact the SIG (
simmon.hofstetter@auckland.ac.nz
Governance
The Research & Innovation Steering Committee, chaired by the Deputy Vice-Chancellor (Research) as Research & Innovation strategic portfolio sponsor, governs the working group.
The Reporting SIG Terms of Reference are reviewed and updated annually.
Open Reporting SIG Terms of Reference document.

items.title: Research Integrity and Responsible Conduct of Research
items.summary: Information about what “Research Integrity” and “Responsible Conduct of Research (RCR)” are and how to apply RCR throughout the lifecycle of your research project.

content.value: What is research integrity?

Research Integrity is sometimes referred to as ‘Responsible Conduct of Research (RCR)’ or ‘Good Research Practice (GRP)’ and encompass the types of attitudes and behaviours that promote trust and confidence in research.
The
Singapore Statement

was formulated as result of global collaborations at the second World Conferences on Research Integrity (WCRI) and was the first attempt to produce a common set of global values and principles for responsible conduct of research. The Singapore Statement contains four principles and 14 responsibilities encapsulating RCR. Two further principles were added at the WCRI Hong Kong conference in 2019.
Honesty - in all aspects of research work
Accountability - in the conduct of research
Professional courtesy and fairness – in working with others
Good stewardship – on behalf of others
Transparency – of research process and presentation of results
Clarity - communication to be understandable, explainable and accessible
These principles have since been incorporated into national codes (e.g.,
Australian Code (2018)
, the
UK Research Integrity Office Code (2023)
) and regional codes (e.g.,
APEC Guiding Principles (2022)
European Code (2023)
). The
Research Charter for Aotearoa
was published in 2020.
These codes share common values and expectations, as depicted in
Figure 1

below. They also share the common structural feature that the research integrity responsibilities of host research organisations and researchers (staff and students) are clearly demarcated for different activities across the research lifecycle.
Why is Research Integrity important?
The credibility of research findings that supports the advancement of scientific knowledge is the most important building block for promoting the trust and confidence in research.

In addition, responsible conduct of research ensures that studies are conducted with honesty, accuracy, and objectivity, leading to better study designs, improved techniques, and reliable data and prevents wastage of time, resources, and funding.

Retaining the trust of the public – who as tax payers contribute to the Government funding for research - is another important reason to ensure research conducted with integrity and with the highest ethical standards.
RCR across the research lifecycle

The research lifecycle describes the process of discovery from end to end, and each step in the lifecycle encompasses activities that embodies RCR. These activities are listed below and are based on the widely accepted RCR principles.
Image from at the
UK Research Integrity Office (UKRIO), What is research integrity.
The Research Integrity Promotion Framework at the University

items.title: Research virtual machines
items.summary: Virtual machines support computationally-intensive research and long-running workflows across Windows and Linux operating systems.

content.value: Rather than running on a desktop or laptop computer,

In a research context, virtual machines provide a separate computing environment that can be used to speed up analyses, facilitate innovative methods, support long-running tasks, collaborate with others, or free up your desktop or laptop to do other activities.
Benefits
Access to more compute power (CPUs and RAM - hardware) than is available in a desktop or laptop.

Limitations
Compute power is finite, and specific performance levels cannot be guaranteed.
Services

items.title: Research Integrity Policy consultation
items.summary: Supporting information for the ongoing consultation on the University’s new Research Integrity policy.

content.value: Introduction

The University is currently consulting on a new Research Integrity Policy which is proposed to replace the University’s current Research Code of Conduct and Misconduct in Research Policy. The survey closed on 26 April 2024.
This page explains what ‘research integrity’ means and provides a summary of the key changes from the existing policies.
Policy development process

The draft Research Integrity Policy has been developed by the University’s Research Integrity Officer in consultation with the Board of Graduate Studies, University Research Committee and Provost, Deans and Directors Committee (PDDC). A summary report on the consultation feedback will be published to the ResearchHub and will be used to prepare the final policy and associated guidelines for approval in mid-2024.
Key policy features
The key features of the new Research Integrity Policy are summarised below:
Structure
Key change:
The Research Code of Conduct and Research Misconduct policies are now combined into a single Research Integrity Policy.
Rationale:
To bring all research integrity matters under one policy and removing the need to cross-reference the two policies.
Title
Key change:
The policy is named the Research Integrity Policy rather than the Research Code of Conduct.
Rationale:
To reflect the University’s commitment to research integrity and to avoid confusion with the University’s existing
Code of Conduct
Purpose
Key change:
Purpose section refreshed to include references to the University’s updated
purpose and values
and
Code of Conduct
, and to emphasise the intent of promoting good research practices, avoiding research misconduct and minimising questionable research practices (QRPs).
Rationale:
Taumata Teitei and the
Code of Conduct
came into effect since the previous review. The current policy does not clearly articulate the differences between research misconduct and QRPs.
University Responsibilities
Key change:
A list of University responsibilities for research integrity has been added, including the appointment of a Research Integrity Officer and Research Integrity Advisers.
Rationale:
The University has a critical role to enable and foster a vibrant and supported research environment that were not included in the previous policy.
Research integrity codes and guidelines in other jurisdictions clearly demarcate the responsibilities of host institutions from those of researchers (e.g.,
Australian Code (2018)
. The
RDM Policy
also adopts this approach).
Researcher Responsibilities
Key change:

Researcher responsibilities have been reviewed to include new areas of focus. The policy includes, for example, expectations relating to the use of artificial intelligence (including Generative Artificial Intelligence) and the promotion of the 3Rs in animal research.
Rationale:
The University has a responsibility to set clear expectations for the research community in these new and emerging areas of focus.
Supervisor
Key change:
The responsibilities of supervisors are listed separately.
Rationale:
Supervisors have a critical role to play in promoting research integrity and good research practices for research students and the future research workforce.
Detailed responsibilities
Key change:
Removed the extensive description of each responsibility from the current policies.
Rationale:
Detailed separate guidance will be provided on the ResearchHub in keeping with the University’s policy format and similar to the format used for the
Research Data Management Policy guidance

items.title: Tidy data
items.summary: Tidy data is an approach to organising tabular data so that is easy to manipulate, model, and visualise.

content.value: Tidy data

is data which has been organised in a way that makes it easy to manipulate within other software for analysis. By following tidy data principles, it will be easier for you and others to take advantage of the power and flexibility of computational methods to analyse your data. Many popular software packages for analyses (including python, R, and MATLAB) work best when data is arranged in a tidy way.
Tidy data principles
Each variable has its own column.
Each observation has its own row.
Each value has its own cell.

The aim is to make sure that each cell contains a single piece of information. For example, if you have an existing date column in the format YYYY-MM-DD, you might prefer to split this into separate columns for each of the three components to make it easier to transform and analyse different facets of your data. You can put these principles into practise when collecting and recording your data, or by transforming your data inside analysis software.
Tips for arranging data
It is often useful to:
Keep an unmodified, original copy of the raw data in case you are required to produce it for verification or integrity purposes.

Keep a separate working copy which you can modify and transform as part of your analyses. Be sure to record the steps you have taken to move from raw to tidy data if you are cleaning up an existing dataset.
Make your variable names human-readable and understandable, but keep them concise. Avoid spaces and special characters.
Use one spreadsheet file for each table and don't combine multiple tables in the same sheet.
Save tabular data in a universal open format such as Comma Separated Values (.csv) so it can be read by the widest range of software.

Create a README.txt file outlining important contextual information about your data instead of relying on formatting and notes within the spreadsheet (which make it harder to import into analysis software). Include information about the variables, their units, information about your project, and any other useful information about the choices you have made when collecting, transforming, or analysing your data. This information will come in handy when you go to publish or communicate your work.

items.title: Co-location guidelines
items.summary: This article provides an overview of how co-locations are organised, including links to supporting policies and guidelines for implementing new co-locations.

content.value: Co-locations are a critical part of the University research ecosystem that supports collaboration, knowledge exchange and commercialisation between industry, government and academia.  Co-locators may be companies, charities or government departments that have entered into an agreement with the University for the use of space and associated support services.
For further information on Co-location approval requirements, please see the
co-location policy
and
procedures
There are three approved co-location models
Waipapa Taumata Rau | The University of Auckland has three co-location models:
Startup model
Commercial model
Precinct model
These models are defined in the
co-location policy
with reference to several key parameters, including:
Development phase of the co-locator
Level of involvement of University staff and students
Type of intellectual property involved
Degree of alignment with host faculty or Large-Scale Research Institute.
Fees are dependent on the co-location model
The fee structure for co-locations is dependent on the co-location model and whether the co-location is serviced or non-serviced, with the types of services available detailed in the
co-location policy

rio@auckland.ac.nz

items.title: Human Frontier Science Programme (HFSP)
items.summary: The International Human Frontier Science Program Organization (HFSPO) is an international collaboration promoting global cooperation in frontier life science research.

content.value: The programme supports novel, innovative and interdisciplinary basic research focused on the complex mechanisms of living organisms. Research is funded at all levels of biological complexity from biomolecules to the interactions between organisms.
The HFSP places emphasis on novel collaborations that bring biologists together with scientists from fields such as physics, mathematics, chemistry, computer science and engineering.
Their mission is to fund high-risk, transformative and paradigm shifting research.
Related disciplines/Areas of interest
Life sciences
Funding opportunities:
The HFSP offer the two following grants:
Postdoctoral Fellowship
and
Research Grant
Fellowships
There are two different fellowships are available:
Long-Term Fellowships (LTF)

are for applicants with a PhD in a biological discipline, who will broaden their expertise by proposing a project in the life sciences which is significantly different from their previous PhD or postdoctoral work.
Cross-Disciplinary Fellowships (CDF)
are for applicants with a PhD from outside the life sciences (e.g. in physics, chemistry, mathematics, engineering or computer sciences
Eligibility
1) Nationality

A candidate who is not a national from one of the HFSP members (see list below) may apply to work only in a research institution in one of the member countries. A candidate who is a national of one of the member countries can apply to work in a research institution in any country.
HFSP member countries: Australia, Austria, Belgium, Bulgaria, Canada, Croatia, Cyprus (EU part only), Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Hungary, India, Republic of Ireland, Israel, Italy, Japan, Republic of Korea, Latvia, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, The Netherlands, New Zealand, Poland, Portugal, Romania, Singapore, Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, the United Kingdom and the United States of America.
Applicants must propose to work in a country different to the one where they did their previous PhD work or first post-doctoral studies.
2) Doctoral degree

A research doctorate (PhD) or a doctoral-level degree comparable to a PhD with equivalent experience in basic research (e.g. a research based MD* or medical PhD) must be conferred by the start of the fellowship. 
It is not required at the time of submission. By “conferred degree” we mean you have received your diploma for the degree. The “conferral date” is the date on the official PhD document. Please refer to the application guidelines for information in case you were not yet awarded the PhD. *NB:
The University of Auckland equivalent to MD is DMedSc from 2024.
3) Research publications

Applicants must have at least one lead author publication by the submission deadline of the Letter of Intent which can be a manuscript (i) published in a recognized OA preprint repository, or, (ii) accepted for publication, (iii) in press or (iv) already published by a peer reviewed journal.
Submission of a fellowship proposal at the full application stage however is only possible with a published research article according to points (ii) to (iv) above. 
HFSP only accepts full-length original research publications in English that were peer reviewed and for which the applicant must either be the single author, first author or joint first author. In a joint first author paper the applicant does not need to be listed in the first position, but the equal contribution of the authors must be clearly stated in all cases.
In some cases the standard publication practice makes first authorship impossible (e.g. alphabetical listing of authors); these circumstances must be explained in the application.
*Please note the funder has a short eligibility test that can be taken on their website for researchers to easily determine whether their research is eligible for funding.
Research grants

HFSP research grants support teams of independent leaders of research groups. Therefore applications from individual scientists or early career researchers carrying out their postdoctoral or PhD level projects are not eligible.
The Principal Applicant of a Research Grant must have a laboratory in a member country.  The other team members and their laboratories may be situated anywhere in the world.

All team members are expected to direct a research group (however small) and must have a doctoral degree (PhD, MD* or equivalent). They must be in a position to initiate and direct their own independent lines of research. The HFSP award is not intended to create scientific independence, this is a decision of the research institute prior to the application.  (*NB:
The University of Auckland equivalent to MD is DMedSc from 2024.)
All team members must be able to determine the course of the HFSP-funded project and have freedom to administer the grant, if awarded.

Structure of the team. The research teams must be international (preferably intercontinental). Normally, there will be only one team member with a laboratory in each country, teams with two members at the same institution are not eligible.
Team members should not have collaborated before, they will normally not have published original research together, and the project must be significantly different from their ongoing research.
Eligibility
Research grants –Early Career

All members of an Early Career grant team must be within 5 years of obtaining an independent position (see below) and must have obtained their first doctoral degree (PhD, MD* or equivalent) not longer than 10 years before the deadline for submission of the letter of intent. (*NB:
The University of Auckland equivalent to MD is DMedSc from 2024.)

All applicants for an Early Career grant must be project leaders directing a research group (however small) and must have full responsibility for the day to day running of their laboratories and will have full control of the HFSP funds.
Written confirmation may be requested from the Head of Department in the case of an applicant who independently oversees a research theme.
Research grants – Program
While researchers can be at any stage in their independent career, participation of early career researchers is encouraged also in Program Grants.

Additional conditions regarding the institutional affiliations, the number of team members, the country of affiliation, internationality of the team, concurrent applications and new applications from previous grant awardees are given in the guidelines .
*Please note the funder has a short
eligibility test
that can be taken on their website for researchers to easily determine whether their research is eligible for funding.
Further information
More info can be found
here

items.title: Research Impact Community of Interest (CoI)
items.summary: Join an internal network of academic and professional staff with a shared interested in impactful research.

content.value: Interested in research impact and wanting to learn more from a group of like-minded people? Keen to share your experiences with research impact and connect with others? You are welcome to join the Research Impact Community of Interest (RI CoI).
The overall objective of the RI CoI is to develop and nurture a positive impact culture within Waipapa Taumata Rau, with an aim to maximise the potential impact of the University’s research.
We address this objective with the following activities:
facilitate networking, develop interactions and new/stronger relationships between support functions and researchers with a shared interest in research impact
share knowledge and good practice to support impact and impact literacy
identify learning and development needs and ways to meet them
provide opportunities to discuss impact-related topics
support, where possible, the implementation of the University Research Impact and Engagement Strategy
support the development of shared tools and resources to support impact activities
act as a voice to respond to specialist consultations and feed into other specialist impact networks including the Australasian Research Management Society (ARMS) Impact Special Interest group
ultimately lead towards developing and nurturing a positive impact culture within the University of Auckland, maximising the potential impact of the University’s research
The Community of Interest hosts 3-4 forums per annum, with themes of the meeting set by the community itself.
Membership

The Research Impact Community of Interest is a relatively informal group, with membership driven considerably by personal and professional interest in fostering the impact of research and creative practice. A small convening group manage the meetings.
Cherie Lacey – Research Impact Manager, RIO
Jennifer Lees-Marshment – A/P Politics and International Relations, Arts
Suzanne Woodward – Researcher and Knowledge Translation Expert, Public Policy Institute
Ellie Gray – Manager Strategic Donor Relations, ARD
If you are interested to become a member of the group, please email
researchimpact@auckland.ac.nz

items.title: Trusted Research - Protective Security Requirements (TR-PSR) implementation roadmap project
items.summary: A research & innovation project, the Trusted Research - Protective Security Requirements (TR-PSR) implementation roadmap is to improve the way we manage risks relating to research activities.

content.value: Te Pōkai Tara | Universities New Zealand has published the
Trusted Research – Protective Security Requirements (TR-PSR) Guide for Senior Leaders
that was jointly developed by the eight universities in Aotearoa with key government agencies.  This publication follows the release of the
Trusted Research Guidance for Institutions and Researchers
in March last year.

The central aim of the Trusted Research - Protective Security Requirements Guide (TR-PSR) is to improve the way we manage risks relating to research activities in an ever-changing and increasingly complex geopolitical environment.
The TR-PSR guide includes national values and principles for TR-PSR that will inform our response alongside the values and Te Ao Māori principles of Waipapa Taumata Rau, as set out in Taumata Teitei.
The guide also includes policy guidance for university leaders across six key domains:
Te Tiriti o Waitangi
Good governance
Policy, planning and risk assessment
Legal and regulatory compliance
Protecting people, assets and reputation

items.title: Predatory publishers
items.summary: Predatory publishers are a problematic part of the modern research ecosystem. Learn what to watch out for and where to go to check journal quality.

content.value: Beware predatory publishers!

Predatory publishers are a problematic part of the modern research ecosystem. They attempt to trick legitimate researchers into publishing with them and then charge unexpected fees. They also publish fraudulent or poor-quality research that can be taken seriously by readers and have lasting negative consequences.
Watch out for the following red flags when assessing a journal's quality and legitimacy:
Aggressive emails:
repeated emails asking for submissions; often for topics unrelated to your area of expertise
Fake credentials:
retired or dead academics on the board; journal name closely mimics top journals; unclear ownership; website URL has a typo or extra character
Hidden fees and policies:
little or no information about terms and conditions on the journal website (e.g. fees, copyright policy, licensing, peer review process); fees are charged after acceptance
Publication process:
very fast publication times; peer review omitted; little or no editing; out-of-scope articles published; nonsense articles published
Comprehensive guidance on assessing journal quality is available on
Think. Check. Submit.

content.value: What is a DMP?
Data management plans (DMPs) are used to describe and document important decisions relating to the data generated or gathered by a research project.
A DMP is required for any research project involving sensitive or restricted research data, but is recommended for all projects.
Benefits of a DMP
Prompts data management considerations and captures decisions to support ethics, security, data sovereignty, funder requirements,
open research
, etc.
Aligns with University policies and processes, including
and the
Clarifies roles and responsibilities for project members and collaborators regarding stewardship and governance during and after the project.
Supports project members and collaborators to follow agreed practices.

items.title: Importance of research impact
items.summary: A brief overview of research impact, a glossary of common terms and the key benefits of prioritising research impact.

content.value: Every type of research has the potential to have impact, from applied through to fundamental research. The impact of your research might not be immediately obvious; however, all research can contribute valuable knowledge, understanding, and insights, and has the potential to create change for future generations — especially if you bring your research stakeholders along with you.
By keeping the potential impact at the centre of your planning, you will ensure appropriate engagement with various communities and other stakeholders who are essential for enabling impact to occur.
There may be many reasons why you want to maximise your potential impact, some of which are listed below.
5 reasons for maximising research impact
Benefiting society:
aligning with the value of hei hua ma te katoa in the
University's Research Impact and Engagement Framework
, researchers are encouraged to undertake research that addresses societal issues and inequities.
Making research more relevant
: by bridging the gap between research and public knowledge, research can more easily address community needs and therefore become more relevant to the public.
Providing justification and support for public research funding
: by displaying how research addresses societal needs, it justifies continued public investment in research projects.
Securing future funding:
by showing the benefits the research has to Aotearoa New Zealand, funders and the government are more likely to invest in your research.
Assisting research institutions to attract resources
: when publicising the benefits of their research to the greater community, institutions and researchers can attract more resources from funders.
Research Impact Glossary

The language used for research impact might be unfamiliar, so we have created a Glossary of commonly used terms and their definitions. You can also find this in other parts of the Research Impact Guide on the left side of the page under '
Documents

items.title: Research impact in funding applications
items.summary: Writing research impact sections in MBIE and HRC funding applications

content.value: How impact matters in funding

Due to the greater emphasis placed on research impact, a number of our domestic funders are assigning a larger proportion of the assessment criteria to potential impact of the research and the robustness of the plan to achieve this impact. This means applications to these funders need to have strong research impact sections to score well in their funding rounds, so it pays to prioritise your research impact planning.

In this article, you can find resources and presentations that outline what MBIE and HRC look for in their research impact sections and how to approach writing these sections. Additionally, you can access
1:1 support for the impact section of your application
here
MBIE funding
The MBIE
Endeavour Fund

has two main grants available: Research Programmes and Smart Ideas. Both require a thoroughly articulated potential impact to Aotearoa New Zealand and a well-thought-through and resourced impact plan.
HRC funding
The Health Research Council has a range of
funding opportunities
and has specified a priority for delivering impact.

items.title: Research metadata
items.summary: Advice for enriching your research data and artefacts with high quality metadata to make them more discoverable, reusable, and verifiable.

content.value: Research metadata is the descriptive information attached to research data and artefacts that allow other people to find, verify, and reuse it. The metadata attached to research data is useful at multiple levels and for different purposes. For example:
At the project level:
What is the study about?
What methodology or process was used?
What instruments or devices were used?
What references were used?
At the file level:
What was done to the files?
What file formats are used and how are they opened?
Are there specific access rights or licensing?
Which version is the most current?
Within a file:
What is the meaning or definition of a specific variable or term?
Metadata standards

A good way to determine what metadata to capture is to think about the information someone else would need to understand your project and reuse the data. Many disciplines, repositories, or data centers use metadata standards or schemas. A metadata standard is a defined set of metadata fields that can be general or discipline specific.
Examples of metadata standards
Dublin Core - domain agnostic, basic and widely used metadata standard
DDI (Data Documentation Initiative) - common standard for social, behavioral and economic sciences, including survey data EML (Ecological Metadata Language) - specific for ecology disciplines
ISO 19115 and FGDC-CSDGM (Federal Geographic Data Committee's Content Standard for Digital Geospatial Metadata) - for describing geospatial information
MINSEQE (MINimal information about high throughput SEQeuencing Experiments) - Genomics standard
FITS (Flexible Image Transport System) - Astronomy digital file standard that includes structured, embedded metadata
BIDS - Brain Imaging Data Structure

items.title: Pacific data sovereignty
items.summary: An introduction to Pacific data sovereignty, including definitions, focus areas and applications throughout the research data lifecycle.

content.value: Pacific data and Pacific data sovereignty
Researchers are encouraged to consider Pacific data sovereignty in grant and ethics applications and throughout the research data lifecycle.
The
Pacific Data Sovereignty Network
(PDSN) offers a definition of Pacific data and Pacific data sovereignty within their
Consultation Document

published in February, 2021. Pacific data is described as existing "across terrains residing in traditional knowledge, scientific knowledge, digital spaces, and spiritual realms, which narrates a story of Pacific peoples, and builds on known or assumed facts."
The PDSN describes Pacific Data Sovereignty as being focused on:

Rights and responsibilities to determine the means of collection, access, analysis, management and dissemination of Pacific data or data deriving from Pacific data – inclusive of historical, existing, and impending datasets.
Producing information from and/or about Pacific peoples is driven by epistemologies, Pacific cultural values, Pacific traditional knowledge systems and that Pacific people maintain these.

Pacific peoples understanding of what data exists, the sources, access pathways, data management, the purpose of collection, how it was used and will be used in future. This will allow for Pacific stewardship of data that is enhancing and not destroying the vitality and wellbeing of Pacific communities and families.

Acknowledging the source of knowledge and from where data derives. Strategic and legal recognition of the Pacific as stewards of the interests that the data represents. This may entail authority and ownership of data bout Pacific, Pacific values, and Pacific interests. Ergo, data is curated and cared for by Pacific people.

items.title: Māori data sovereignty
items.summary: Resources for researchers on Māori data sovereignty.

content.value: Researchers are encouraged to consider responsiveness to Māori and Māori data sovereignty in grant and ethics applications and throughout the research data lifecycle.
What is Māori data and Māori data sovereignty?

spoke

Whanaungatanga - Obligations: Balancing rights, Accountabilities
Kotahitanga - Collective benefit: Benefit, Build capacity, Connect
Manaakitanga - Reciprocity: Respect, Consent
Kaitiakitanga - Guardianship: Guardianship, Ethics, Restrictions
The principles can be applied when starting your research planning through data capture, storage and governance.

items.title: Australia New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC) codes
items.summary: An overview of the ANZSRC classification system for different types of research, fields of research and socioeconomic objectives.

content.value: Overview of
ANZSRC codes

The Australia New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC) Codes are used by government departments, funding agencies, publishers and research organisations in Australia and New Zealand to classify research proposals, projects and publications. The ANZSRC was revised in 2020 and includes three related classification systems:
Types of Activity (ToAs)
Fields of Research (FoRs)
Socioeconomic Objectives (SEOs).
Importance of ANZSRC codes

ANZSRC codes are mandated by many research funders, such as the Ministry of Business Innovation and Employment (MBIE). This classification enables funders to invest in research using portfolio management principles and also assists with the monitoring and analysis of research trends and collaborations within and across different disciplines.
Types of Activity (ToAs)
ANZSRC 2020 recognises four ToAs:
Pure basic research

is basic research carried out for the advancement of knowledge, without seeking long-term economic or social benefits or making any effort to apply the results to practical problems or to transfer the results to sectors responsible for their application.
Strategic basic research

is experimental and theoretical work undertaken to acquire new knowledge directed into specified broad areas in the expectation of practical discoveries. It provides the broad base of knowledge necessary for the solution of recognised practical problems.
Applied research
is original investigation undertaken in order to acquire new knowledge. It is, however, directed primarily towards a specific, practical aim or objective.
Experimental development

is systematic work, drawing on knowledge gained from research and practical experience and producing additional knowledge, which is directed to producing new products or processes or to improving existing products or processes.
For a detailed overview, see the
StatsNZ Ariā ToA page.
Fields of Research (FoRs)
The FoR is a hierarchical classification of disciplines and fields of research that has three uniquely identified levels: Divisions (2 digits), Groups (4 digits) and Fields (6 digits).
Each Division is intended to represent a broad discipline and each Group is intended to represent a collection of related Fields of research.
For example, the Field of 090101 Aerodynamics is situated within the Group of 0901 Aerospace Engineering and the Division of 09 Engineering.
For a detailed overview, see the
StatsNZ Ariā FoR page.
Socioeconomic Objectives (SEOs)

The Socioeconomic Objectives (SEOs) classification is based on the intended purpose or outcome of the research. Related research Objectives (6 digits) are clustered into Groups (4 digits) and Divisions (2 digits).
For example, the Objective of 200307 Nursing is situated within the Group of 2003 Provision of health and support services and the Division of 20 Health.
For a detailed overview, see the
StatsNZ Ariā SEO page.
Data Management Plans
Data Management Plans (DMPs) are an ideal location for researchers to record their ANZSRC classifications.
For more information on creating a Data Management Plan, please visit
Create a data management plan (DMP)' ResearchHub page
2020 ANZSRC review
For additional information on the 2020 update to the ANZSRC, visit the
MBIE ANZSRC page.

items.title: Eduroam
items.summary: Access the internet and wireless networks while visiting other institutions using your Auckland username and password.

content.value: What is Eduroam?
Eduroam stands for "education roaming". It allows every University of Auckland staff member and student to log on to the Eduroam wireless network at another institution.

Eduroam is a federated authentication service that allows participating institutions to provide access to their wireless networks to users from other Eduroam participating institutions using the institutional username/password credentials password they use at their home institution.

Eduroam allows wireless network access at visited institutions automatically: users simply open their laptop or device configured to authenticate and connect via Eduroam (they will be remotely authenticated and authorised to access the visited institution's network).
Eduroam also allows visitors from participating institutions to access the wireless network at University of Auckland campuses.
Download and install Eduroam
Ensure you are connected to your home institution's network and
download Eduroam
Install Eduroam; once installed, you will be prompted to provide your UoA username email (
username@auckland.ac.nz
and password.
Test Eduroam; Anyone planning on using Eduroam while travelling should test their Eduroam connectivity here on campus at the University of Auckland first.
Connect to Eduroam around the world

If it works at UoA, it should work at any other institution that is enabled worldwide. If you can't connect while travelling, it could mean that the system configuration at that institution differs from the standard. In this case it would be best to delete/forget the Eduroam SSID from your device and then re-connect the Eduroam SSID at the institution you are visiting. Authentication will always come back to the University of Auckland.
Need help?
If you experience problems connecting to the service, to contact the local institution's IT support to assist with your setup. They can contact University of Auckland IT support if required.

items.title: Story completion
items.summary: Story completion is an innovative method for qualitative data collection.

content.value: Story completion is fairly new and innovative as a qualitative data collection approach, that takes researchers away from the direction of question-and-response approaches that dominate the social sciences (such as interviews, focus groups, or surveys) and into the realm of more creative methods.
With story completion, participants are asked to write a speculative ‘story’ in response to a brief cue (one, or sometimes more than one) developed by the researcher.

The method has origins in the projective tradition of clinical work, where people are asked to respond to an ambiguous stimulus as a tool to assess psychological characteristics. In qualitative research iterations, it’s mostly become a tool for understanding the social meaning worlds related to a topic of interest.

Story completion is being actively explored by researchers located in different traditions and places, across a number of disciplines. This site gives you the resources and context for understanding, and playing with, the method in your own research.
Audience: Anyone doing qualitative research, especially if wanting to explore creative, or online methods for data collection. Anyone teaching or supervising qualitative research.
Cost: Freely available
Availability: Service is available at any time

items.title: Thematic analysis
items.summary: Thematic analysis (TA) is an accessible method for analysing qualitative datasets, widely used across multiple disciplines.

content.value: The Thematic Analysis website (thematicanalysis.net) will provide you with everything you need to learn and start to do thematic analysis (TA). TA is a popular, widely used and accessible qualitative data analysis, characterised by theoretical flexibility, and suitable for use across many disciplinary areas, research fields, and topics. Developed by Virginia Braun and Victoria Clarke, recognised globally for their qualitative research expertise, this site provides a treasure trove of information and resources connected to TA. The site contains extensive resources for teaching and supervising TA, as well as learning about TA in order to conduct your own research. There are links to various talks and lectures, podcasts and publications, responses to a wide range of FAQs about thematic analysis, and an extensive list of resources.

Audience - Anyone doing qualitative research, especially if new to these approaches, and wanting information and guidance for doing thematic analysis of qualitative datasets. Anyone teaching or supervising thematic analysis.
Availability - This service is available at anytime.
Cost- Freely available.

items.title: Universitas 21 (U21)
items.summary: U21 is a leading network focused on educational innovation, student experience, international connectivity and global citizenship. U21 is comprised of 28 research-intensive comprehensive universities across the globe.

content.value: About U21

Universitas 21 empowers students and staff from 28 world-class universities to share excellence, collaborate across borders and nurture international knowledge exchange. U21 value’s cultural difference, connecting together perspectives from around the world, and harnessing the collective expertise of our exceptional institutions to benefit all members.
Themes and activities
Researcher engagement
U21 promotes international networking and skills development for doctoral students and early career academics via workshops, virtual networks, joint programmes and training opportunities.
Activities in this cluster are overseen by the Researcher Engagement Steering Group, and include:
Early career researcher workshops
Joint PhDs
Graduate collaborative research awards
3-Minute thesis competition
Global research ethics module
Educational innovation

The Educational Innovation cluster examines issues related to learning and teaching. It is concerned with developing effective and sustainable approaches to teaching in a rapidly changing digital environment, effective virtual and physical learning environments that adapt to changing learner needs and broad educational experience that prepares students to become global citizens.
Related groups and activities include:
Deans of education group
Forum for international networking in education (doctoral students in education)
Shared online course “critical thinking in global challenges”
Educational innovation conferences
Student Experience

Since its inception, U21 has been dedicated to promoting the exchange of international perspectives and fostering global citizenship. The network offers a myriad of opportunities for students to connect, network and develop their international awareness.
Staff members at participating institutions contribute to this cluster’s strategy via the Student Experience Steering Group and the Student Mobility Network.
Activities for students include:
U21 social entrepreneur corps
Global citizenship workshop
Global ingenuity challenge
RISE competition
Activities for doctoral students can be found under the Researcher Engagement cluster.
Collaborative groups & communities of practice

Academic and professional staff members can connect with colleagues in similar fields across U21 to discuss good practice, benchmark and collaborate on the development of programmes or solutions to common issues.
Existing collaborative groups include:
Health sciences
Research universities and their regions
Data Sharing (DS³) Group
For a list of U21 meetings, conferences and workshops, please visit
Upcoming network events
If you would like to connect with colleagues overseas through the U21 platform, please contact
Addison Pan
, International Networks Manager.
For further information about U21, please contact
Addison Pan
, International Networks Manager.

items.title: Association of Pacific Rim Universities (APRU)
items.summary: Since it was established in 1997, APRU has fostered cooperation among universities in the Pacific Rim community. Its membership includes 60 leading institutions based in 19 economies across Asia.

content.value: About APRU
Established in 1997, APRU brings together 60 universities from the Pacific Rim linking Asia, Oceania and the Americas.
APRU

positions itself as the “Voice of Knowledge and Innovation” for the Asia-Pacific region bringing together thought leaders, researchers, and policy-makers to exchange ideas and collaborate on effective solutions to the challenges of the 21st century.

APRU provides a platform for institutional leaders to work together in responding to the challenges that universities face due to changing economic, political and cultural environments. Through partnership between members, international organisations and the policy community, APRU aims to shape higher education and research in the Pacific Rim.

APRU’s primary research areas include disaster risk reduction, women in leadership, indigenous knowledge, virtual student exchange, e-sports, population aging, global health, sustainable cities, artificial intelligence, waste management, and more.
Partnering on solutions to Pacific Rim challenges

APRU facilitates the creation of programme hubs for research issues of particular interest to the Pacific Rim community. These hubs aim to leverage collective research strengths to engage international funding bodies and policy makers.
Current APRU research programmes include:
Digital economy
Global health
Multi-hazards
Biodiversity and Pacific ocean
Population ageing
Sustainable cities and landscapes
Sustainable waste management
United Nations Sustainable Development Goals
New APRU initiatives are introduced periodically. If you are involved in a new programme or would like to join an existing one, please contact
Addison Pan
, International Networks Manager.
Events
See the
APUR events
page for all upcoming and past events.
If you need further guidance with regards to the events applicable to you please contact
Addison Pan
, International Networks Manager.
Event recordings
APRU events hosted by the University of Auckland can be found on the
University YouTube channel.
UN climate change university partnership program information session

items.title: Research data management policy guidance
items.summary: Support for following the University's Research Data Management (RDM) Policy.

content.value:
Research Data Management Policy 
|
Te Kaupapa Here Whakahaere Raraunga Rangahau
Waipapa Taumata Rau, University of Auckland has introduced a
Research Data Management (RDM) Policy
, effective 1 July 2023.  The policy applies to all staff, students, supervisors and other members of the University community that are involved in the management of research data.
This policy provides clarity on the University’s requirements for the management of research data that are consistent with:
international standards for
FAIR data
and open research that are increasingly required by funders, data providers and publishers
the University’s obligations under Te Tiriti o Waitangi and commitment to becoming a Māori Data Sovereignty organisation
the CARE principles for the governance of indigenous data, including Pacific data
legal, ethical and protective security requirements for research data
This policy is supported by the
guidance, and the
Guidance on policy responsibilities
The RDM policy details 18 responsibilities across three groups; the University (1-3), researchers (4-16) and supervisors (17-18).
Researcher responsibilities | Ngā haepapa a te kairangahau
Supervisor responsibilities | Ngā haepapa a te kaimatapopore

items.title: UniServices
items.summary: UniServices links Waipapa Taumata Rau, University of Auckland researchers to industry, government, investors and communities to help them change the world for good.

content.value: UniServices: Bridging Academia and Innovation

UniServices, a not-for-profit company wholly owned by the University of Auckland, connects academia with industry, government, and communities to transform research into real-world impact. Established in 1988, UniServices supports researchers by securing funding, managing intellectual property, and fostering partnerships globally.
Learn more about UniServices team
Mission and values
UniServices aims to create a better future through collaboration, innovation, and community impact, acting as a bridge between academic discoveries and practical solutions.
What do UniService do?
Advancing research
UniServices collaborates with University of Auckland researchers to enhance their work, providing support through funding opportunities and partnerships with government and industry.
Learn more about advancing your research
Investing & partnering

They invest in and partner with start-ups and technologies from research, aiming to create global impact. This includes managing the University of Auckland Inventors' Fund and fostering Māori partnerships.
Learn more about investing & partnering
Entrepreneurial journey
UniServices assists researchers in commercializing their ideas, whether through start-ups or licensing technologies, offering guidance on intellectual property and funding.
Learn more about the entrepreneurial journey
Services & projects
UniServices run various projects and programs that leverage university research to benefit the community in fields like health, education, and public policy.
Learn more about services & projects
Performance and impact

In 2023, UniServices launched eight companies and licensed 27 patents. The University of Auckland Inventors’ Fund was valued at $41 million. Their initiatives in health education and community engagement highlight their broad impact.
Global and community collaboration
UniServices partners with researchers, entrepreneurs, investors, and government agencies globally, ensuring research benefits society worldwide

items.title: Research ethics survey
items.summary: Learn more abou the research ethics survey which is now closed. Results are expected to be shared in Q3.

content.value: The survey is now closed. Thanks for those who have provided feedback

Researchers, academic staff, doctoral and master’s students, and professional staff were invited to participate in the Research Ethics survey which closed on the 7 of July 2024. The survey seeks feedback and ideas to improve the research ethics experience at Waipapa Taumata Rau | University of Auckland.
The survey is part of the
Research Ethics Improvement Plan

which aims to enhance the ethics ecosystem for researchers by addressing current and future ethical challenges; and align the University research ethics ecosystem with National Ethics Advisory Committee (NEAC) guidelines (revisions to be released in 2024) and Te Ara Tika Guidelines.

In addition, the survey responds to concerns about the complexity of ethics processes for 'low risk' research (identified in 2021 researcher journey mapping) and seeks ideas from researchers on alternative pathways.
Research ethics survey results
Your feedback will help us to understand where we could enhance ethics information, systems, processes, training and pathways, as part of the
Research Ethics Improvement Plan
Survey insights and results will be shared Q3 2024.
Stakeholder engagement

In addition to the survey, further engagement and workshops will be planned with Faculty Based Ethics Advisors and Māori ethics advisors and key stakeholders on the University’s approach to implementing Te Ara Tika Guidelines.

The Research Ethics survey follows the recent UniForum Service Excellence Survey, with targeted and specific questions to gather more detailed insights on human ethics, animal ethics, and biological safety challenges, aiming to identify improvement opportunities.
Queries
If you have any questions about the survey, you may contact the Research Ethics Improvement Plan Change Manager, Christine Mullan:
Christine.mullan@auckland.ac.nz
Thank you for participating!

items.title: Amendments to an animal ethics applications
items.summary: Amendments to the approved protocol must also be approved by the Animal Ethics Committee.

content.value: Amendments

Changes to the protocol can only come into effect after approval by the AEC. Please be aware that obtaining approval for an amendment may take several days to weeks, depending on the nature of the requested change and on when the next AEC meeting will take place.

Minor changes may be considered by the Chair of the AEC, but most changes will require consideration by the whole AEC at the next meeting. Significant changes to the protocol - including a change of the aim of the project - require a new submission.
To apply for an amendment approval by the AEC, please make a submission as instructed below.
Applications for changes to the approved protocol
Submissions of Amendment Requests or Changes of Personnel can be submitted online.
User Guide for electronic submission:
See Ethics RM guides (Research Management Libray Sharepoint)
Direct link to the Electronic Research Management system:
https://apply.ethics.research.auckland.ac.nz/
Examples of amendment requests:
Addition of Personnel

Addition of Personnel requests will be processed as soon as possible and do not require consideration by the whole AEC. However, approval of an Addition of Personnel will be conditional on the new person completing the compulsory training modules they have not already done so.
Change of the Principal Investigator

If the Principal Investigator resigns, the investigator who is currently responsible for the protocol needs to submit an amendment request in Ethics RM to request the replacement of the PI, together with a written progress report of the project (numbers used to date, staff changes, outcomes so far, etc.).
The amendment request needs to be signed by the resigning PI and the new PI, requesting transfer of responsibility. This is considered a Major Amendment and needs to be considered at an AEC meeting.
Increase of animal numbers and/or variance to approved protocol

Any increase in the number of animals used, or any modification or addition of manipulations, requires prior approval by the AEC. If required, discuss the change in protocol with the animal facility first, to ensure that the amended protocol can be facilitated.
Extension of time

Most protocols are approved for three years and extensions to the approval period are not encouraged. In extenuating circumstances (e.g. a late start due to slow recruitment of staff or securing of funding) the AEC will consider a brief extension, if this enables the work to be completed.

items.title: Apply to use higher risk micro-organisms
items.summary: Procedure for making an application to work with higher risk micro-organisms. Prior UABSC approval is required before undertaking any work with higher risk organisms.

content.value: Introduction and higher risk microorganisms definition
Higher risk microorganisms
are defined as:
Risk Group 2, 3, and 4 micro-organisms (whether Genetically Modified Organisms (GMOs) or unmodified micro-organisms) as defined by the
Australian/New Zealand Standard “2243-3:2010 Safety in laboratories Part 3: Microbiological safety and containment”
and/or
the United States National Institute of Health “
Guidelines for Research Involving Recombinant DNA Molecules
Any microorganism that displays resistance to antibiotics and/or treatments used to clinically treat the microorganism in question.

Criteria for assessment is similar to HSNO decision-making but also includes additional factors such as the pathogenicity of the microorganism, the expertise of the applicants, and the proposed protocols and controls.

Refer to the NIH Classification of Biohazardous Micro-organisms by Risk Group. Researchers who are unsure of the risk group classification for a particular microorganism should in the first instance contact the
Biological Safety Officer
Application process – how to apply to use higher risk microorganisms
Create a new Biological Safety Application – “
Application to use higher risk microorganisms”
using
Ethics RM
following the steps in the
Infonetica Ethics RM – Creating an application
guide, noting the following:
The application form is intended to provide guidance to the applicants.  Applicants should supply any additional information relevant to the application.

Applicants are encouraged to ensure that the descriptions of any experimental protocols are written so that they can be understood by lay members. However, there will be parts of the application that require technical detail. Where this is the case, please ensure that sufficient detail is supplied so the scientific members can readily assess the proposal.
Emphasis should be placed on protocols to mitigate risk when working with these organisms.
Applicants should state the location where proposed work is to be undertaken and the staff and students involved in the project.

The Committee encourages applicants who have limited experience with high risk microorganisms to consult/collaborate with a microbiologist or infectious disease specialist prior to developing their application.
Submit the application following the steps in the Infonetica Ethics RM –
Submitting an Application – no sign-off (Biological Safety Committee applications only)
guide.

Note that the Principal Investigator must submit the application as they will be agreeing to terms and conditions of the 
application in the process of submission.
The application must be submitted at least 10 working days before the next
UABSC scheduled meeting
Committee requests for further information

During the assessment of the application, the Committee may decide that it needs further information prior to coming to a final decision. You will be informed formally by letter what further information the Committee would like added to the application. Please be aware that the application is formally stalled once the request for information is sent.
After you have amended the application form, re-submit the form for review. Only major revisions will require full Committee re-review.

items.title: Research data classification standard
items.summary: Definitions and examples of the University's data classification and confidentiality standard as they relate to research data.

content.value: Research data classification standard

The University has a four-tier data classification standard to be applied to all research data at Waipapa Taumata Rau and its subsidiary, Auckland UniServices Limited. This is based on work by peer institutions within Aotearoa New Zealand and internationally, and the
government’s classifications for information security

. 

The standard is incorporated into the
Research Data Management Policy

and informs rights on access, storage, sharing, distribution and handling of data. It supports recognition and understanding of the value of research data and the identification and management of associated risks.
Data are to be classified as:
Public
Internal
Sensitive
Restricted
Applying the standard

Researchers are to consider all the types of data they will be working with for a particular project and select one or more data classifications using the descriptions and examples included in the table below. They should then refer to the Research Data Management Policy and
guidance
and ensure that this classification is recorded in their
Data Management Plan

items.title: Use of Data from Biobanks
items.summary: To clarify the University’s expectations around the ethical requirements when using data from established biobanks

content.value: Biobank

Researchers must apply to the AHREC ethics committee for ethical approval to use data from a biobank. This applies even in cases where the biobank has its own local ethics approval. The only instance where researchers can currently utilise information contained in a biobank without first gaining AHREC ethics approval is where an exemption applies:
3.1.1   Exemptions
The following are exempt from ethics approval:
Teaching and course evaluations within the University, including all Education Committee-approved surveys listed in the Student Survey Plan that are not for the purpose of research or publication
Departmental reviews and similar evaluations
Surveys, questionnaires or interviews by University members undertaken not for the purposes of research but only for improving the teaching and administrative activities of the University

A solitary interview with an individual public figure about public matters, or an interview with a single participant who is asked to discuss his or her area of expertise and who can reasonably be regarded as having sufficient seniority and experience to be aware of, and protect, his or her own interests with regard to the research and its publication. However, a series of interviews with a single person or a number of persons on the same topic does require approval
Observational studies in public where participants are not identifiable
Discussions of a preliminary nature that will assist in the development of a research study or instrument, but will not provide data to be incorporated into the research dataset
Research using only published or publicly available data

Research that is undertaken independently of the University (for example, in private consultancy), so long as the participants are told at the outset that the research is not connected with the University. Under no circumstances should the name of the University, the researcher’s University title or the University logo be used. In these circumstances researchers are advised to check for any independent institutional ethical review requirements.
Published or publicly available information exemption

Researchers who rely on the ‘published or publicly available data’ exemption in 3.1.1 of University of Auckland’s ‘Guiding Principles’ must ensure the biobank data fits the criteria for ‘published or publicly available’.  If the data is not freely available to members of the public, then this will not fall within the exemption. Please be careful when you consider this question, as some University of Auckland researchers may have permissions to datasets through University (or other work) logins, and may not be aware that this data is not accessible to the general public.
For the avoidance of doubt, consideration should be given to the following:
Are researchers required to sign an access agreement?
Do you need to submit information about you and your team to gain approval?
Are you required to submit information about the study design?
Does the biobank have a review committee / process whereby some researchers are denied access to the data?
If you answer ‘yes’ to any of these questions, researchers will not be able to rely on the exemption in 3.1.1.
Case Scenario: UK Biobank
The UK Biobank is a very well-established biobank that researchers may seek to use for the purposes of their research.
The
UK Biobank

has gained local ethics approval and is a potential source of high-quality data. To use data from the UK Biobank, signing of a Material Transfer Agreement (MTA) is required. Researchers are also required to submit an application form and payment of an administration fee.  This process means the biobank data information is not considered publicly available under the exemption in 3.1.1 and researchers will need to submit an ethics application prior to use of data from the UK biobank. In addition, careful reading of the ethics approval for the UK Biobank shows the approval is only valid in the UK, even though the website currently states ‘that researchers do not require separate ethical clearance and can operate under the RTB (Research Tissue Bank) approval’.
University Biobank ethics approval requirement

Unless data contained in a biobank falls within exemption 3.1.1 of the University of Auckland guidelines, researchers using biobanks (whether the UK biobank or other biobanks) are required to apply for ethics approval from AHREC.
The National Ethics Advisory Committee has further guidance on biobanks and researchers should be familiar with ethical obligations contained in that advisory.
National Ethical Standards for Health and Disability Research and Quality Improvement | National Ethics Advisory Committee
That advice states:

A biobank is a collection of human tissue samples stored for potential use in research beyond the life of a specific study.
To be a biobank, a tissue collection must contain both:
human biological materials, with or without genetic information generated from their analysis; and
associated demographic and health information.
Some common features of biobanks are as follows:
They are ongoing and open-ended, which allows for unspecified future research and the donation of tissue that is stored for definite or indefinite periods.

They need tissue and data to remain potentially re-identifiable, even if they are coded, because researchers may need to link tissue and associated data to other sources of health information for studies in the future, or to follow up information added over time.

They focus on the common good, with a greater concern for future public benefit than individual benefit for participants themselves. Currently, many studies that make use of biobanks offer no direct or immediate benefit to individual donors.

There are additional ethical concerns in the New Zealand context with the establishment and use of biobank material when we consider Te Ara Tika Māori ethics principles. Researchers should be aware of these additional obligations and address these concerns when submitting an ethics application.
Further reading:
FAQs: Where
to seek further assistance about Biobanks
I am using a biobank in my current research but did not seek ethics approval before use. Where do I go to for assistance?
You should contact the
Research Integrity Officer,
Elizabeth Visser, who can assist you in navigating what your next steps should be.
I have an overseas collaborator who uses a local biobank and has obtained ethics approval from their institution. What approvals from UOA do I need?

Contact the Ethics Team to gain advice on whether you can apply for a ratification of the overseas ethics approval. If so, this is a streamlined process that the Ethics Team can help you navigate. Otherwise, you must apply for full ethics approval from AHREC (unless exemptions apply).
I am using a biobank with local ethics approval (e.g., the UK Biobank), and I want to use secondary data from this for a new project. What permissions from the UOA do I need?
You must contact the Ethics Team, who can guide you through the exemption criteria and advise you on submitting an ethics application to AHREC (if no exemption applies).
I am using data from several biobanks in my research and am about to seek publication. I did not apply to UOA for ethics approval. What should I do?
You should first contact the
Research Integrity Officer
to determine how to proceed. The Ethics Committee cannot grant retrospective approval.

items.title: Choosing data storage
items.summary: An overview of University-managed research data storage options.

content.value: Research data storage options
The University of Auckland provides a range of data storage options for research data, but in general, researchers are advised to use one or both of:
Request research data storage
Research Drive
and
Dropbox for research
can be requested by research staff and doctoral candidates.  Other postgraduate research students, external collaborators, and visiting academics may be added as collaborators.

Research data storage is allocated by research project to enable appropriate governance (e.g., ethics conditions, access restrictions, retention, long-term stewardship). Therefore, storage requests must contain basic information about the project, researchers involved, and data.
Advice is available through the Centre for eResearch
service.

items.title: New Zealand research funding landscape
items.summary: Understand the NZ research funding landscape in the context of the University of Auckland and the support available.

content.value: UoA plays a prominent role in the
NZ research environment
as the largest of
New Zealand’s eight universities
This diagram shows the New Zealand research funding landscape in 2023:
Image from
Endeavour Fund Investment Plan

Funding sources can be investigator-led (researcher proposes subject), mission-led (researcher proposes topic within a theme) and end-user led (funding targeting particular problems). To obtain funding researchers must articulate how their research fits a funding source, how best to pitch an idea and what partnerships might be possible with industry, research collaborators and/or community groups.

Royal Society of New Zealand
