items.title: Evidencing your impact
items.summary: Evidencing impact through a variety of methods will build a robust case for impact.

content.value: Evidencing your impact indicators and creating a record does not need to be difficult or time-intensive, but it will be easier if you include capturing your impact in your impact plan.
What kind of evidence should I capture?

In many cases, testimonials may be the most appropriate evidence to collect. You can also consider other relevant evidence for each indicator, such as reports, policy, guidelines, and so on. Each impact indicator could be informed by several different types of evidence.
How do I capture evidence?

Having a plan for capturing impact evidence can ensure that you regularly search for evidence of impact. It is also important to have a system to help you collect and organise your collected evidence. Some options include:
The
impact module in Research Outputs
The
Researcher Impact Database
template
or the
Research Project Impact Database
template
A spreadsheet or folder of documents
A folder in your email

There are also specialised tools commercially available that can help you record evidence of impact, though you may need to include these in your research budget. You can structure these evidence logs around the impact indicators that you have chosen.
If you are unsure about what the potential impact of your research might be and what evidence you might be able to capture, you may find the following resources useful.
Guidance for collecting evidence of impact
Further resources
Capturing impact from social media
Guide for evaluating public engagement activities
Impact module in Research Outputs (available to all researchers at Waipapa Taumata Rau)
Grow Impact (a tool designed specifically to aid researchers in tracking the impact of their research)

items.title: Reporting requirements for animal ethics
items.summary: Annual animal usage returns and an end of approval report must be submitted online via Infonetica. Responsible Investigators must also report all clinical incidents and unexpected adverse events.

content.value: Reporting by the AEC

Each year, the reports on all AEC approved protocols are collated into a report that the AEC needs to send to the University Council and to MPI. MPI collects data on the numbers and types of animals used in approved programmes throughout New Zealand. Therefore, it is important that you report the actual numbers of animals used and the severity of the manipulations, in a correct and timely manner.

The 1999 Regulations provide that institutions must keep readily accessible records of all experiments involving animals and provide this to MPI annually and on request. The regulations also specify that records must be kept for five years following the expiry of the period of approval.
End of approval reporting
Research
When the project finishes, or when the approval expires, an End of Approval report is to be submitted online. This should take place, within three months.
The report will capture information on the manipulations that were performed or the tissues collected, the number of animals used and the outcome of the project.
A Final Animal Usage Return for the final year, or part year of the project together with the End of Approval Report is to be submitted online via the Infonetica Ethics RM system.
Teaching
When the project finishes, or when the approval expires, the
Teaching Questionnaire and Summary of Responses
, is to be submitted via e-mail to the
Animal Ethics Administrator

A Final Animal Usage Return must be submitted online via the Infonetica Ethics RM system. The report will capture information on the manipulations that were performed or the tissues collected, the number of animals used, and the outcome of the project.
Animal welfare issues or incidents

If anything unexpected happens before, during or after manipulations, and this affects animal welfare, it needs to be reported as soon as possible. Urgent welfare concerns must be acted upon immediately by contacting a team leader or unit manager of the animal facility. In all cases, report the issue or incident using the appropriate form below, and contact the
Animal Welfare Officer
or
Animal Ethics Administrator
as soon as possible.

All deaths that occur prior to the planned end of experiment must be notified to the Animal Welfare Officer as soon as possible so that a post mortem examination can be carried out if necessary. These include:
Animals that are found dead or moribund.
Animals that are killed due to abnormalities which make them not fit for purpose.
Sick animals should be reported to the animal facility manager as soon as possible, using a
Clinical Incident Form
(also known as a Sick and Dead Animal Report) which is available in all animal facilities.
Note: Husbandry or experimental incidents that have impacted or may impact animal welfare (e.g. power cut, accidental overdose of anaesthetic, flooded cage) must be reported according to the
Unexpected Adverse Event Report
. The Animal Facility Manager must also be notified.

items.title: ARRIVE guidelines
items.summary: The ARRIVE guidelines ensure that studies are reported in enough detail to add to the knowledge base. Reporting animal research in adherence with the ARRIVE guidelines ensures transparent and thorough reporting.

content.value: The ARRIVE guidelines are relevant to any study involving live animals, from mammals to fish, as well as invertebrates, in any area of the biosciences. The guidelines are primarily aimed at researchers, reviewers and journal editors of studies involving animals.
The guidelines and associated resources are useful throughout the course of a study:
During study planning

The guidelines and accompanying Explanation and Elaboration document provide advice on experimental design, minimisation of bias, sample size and statistical analyses, helping researchers design rigorous and reliable
in vivo
experiments.
During the conduct of a study
This allows researchers to record important information about study methods, which will be needed later for manuscript preparation.
When writing a manuscript
Used as an
aide memoire
to ensure the manuscript contains all relevant information.
When reviewing a manuscript
To ensure all relevant information is available to scrutinize and replicate the work.

items.title: PREPARE guidelines
items.summary: PREPARE (Planning Research and Experimental Procedures on Animals: Recommendations for Excellence)

content.value: As part of efforts to reduce animal waste, promote alternatives, and increase the reproducibility of research and testing, a group of experts from the UK and Norway, have  produced a set of guidelines for
planning
animal experiments:
PREPARE
P
lanning
R
esearch and
E
xperimental
P
rocedures on
A
nimals:
R
ecommendations for
E
xcellence)
PREPARE covers the three broad areas which determine the quality of the preparation for animal studies:
Formulation of the study

1. Literature searches
2. Legal issues
3. Ethical issues, harm-benefit assessment and humane endpoints
4. Experimental design and statistical analysis
Dialogue between scientists and the animal facility

5. Objectives and timescale, funding and division of labour
6. Facility evaluation
7. Education and training
8. Health risks, waste disposal and decontamination
Methods

9. Test substances and procedures
10. Experimental animals
11. Quarantine and health monitoring
12. Housing and husbandry
13. Experimental procedures
14. Humane killing, release, reuse or rehoming
15. Necropsy

items.title: Monitoring after animal ethics approval
items.summary: The Animal Welfare Officer is a regular visitor to most animal facilities. They are involved in formal monitoring activities, such as welfare reviews, but they also pay informal visits to see how things go, inspect animals, and provide advice.

content.value: Animal Ethics Committee visits

Members of the Animal Ethics Committee (AEC) pay regular visits to animal facilities and Principal Investigators (PI) to monitor animal management practices, and to ensure compliance with the conditions of the approval and the terms of the Code of Ethical Conduct.

Please note that these post-approval visits are a requirement under the Animal Welfare Act 1999. A scheduled visit by either the Animal Welfare Officer or by members of the AEC does not imply any breach of conditions by the researchers.
During these visits the members of the AEC will pay attention to animal care and welfare, record maintenance and the use of appropriate techniques, equipment and facilities.
The monitoring activities of the AEC are broadly classified into three categories:
Facility visits -
These are structured visits to animal facilities, to check animal management practices and compliance with Standard Operating Procedures.
Welfare reviews -

These visits focus more on individual procedures or components of an approval, rather than the whole protocol. Welfare reviews are based on conditions imposed by the AEC, usually involving the monitoring of new procedures or models, or manipulations with high animal welfare impact.
Ethical reviews -

These are routine visits to Responsible Investigators to review compliance with their current protocols and the progress of the research project, taking all aspects of the approval into account. The AEC aims to visit every PI at least once during the approval period. These visits also offer an opportunity for PIs to ask questions and to provide feedback to the AEC.
If you have any animal welfare questions or concerns, do not hesitate to contact the Animal Welfare Officer.

items.title: Disclose and protect your idea
items.summary: Find out about how UniServices' investment and partnering opportunities can help unlock innovative collaborations for academic, commercial, and social advancement.

content.value: Disclose and protect your idea

If you believe your research at Waipapa Taumata Rau, University of Auckland has investment potential, the first step is to confidentially share your idea with us so we can help ensure your intellectual property (IP) is protected.

If you invented something, securing a patent, ensures you’re recognised as the inventor. This ensures you can benefit from any commercialisation opportunities. UniServices can help you with this. If you don’t disclose your idea to us early and get advice on next steps, there’s a significant chance that you or someone else may inadvertently disclose the idea through publication or public presentation. This may make it impossible for you to patent your idea and commercialise it later. Patenting and publishing are not mutually exclusive but it is important to get the timing right, otherwise the opportunity to apply for a patent may lapse.
Securing your Intellectual Property (IP) rights, including patents, copyright and trademarks means you’re starting your company on a solid foundation. UniServices also has
template documents
you can use to legally start your company on solid footing.
New business venture also need capital. UniServices manages the
University of Auckland Inventors’ Fund, which
might be able to help.
Protecting your idea
Protecting your idea involves idea disclosure, which is a submission process that involves providing a description of your invention or development to us. You can use our
idea disclosure form
(available for current Waipapa Taumata Rau, University of Auckland staff and students only), or you can phone or send an email to our team. We will ask:
What your idea or invention is, including what problem it solves and what applications it can be used for.
Who invented it, including names and institutional affiliations.
Whether you’ve published or presented the idea.
If you’ve had funding for the research, from what sources.
If there are any mātauranga Māori aspects to your idea.
Why you think your idea may have commercial value.
How we can contact you and any co-inventors.
Contact UniServices on
ip@uniservices.co.nz
to find out more.

items.title: FoS Shared Research Equipment (ShaRE)
items.summary: ShaRE houses core research platforms within the Faculty of Science to help people access the key analytical equipment and expertise necessary to support quality research and teaching.

content.value: ShaRE brings together related or complementary pieces of analytical equipment and their expert operators and services from across the Faculty of Science and coordinates the hire and use of major and specialised equipment within the faculty.

ShaRE's equipment and technical expertise are grouped into the following platforms: Auckland Cytometry, Auckland Genomics, Imaging Centre (SBS, SCS), Mass Spectrometry Centre, Microcharaterisation (ENV, SCS) and the Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) Centre.
Across these platforms, there are more than 70 individual analytical instruments available for use by researchers and postgraduate students.
Eligibility

Postgraduate students and University Staff can access centre equipment and expertise. Teaching and student use outside of a user-pays model can be developed via consultation with the relevant centre's advisory board.
External and commercial users are also able to access the cores and their equipment and services.
Cost
The cost varies across equipment and services, with University of Auckland usage subsidised. For more information please read the
ShaRE FAQ
Access requirements
Most ShaRE equipment, training, and services are requested and accessed via iLab.
Considerations

Facilities within ShaRE are distributed across the campus. The transport of some biological material between facilities for analysis may require approval and designated processes to be adhered to. Each core within ShaRE has its own key contacts who you should approach to discuss your research needs.

items.title: Mass Spectrometry Hub (MaSH)
items.summary: The Mass Spectrometry Hub (MaSH) provides support to develop an outstanding technical and research environment to increase the effective impact of University of Auckland mass spectrometry-based research.

content.value: About MaSH
The
Mass Spectrometry Hub (MaSH)
brings together researchers and technical staff from across the university to foster interdisciplinary collaboration and develop our mass spectrometry data analysis capability and knowledge base.
MaSH provides:
Engagement between researchers, technical staff and available equipment.
Informed instrument selection and advanced information.
Opportunities for theoretical and practical training of students.
Software and data analysis workflow solutions.
Updated mass spectrometry related News and Events.
Information about mass spectrometry courses, seminars, and conferences.
Subscribe to MaSH
The MaSH website describes in detail a wealth of supporting resources and information. Subscribe to the
MaSH webpage
to stay up to date with all new information. The subscribe button is found at the bottom right corner of the
MaSH webpage
Mass Spectrometry equipment at UoA
Access software and data analysis tools
The majority of software and data analysis tools are located on virtual machines and can be accessed anywhere in the world by University of Auckland staff and students.
Life Science Mass Spectrometry (LSMS) research
Eligibility

Postgraduate students, doctoral candidates, and university staff are eligible for instrument use. External users are eligible to use some of the instrumentation (see specific instrument page for details).
Access
Access and operation of mass spectrometers are specific to each instrument. Make contact with the instrument experts using the information on the

Data analysis software usage is free of charge; however, user charges do apply for all mass spectrometry equipment. Contact us or the instrument manager to discuss your project and for specific cost details.

items.title: Systematic review guide
items.summary: A systematic review aims to answer a research question by identifying, critically appraising and synthesising relevant primary evidence. This guide gives essential foundation information for anyone who is new to systematic reviews.

content.value: What is a systematic review?

A systematic review aims to answer a research question by identifying, critically appraising and synthesising relevant primary evidence. Systematic reviews are large research projects that take a lot of time, effort and dedication. Before embarking on a systematic review, it is recommended that you familiarise yourself with the methodology and resources required to ensure this type of review is appropriate for your research topic.

Given the prolific nature of academic publishing, it is difficult to come to a conclusion based on single research papers. By identifying, critically appraising and synthesising primary evidence, the systematic review methodology enables researchers to give a more reliable and complete picture of a topic than individual pieces of research. Systematic reviews are mostly found in medical disciplines but are becoming more common in other fields.
Te Tumu Herenga | Libraries and Learning Services Support
Te Tumu Herenga | Libraries and Learning Services have created a
Systematic Review Guide

for anyone who is new to the systematic review process. This guide introduces the overall process and timeline of a systematic review. It also provides support and guidance on creating a highly sensitive search strategy, an integral part of a systematic review.
To get advice and feedback on your systematic review search strategy, please submit an
AskUs
request.

items.title: Reference management software
items.summary: Dealing with a large number of references? Reference management software can help you organise your references and reference correctly.

content.value: R

eference management software tools (e.g., Endnote, RefWorks, Mendeley and Zotero) will allow you to keep a record of your literature, make notes, organise your readings and retrieve references when you need to use them.

Before selecting and using a reference management tool it is important to first learn to reference in your chosen style(s), including emerging reference types like Generative AI. The quality or accuracy of your finished references will only be as good as the quality of the data entered.

items.title: New Zealand eScience Infrastructure (NeSI)
items.summary: NeSI provides a national platform of shared high performance computing tools and eResearch services. The University has invested in NeSI's infrastructure and services, enabling research projects to access NeSI resources and services for free.

content.value: Services and training

Is NeSI for me?
If you have computational or data-intensive work as part of your research and you would like to run it at scale or faster than your local machine, consider using NeSI.

We support research projects across all domains, from climate change investigations, to human and taonga species genomics, to national responses to a pandemic. Examples from Waipapa Taumata Rau include:

items.title: Confidentiality and Non-Disclosure Agreements
items.summary: A Confidentiality and Non-Disclosure Agreement should always be in place prior to having conversations or meetings in which confidential information may be disclosed.

content.value: A Confidentiality and Non-Disclosure Agreement (CDA) is a legally binding agreement put in place when two or more parties will be sharing confidential information and wish to ensure that such information remains confidential and is not disclosed, published or disseminated to other parties.
This may be required by a client/funder, but a CDA should always be in place prior to having conversations or meetings in which confidential information may be disclosed.

Confidential  Information can include scientific, technical or trade information, techniques, formulations, equipment, tests, data, reports, intellectual property, know-how, information concerning the scope or activities of research, samples and materials, and so forth.

The primary role of CDA is to restrict the unauthorised disclosure of Confidential Information and to prohibit the unauthorised use of this Confidential Information. They are intended as an interim measure to facilitate preliminary discussions and assess any possible opportunities before a contract for a project is established.
As CDAs are legal documents, they must be reviewed and signed by the
Research Grants & Contracts
Managers. To discuss your requirements and progress your request for a CDA/NDA please contact FIRST, who will submit a
Service Cloud Request
to your
Research Grants & Contracts
Manager.
If you are unsure whether a CDA/NDA is required, please contact your Contracts Manager.
Types of CDA
A
one-way

CDA is used when only one of the parties to the agreement will be disclosing information. If the client/funder is the only party exchanging information, it is important to ensure that confidential information is not shared in return, as they will have no obligation to keep this confidential.
A
two-way

CDA is used when all parties to the agreement will be disclosing Confidential Information. This can also be used when there are more than two parties to the agreement. This is the preferred type of CDA as it protects all parties.
The Research Grants & Contracts Team
has templates for both these types of agreements and the preferred position is to use the
Research Grants & Contracts Team
templates where possible.
Obligations of CDAs
CDAs bind the parties to keep shared information relating to a specific field and purpose confidential for an agreed period of time.

Generally, CDAs will cover a period of 12 months and consequently, any information disclosed during that period will be bound by the provisions of the agreement. However, the obligations of confidentiality usually extend well beyond the term of the agreement, typically for a period of five years.

It is important that the obligation of confidentiality is clearly understood and adhered to, as the consequences of breaking a confidentiality agreement are severe, and could result in significant liability for the University.

items.title: Memorandum of Understanding
items.summary: A Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) is a formal non-binding agreement between two or more parties outlining the terms and details of an understanding, including each parties' requirements and responsibilities.

content.value: A Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) could be required in two main scenarios:
Applying for funding or submitting a proposal in collaboration with another party
Recording general intentions to collaborate, share ideas and work together in the future

An MOU is often the first stage in the formation of a formal contract however, it is not usually legally binding unless it is 
explicitly stated as such.
To discuss requirements and to request an MOU, please contact FIRST who will submit a
Service Cloud request
to your
Research Grants & Contracts
Manager so that they can begin drafting and negotiating the agreement.
If you are unsure whether an MOU is required, please contact your
Research Grants & Contracts
Manager.
MOUs for Proposals

Increasingly, funding bodies such as the HRC, MBIE and Marsden are encouraging inter-institutional research with policies that require evidence of research collaboration. Therefore funding applications may require agreements with individuals or groups working at other institutions.
It is important that before the application is submitted, the parties involved in the collaborative research project have reached a formal agreement on:
how the funds are allocated or reallocated if the amount requested is different from the amount awarded
how the costs of the research and overheads are allocated or re-allocated between institutions
how the intellectual property ownership rights of all parties are defined.
General MOUs

Often when industry clients are exploring ways to engage with the University, they begin the process by formally recording how the parties will collaborate and the intentions of the collaboration, such as identifying research projects with mutually beneficial outcomes.

Some international clients in particular place a great deal of importance on establishing MOUs, as they are considered to carry a degree of seriousness and mutual respect, stronger than a gentlemen's agreement.

items.title: Material transfer agreements
items.summary: To meet the University’s health and safety obligations and protect  intellectual property, transfers of certain experimental materials to or from the University of Auckland must be covered by a formal contract between the transferring organisations.

content.value: To ensure that the University’s legislative obligations for health and safety are met, and to protect researchers’ and the University’s intellectual property, transfers of certain experimental materials to or from the University of Auckland must be covered by a formal contract between the transferring organisations. Such contracts may be in the form of a Material Transfer Agreement (MTA) or Conditions of Supply Form (CSF).
These contracts must be negotiated and executed by the
Research Grants & Contracts
team. If you are unsure if you require a MTA, please seek advice in the first instance from the
Research Grants & Contracts
team.
To discuss your requirements and progress your request for a MTA please contact FIRST, who will submit a
Service Cloud request
to your
Research Grants & Contracts Manager
A Material Transfer Agreement (MTA) is required for the following material:
experimental material that has commercial or potential commercial application and is or may be subject to
Research Grants & Contracts
or Intellectual Property agreements
experimental material with therapeutic application
experimental material that is pathogenic, hazardous, contains radionuclides or whose properties are unknown
cell-lines established from tissue taken in New Zealand.

Biological materials, such as reagents, cell lines, plasmids, and vectors, are the most frequently transferred materials, but MTAs may also be used for other types of materials, such as chemical compounds and even some types of software.
A Conditions of Supply Form (CSF) is required for the following material:
material that is readily available for sale by other parties and which will be supplied with no restrictions to subsequent resale
polyclonal/monoclonal antibodies and non-hazardous materials that are not covered by
Research Grants & Contracts
or Intellectual Property agreements
Specimens fixed in formaldehyde or ethanol from animals excluding human specimens.

items.title: Data sharing agreements
items.summary: Advice for preparing a data sharing agreement with external parties to protect yourself, your project, and your participants.

content.value: Data sharing

Data sharing or data transfer is a common practice in many research projects and may occur with data or service providers, collaborators, or participants. Research projects must ensure that legal, ethical, data sovereignty and commercial constraints relating to primary materials and digital research data processing, access and storage, are considered prior to data collection and adhered to throughout the research data lifecycle. This is particularly important where human data are concerned.
The requirements and obligations surrounding data sharing outside the University are many and relate to the following:
The Privacy Act 2020
National Ethical Standards
University of Auckland
Research Data Management (RDM) Policy
Other useful advice relating to data privacy and data management within New Zealand can be
found here

Researchers may first consider issues of privacy when they propose to collect or gather data from or about participants as part of obtaining ethics approval. However, having ethics approval does not cover all the issues you need to consider when you share (send or receive) data from external sources; and often, researchers may need to share data prior to funding or ethics approval.
Data sharing or data transfer agreements reduce the University's exposure to legal and reputational risks, and can support researchers to commercialise their research.
University requirement

According to the RDM Policy, researchers are responsible for ensuring collaborations with external parties have agreements in place that specify ownership and custodianship rights and responsibilities for research data.  These agreements must be signed by the appropriate University delegate. 

These agreements document arrangements for the following:
Data governance and custodianship – how will decisions be made now and in the future?
Intellectual property matters – who are the stakeholders and what are their rights and obligations?
Liabilities – if things go wrong, who accepts responsibility? For what types of issue? And to what extent?
Getting an agreement
The Research Grants & Contracts
can support you with an agreement appropriately sized to your project through the R
esearch Grants & Contracts
Team.  Please contact your

to request a data sharing or data transfer agreement, or to have the terms of an agreement sent to you by an external party reviewed and signed. This will ensure that any collaborations you have with external parties have agreements in place that are executed by the appropriate University delegate and specify ownership and custodianship rights and responsibilities for research data and primary materials.

If working with a large research partner in New Zealand, you may be covered by an existing ‘umbrella’ agreement. In either case, it is also important to understand whether there are already existing obligations with them and what these might entail.

items.title: Office of Naval Research (ONR)
items.summary: ONR funds basic research, applied research, and advanced technology development.

content.value: Founded in August, 1946, the Office of Naval Research (ONR) was originally created to maintain the partnership arrangements among government, academia and industry that had developed during World War II and produced major technological advancements. ONR is located in Arlington, VA and functions as the research arm of the US Navy and Marine Corps.

ONR funds basic research, applied research, and advanced technology development. ONR interests include mathematics, computer science, electronics, machine learning/intelligence, sensors, communications, ocean engineering and acoustics, materials research (including biomaterials), non-destructive evaluation, cognition, biometrics, computational neuroscience, decision-making, gut microbiology, microbial fuel cells, force health protection, stress physiology, aviation technology, unmanned air systems, turbine engine technology, and many more.
Funding opportunities:

Like all U.S. Department of Defense research agencies, grant proposals are submitted in response to specific Broad Agency Announcements (BAAs) issued by ONR. While some BAAs are very topic-specific, the Long Range BAA for Navy and Marine Corps Science & Technology provides details about agency interests as a whole and is updated yearly in terms of current interests, personnel, and process. In addition to BAAs, ONR also issues Requests for Proposals (RFPs) that outline government requirements to potential contractors. RFPs are used to fund very specific tasks in contrast to BAAs that outline agency needs and leave project design to the proposer.
Funding opportunities can be found on the funder's
website announcement
Additional funding mechanisms

Other DOD-wide funding opportunities in which ONR participates are the Defense University Research Instrumentation Program (DURIP) and the DOD Multidisciplinary University Research Initiative (MURI). ONR also offers a yearly Young Investigator Program.
Internal institutional registration steps
Please read the linked UOA guidance - how to go about a submission to the ONR.  If you intend to apply please contact the
Research Funding Team
here
Further information
Access the funder website via this
link
Chief of Naval Research Priorities 2022

items.title: Meta research
items.summary: Meta (Previously Facebook) calls for proposals align to specific areas of research. They offer insight to the academic community on topical research questions of interest to Meta, where academic insight is key.

content.value: Meta Research (previously Facebook Research) engages with the global academic community through a variety of awards to fund topics that align with their areas of interest.  They release requests for proposals (RFPs) to strengthen their ties to academia by discovering activities and key players in academia that are aligned with their research challenges and grow the body of knowledge. This approach allows them to dive into certain topics or areas more deeply over the course of many years, and apply the most cutting-edge technologies to enhance Meta's apps and services.

In general, there are 15 to 20 RFP opportunities each year across a variety of the areas of interest.  Invitations typically address specific research challenges that have been identified as important to their mission. They vary in nature and may solicit proposals from individual researchers addressing a well-defined problem or may require multiple university departments to collaborate with a diverse set of skills to solve a more complex multi-disciplinary challenge.
The areas of research interest are:
AR/VR • artificial intelligence
Blockchain and cryptoeconomics
Computational photography and intelligent cameras
Computer vision • data science
Databases • economics and computation
Human computer interaction and UX
Machine learning
Natural language processing and speech
Networking and connectivity
Security and privacy
Systems and infrastructure

The number of proposals and success rates vary per RfP. During 2022, the number of reviewed proposals ranged from 30-161, with success rates ranging from 4-30% for each RfP.  The University of Auckland won two awards during 2022, one for the RfP- Meta AR/VR Policy Research Request for Proposals for the Asia Pacific Region and one for the RfP- Controls That Matter and Considering Everyone: High-Realism VR Avatars in Virtual Work .

In 2021, the number of reviewed proposals ranged from 29-446, with success rates ranging from 2-17% for each RfP. The University of Auckland won two awards during 2021, one for the RfP- Agent-based user interaction simulation to find and fix integrity and privacy issues and one for the RfP- Environmental considerations for soft electronics systems and energy sources.
Applicants must be part of a current faculty of an accredited academic institution to be eligible to apply for funding.
To find the latest open RfP use
this
link.

items.summary: The Foundation is a US-based philanthropic organization whose mission is to address the most perplexing questions of humankind.

The OFI is open in August each year for each grant.The Foundation has three activity types that it will fund: research (discovery and investigation actions), public engagement (dissemination of ideas to a wider audience) and intellectual humility (civil dialogue and open-mindedness).

items.title: Spencer Foundation
items.summary: The Spencer Foundation invests in education research that cultivates learning and transforms lives.

content.value:
The Spencer Foundation invests in education research that cultivates learning and transforms lives.  They aim to improve education, making education systems more equitable, and increasing opportunities to learn across the lifespan by the development of new foundational knowledge that will have a lasting impact on policy-making, practice or educational 
discourse.

The research grants are researcher-led focussed on supporting rigorous, intellectually ambitious and technically sound research that is relevant to the most pressing questions and compelling opportunities in education. They value work that fosters creative and open-minded scholarship, engages in deep inquiry, and examines robust questions 
related to education.
Related disciplines/Areas of interest

Education-focused research projects, research training fellowships, and additional field-building initiatives that can include but not limited to relevant topics and disciplines such as anthropology, philosophy, psychology, sociology, economics, history, law, or neuroscience.
Funding opportunities:
Large grants
(two calls per year, generally Jan & July)
Small grants
(three calls per year, generally Mar, July & Nov)
Research practice partnership grants
(one call per year, generally Jan)

(one call per year, generally April-June)
Transformative Grant Programme
(Two
Vison Grant
calls per year and one or two Transformative Grant annully)
Further information

A guide to writing successful field-initiated research grant proposals

The funder has an
archive of successful grants for each scheme

The funder recently announced its

content.value: De-identification removes information to allow data to be used without the possibility of individuals being identified. Data de-identification may be used to protect the privacy of individuals and organisations, or for example, to ensure that the spatial location of minerals, archaeological findings, or endangered species are not publicly available.

items.title: Research data publishing and discovery
items.summary: Publishing research data increases the transparency and impact of your work.

content.value: Why publish research data
Publishing research data and artefacts is increasingly required by funders and journal publishers, and supports the internationally recognised
. You may also be expected to publish your research data as per the University's
Research Data Management Policy
Publishing research data directly benefits researchers by:
Increasing citations for your research outputs
Directing readers to associated publications and materials
Facilitating research collaborations
Preparing research data
Before publishing your data, and regardless of the type of data or discipline, consider:
(a summary of human-readable
metadata
) which helps others to understand your research and associated data.
Creating a machine-readable metadata file using a discipline-specific standard (if appropriate). See
for more information.
in a clear, concise, and consistent way to make it easier for others to understand the data..
Saving a version of the data files in open, universal formats (e.g. saving a spreadsheet as a .csv file rather than an Excel spreadsheet, .xlsx).
When working with data in spreadsheets (tabular data), the following
principles will make it easier for other people to ingest, manipulate, and visualise the published data in statistical programs:
Ensure each column contains one variable, each row contains one observation, and each cell contains one value.
Move separate data tables and sheets into their own spreadsheet files.
Remove highlighting, borders, notes, and other formatting.
These strategies support others to find, understand, and work with your published data.
Selecting a data repository
When you are ready to publish research data, select an appropriate research data repository:
The University-hosted
is often a great choice.
A disciplinary or community-recognised repository may be appropriate such as CERN Open Data Portal.
You may prefer a general data repository such as Zenodo.
Search
re3data
(Registry of Research Data Repositories) to find a suitable repository.
Publishing a metadata-only record

If you’re working with sensitive data, it may be more appropriate to publish a descriptive record about the data instead of the data or artefact itself. A descriptive or metadata-only record indicates the existence of a particular dataset and provides information about it, without sharing the actual data. Researchers may have legal, funder, or institutional requirements which make it necessary to broadcast the existence of a dataset without actually sharing it.
Publishing a metadata-only record supports:
Data and artefacts to be findable and accessible online, aligning with
, and;
Collective benefit, governance and the authority to control access and use of the data associated with
or

A metadata-only record can include instructions for how others may apply for access to the data. This is mediated access as it involves a social interaction before the data is provided (e.g. an email or application to a data access committee). It may also provide access to a single file to enable a potential requester to assess if the quality, format, and content of the dataset will be useful before applying for access.

items.title: Research data management overview
items.summary: An overview of Research Data Management: the planning, collection, organising, preserving, and sharing of research data throughout the research lifecycle.

content.value: What are Research Data?

Research data are the evidence that underpin the answers to research questions and 
can be used to validate findings. Research data can be in print, digital, or physical formats, and can include interviews, images, surveys, observations, audio/visual recordings, medical records, maps, instrument data, spreadsheets, bibliographies, and more.
While research data differ accross disciplines and are unique to each project, a set of general principles and best-practices can be applied to guide the management of data.
Research Data Management

Research data management (RDM) is the process of planning and undertaking the collection, organisation, management, storage, backup, preservation, and sharing of data, before, during, and after the research project.
Good research data management helps you to:
Understand the requirements, complexities, and policies which apply to your research project.
Maintain the integrity of your research process and ensure your outputs are verifiable.
Store your research data securely and publish or share it when you're ready.
Maximise the visibility and impact of your work and ensure you receive recognition for your outputs.
Research data lifecycle
The research data lifecycle separates the research process into
Plan & Design
Create & Collect
Analyse & Interpret
Publish & Report
Discover & Reuse
Each stage of the research data lifecycle requires different data management practices.
Policies and principles
Ensure you understand the requirements and expectations of funders, institutions, and participants.
The University's
Research Data Management Policy

commences from 1 July 2023 and applies to all staff, students, supervisors and other members of the University community that are involved in the management of research data. It outlines responsibilities relating to planning, storing, governing, publishing, retaining and disposing of research data appropriately.
The University's
Research Code of Conduct
Intellectual Property Policy
, and
Privacy Policy
all have implications for the way staff, students, and visitors work with research data.

items.title: Naming and organising files
items.summary: Organising and naming files and folders logically makes it easier for you to find research data files and understand their contents.

content.value: It is good practice in research data management to develop a systematic way to name and organise your key data files and folders. Filenames should be descriptive identifiers that tell you what the file contains. A clear, concise, consistent file naming and organising system will make it easier for you to find files later and understand their contents without having to open them. A structured and consistent file naming strategy will also make it possible to easily batch rename files and sort or automate parts of any future analysis.
For key files in your research project, consider using a naming schema. For example:

Schema: [investigator]-[method]-[specimen]-[YYYYMMDD].ext
Example: tmr-lcms-8886-20170912.dat

Schema: [YYYMMDD]-[type]-[subject].ext
Example: 20170403-interview-recording-cmc.mp3
Possible elements to include in a file name:
Project/grant name/number
Date of creation YYYYMMDD (this format ensures that all your files stay in chronological order)
Initials of creator
Description of content
Collection method
Version number
Other tips for file naming:
Avoid spaces. Use – (dash) or _ (underscore)
Avoid special characters (% ^ & * etc.)
Keep to standard file extensions – e.g .txt .csv
Pad numbers with appropriate leading zeros – e.g. 001, 002

Whichever schema or system you use, it should enable easy identification while skimming through many files and versions. File names should be distinguishable and unique both within and across folders. Keep in mind that very long filenames can be problematic when moving data between different systems.

Ensure you document your organising and file naming strategy in a README.txt file kept in your project folder, for your future self and any collaborators to quickly understand how the project is organised.

items.title: Encryption
items.summary: A guide to understanding how data encryption can be used to secure research data.

content.value: What is Encryption?
Encryption is used to prevent unauthorised access to files in order to keep them secure. The two most common methods to protect stored data are:
Full disk encryption: protects everything on a disk drive.
File encryption: protects only selected individual files.

Both methods rely on using strong passwords. Be aware that if you forget your password then you cannot recover the data. Encrypted files should only be worked on by one person at a time to avoid file corruption.
Encryption software
Commonly used encryption software includes:
Pretty Good Privacy can encrypt files or entire storage volumes and is widely recognised as the most commonly used encryption software. Free open source versions are available (for example
Gpg4win
for Windows).
BitLocker
is part of recent editions of Windows and can be enabled for the encryption of disk volumes and USB devices. See
this video
for how to encrypt a portable hard drive using Bitlocker.
FileVault2
comes standard on Apple Macs and can be used to encrypt an entire storage volume. See
this video
for how to encrypt a portable hard drive using FileVault2.
VeraCrypt

is free software for establishing and maintaining an on-the-fly-encrypted volume, meaning that data is automatically encrypted right before it is saved and decrypted right after it is loaded, without any user intervention. VeraCrypt can encrypt an entire storage volume, or it can create an encrypted container of a specified size on the disk. See
this video
for how to create an encrypted container.
Cryptomator

is free file encryption software that works by encrypting a folder specified as a "vault”. It encrypts folders and files directly as well as encrypting file and folder names. This makes it significantly easier to sync with cloud storage as it only syncs file by file, as opposed to synchronising a complete container or archive

items.title: Research data glossary
items.summary: Definitions of terms associated with research data that are used at the University of Auckland.

content.value: This A-Z listing provides definitions for terms associated with research data management, including those used in the
and
Definitions | Ngā whakamāramatanga kupu
Agreement,

in the context of research data sharing or transfer, refers to a formal contract that sets out the purpose of the data sharing or transfer, how the data will be managed and the rights and responsibilities of the parties.  Sometimes referred to as a
data sharing agreement
or
data transfer agreement.
See
for more information.
CARE
C
ollective benefit,
A
uthority to control,
R
esponsibility and
E
thics) refers to the CARE Principles of Indigenous Data Governance published by the
Global Indigenous Data Alliance
.  See
for more information.
Data Availability Statement,

sometimes called a data access or accessibility statement, explains where the research data associated with an article or output can be found.  It may include the conditions of access, reasons for restriction, and, where applicable, links to the data.  See
for more information.
Data classification
refers to the University’s schema for classifying different types of data, as detailed in the University’s
Data governance

refers to the arrangements put in place to ensure the interests of rightsholders and stakeholders in research data are protected and that all ethical, legal, data sovereignty and commercial constraints are adhered to throughout the research data lifecycle.  Commonly, research data governance will enable answers to questions regarding: the quality and value of the data for a particular application; who can access it and for what purpose, how this is decided and by whom; how it can be accessed, including location; and the security required and how the data are being protected. These details should be documented in a Data Management Plan.
Data Management Plan (DMP)

is a plan describing: the research data that will be collected and its data classification; the legal, ethical, data sovereignty and commercial constraints relating to research data; how the research data will be organised and managed; the research data management roles, responsibilities, governance and access arrangements; how research data will be stored, shared and returned, retained, deleted and/or destroyed (as appropriate).  See
for more information.
Deletion
means logically, but not necessarily physically, erasing research data. Deletion does not always eliminate the possibility of recovering all or part of the original research data.
Destruction
means the process of overwriting, erasing or physically destroying information so that it cannot be recovered.
Digital Object Identifier (DOI )

is a digital identifier of an object, and can be assigned to any object, whether physical or digital. DOIs serve as unique, permanent alphanumeric strings assigned to specific objects, which remain unchanged. DOIs are the most common type of identifier for digital objects, particularly for scholarly, research, and technical publications and outputs. See
for more information.
FAIR
F
indable,
A
ccessible,
I
nteroperable, and
R
eusable) refers to the FAIR guiding principles for scientific data management and stewardship.
High availability
, in the context of a Secure Research Environment (SRE), is a characteristic of a system which aims to ensure an agreed level of operational performance, usually
uptime
. For example, the delivery of clinical care requires high availability of systems to perform routine daily activities.
Indigenous data
refers to digital or digitisable information or knowledge that are about or from indigenous people, language, culture, resources, or environments.
Institutional data

refers to the administrative data generated by research activities e.g., grant or ethics applications, that are governed by the University’s Data Governance Policy.  This includes data about research grants and contracts.
Instrument Data Service Project

refers to a two-year year funded business case (2023-2024) to assist the University to address the challenges of modern instrument data storage, data access, collaboration and archiving. The project extends engagement and workflows developed with early-adopters in the Phase One Scientific Instrument Data Service and provide further automation and operationalisation of the MyTardis repository. See
for more information.
Machine-actionable
refers to the information that is consistently structured so that machines can be programmed against such a structure.
Machine actionable Data Mangement Plan (maDMP)
sometimes referred to as machine-readable DMPs, are structured so they can be read and actioned by humans and computers or programmes to enable automation and integration. See this
article
and
for more information.
Māori data
refers to digital or digitisable information or knowledge that are about or from Māori people, language, culture, resources, or environments.  See
for more information.
Māori Data Sovereignty
recognises that Māori data should be subject to Māori governance and managed in accordance with the principles of Māori Data Sovereignty published by
Te Mana Raraunga
.  See
for more information.
Master sources
, sometimes referred to as sources of truth, are those sources or systems within the University
where a particular
data element
is
mastered

(or edited) in only that place. In this context, it defines where an information element can be pushed, or pulled from or to a system to ensure data integrity e.g., the ethics system is the source of truth for the approved ethics obligations for a particular project, it should only be updated through following processes connected to that system but this information can flow from this system to be reused by other systems.
Metadata
is information about research data, such as content, quality, format, location and access rights.  See
for more information.
ORCiD
is an identifier designed specifically for the research community to disambiguate researchers. ORCiD partners with local organizations to form regional consortia. Aotearoa New Zealand’s
ORCiD Hub
was established following initial development in 2017/18 and includes more than 50 member organizations across university, government, research data management, and medical sectors. See
for more information.
Open access

is a set of principles and practices through which academic research outputs are made available publicly through online distribution, either via an open access journal, open access book, or inclusion in an institutional or disciplinary repository. See
for more information.
Ownership
has the same meaning as intellectual property right under the Intellectual Property Created by Staff and Students Policy.
Pacific data
refers to digital or digitisable information or knowledge that is about or from Pacific people, language, culture, resources, or environments. See
for more information.
Persistent Identifiers
(P
I

Ds): An identifier is any label used to name something uniquely (whether online or offline). URLs are an example of an identifier. So are serial numbers, and personal names. A persistent identifier is guaranteed to be managed and kept up to date over a defined time period. ORCiD is an example of a persistent identifier for a person, while a DOI is a persistent identifier for a research output. See
here
and
for more information.
Protective security requirements (PSR)
refers to the policy framework for protective security in Aotearoa, as detailed in the
Trusted Research Guidance for Institutions and Researchers
. See
for more information.
Primary materials
are physical objects and samples, such as biological samples, that are acquired for the purpose of research and from which research data may be derived.
RAID
R
esearch
A
ctivity
Id

entifier) is a persistent and unique identifier assigned to a research project or activity's descriptive or metadata record. Date/time stamps attached to the PIDs form a timeline of the research actions and interactions to record all the researchers, institutions, outputs, tools and services that are used in a project.
RDM capability maturity model

is a Capability Maturity Model (CMM) that details the dimensions (or ‘ingredients’) of an institutional capability and describes what those dimensions look like at different levels of maturity. The full Waipapa Taumata Rau model is available in
Figshare
RDM stocktake report and recommendations.

A report detailing the findings from a stocktake (engagement, survey and interviews) of Research Data Management (RDM) capability maturity at WaipapaTaumata Rau (the University of Auckland) with reference to a new RDM Capability Maturity Model (CMM) developed through the RDM project (2020-21).
Research data
are the evidence that underpins the answer to a research question and can be used to validate findings regardless of its form (e.g., print, digital, or physical). Research data does not include
institutional data
or
primary materials
Research data lifecycle
is a multi-phase approach to governing, organising and managing research data; starting with
planning and designing
and moving through,
creating and collecting
analysis and interpretation
publishing and reporting
, to enabling the
discovery and reuse
of research data. Activities within these phases will differ across disciplines and research methods.
Research data management
is the process of planning and undertaking the collection, organisation, management, storage, backup, preservation and sharing of data before, during and after a research project.
Research staff
means all staff members employed to undertake research as part of their employment agreement with the University.
Researcher

includes research staff, students, honorary appointees, adjunct appointees and contractors that undertake research at the University or using University resources, or otherwise on behalf of the University.
Restricted data
has the meaning set out in the University’s
Retention
means to retain research data in accordance with the University’s minimum
periods.
Return
means the return of research data to the originating community or data provider, as indicated by the original terms of access to those data and materials.
Research Organisation Registry or ROR
is a global, community-led registry of open persistent identifiers for research organisations.
Sensitive data
has the meaning set out in the University’s
Secure Research Environment
(SRE, previously referred to as a Data Safe Haven)
is a highly secure environment that enables the secure upload, storage, processing and analysis of sensitive data by approved research collaborators. Examples:
The University of Edinburgh Data Safe Haven
Swansea University Safe Haven

, or

.   See
for more information.
Student
, in the context of research data management, means any person enrolled in a degree, diploma or certificate course at the University whose enrollment includes undertaking research.
Supervisor

University community

University delegate

University-managed research storage

items.title: Research data retention
items.summary: Guidance for how long research data are required to be retained.

content.value: Research data retention
Researchers are responsible for retaining research data in accordance with the
Research Data Management Policy
and the University’s retention periods outlined below.
These are the University’s default retention periods which may be extended through ethics approval processes or contractual agreements with funders or data providers.

items.title: FAIR principles for research data
items.summary: Guidance for making research data and artefacts Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, and Reusable (FAIR).

content.value: The
FAIR
principles

(Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, and Reusable) are designed to make research data more discoverable, both by humans and machines, and to promote wider sharing and reuse of data. They can be applied to digital data and artefacts from any discipline. Working towards making research data more FAIR provides a range of benefits including:
increasing the visibility and citations of your research
improving the reproducibility and reliability of your research
enabling  new innovative research approaches and tools
aligning with international standards and approaches
FAIR research data is easier to understand and share with collaborators or with the wider world.

This webinar provides an overview of the FAIR principles: their origins, Australian FAIR initiatives, what FAIR is (and what it is not), the four findable principles which underpin the discoverability of data, and resources to support institutional awareness and uptake of findable principles to make your institutional data globally discoverable.
Watch
Read the transcript
If you would like to assess the ‘FAIRness’ of a dataset and get tips on how to enhance its FAIRness try the
ARDC FAIR tool
F
indable
To make research data findable, publish the data (or a metadata-only record) with as much as much
as possible. Most research data publishing platforms (including the University's
) provide you with a persistent identifier, such as a
digital object identifier
, which you can then use to cite or share the work.
A
ccessible

To make research data accessible, ensure it can be downloaded over the internet from the publishing platform it is hosted on. Consider using a publishing platform that supports API access to make it easier for machines and databases to harvest the research data or it's metadata.

Even when the data itself cannot be made publicly available without restrictions, such as particular types of sensitive data, it is still possible to provide clarity and transparency around the conditions governing access and reuse, if these are allowed at all.

This ARDC webinar recording includes an overview of the accessible principles which underpin access and reuse of data and the resources to support institutional awareness and uptake of accessible principles.
Watch
Read the transcript
I
nteroperable
To make research data interoperable, use community-accepted languages,
formats
and
vocabularies
in the data and metadata. Metadata should reference and describe relationships to other data, metadata and information through the use of
identifiers

This ARDC webinar recording provides an overview of the three Interoperable principles which use vocabularies for knowledge representation, standardisation and references other metadata as well as the resources to support institutional awareness and uptake of interoperable principles.
Watch
Read the transcript
R
eusable
To make research data reusable, it should come with a clear human- and machine-readable
licence
and
provenance
information on how it was collected or generated. It should also abide by discipline-specific data and metadata standards where possible, to ensure it retains important context.

This webinar includes an overview of the four reusable principles which bring together licensing, provenance and domain-relevant standards and resources to support institutional awareness and uptake of reusable principles.
Watch
Read the transcript
Working with CARE, Māori Data Sovereignty and FAIR data principles
The FAIR principles can complement the CARE and Māori Data Sovereignty principles by encouraging the consideration of both people and purpose. For more information, see this
presentation
on Māori Data Sovereignty, the Global Indigenous Alliance, and CARE principles by Maui Hudson.
