items.title: Human ethics studies affected by the COVID-19 restrictions
items.summary: Important information for adapting your study to meet COVID-19 restrictions

content.value: Refer to the University’s
COVID-19 Protection Framework Plan
(UCPFP) for up to date information about requirements for doing research under the COVID-19 Protection Framework.
Additional guidance:

Where the research plan requires participants to leave their homes or meet with researchers or other participants, participants researchers should take into account the current requirements for meeting with participants, and if necessary, participants should be given the option to withdraw their participation (provided this is safe for them to do so).

Research involving participants over 70 may need to be put on hold until the COVID-19 risks have passed. Amendment requests to extend ethics approval for this reason will be approved, and extensions may be allowed to go beyond the 6 year limit of approval if necessary.

Research in schools may also need to be reconsidered while Covid restrictions continue. Amendment requests to extend ethics approval for this reason will be approved and extensions may be allowed to go beyond the 6 year limit of approval if necessary.

Where research involves face to face interviews with participants, researchers should consider substituting on-line or phone interviews. An amendment request for this purpose, accompanied by the information to be provided to participants about this change) will be quickly approved. Provided that there is an information sheet about the project, new documents may not be required.
Please click
here
for additional information that will be required in your application when changing to Zoom or other virtual software for interviews.
Research involving focus groups may need to be reconsidered to meet government advice with respect to meeting in groups and maintaining physical distance.

Students below masters level planning research which would involve interaction with human participants (other than online or by phone) may be advised to reconsider their project in favour of something using publicly available data.
Research involving patients will need to follow guidance from the District Health Boards and the Ministry of Health.

items.title: Auckland Health Research Ethics Committee (AHREC) reviews
items.summary: Committee meetings, submission deadlines and the review process for ethics applications submitted to Auckland Health Research Ethics Committee (AHREC).

content.value: Committee meetings and submission deadlines

Applicants can request to attend a meeting to discuss their ethics application with the Committee. However, the Committee reserves the right to close the meeting at any time. Please contact the Ethics and Integrity Team to advise the committee if you wish to attend a meeting. The Committee may also request that an applicant attend.
Review process
There are two pathways for review of AHREC ethics applications: expedited review and full review.
Expedited review

A research project in which there is a low risk of physical harm, psychological harm, exploitation or other potential adverse effects will be reviewed via an expedited review process. Expedited applications will be reviewed by one Committee member and the Chair outside of the Committee meetings. The turnaround time for applications is usually about three weeks from the time of submission of the application.
Examples of low-risk studies are those that:
require access to health information only, where the person accessing the data is involved in the clinical service provision in that clinical area
involve administration of low risk procedures (e.g. interviews, questionnaires, etc.) not as part of clinical care and not involving vulnerable participants
observation only of clinical processes by members of the clinical team.
During the expedited ethical review, reviewers may recommend that the application is referred to the Committee for full review.
Full review

Any research not qualifying for an expedited review will be placed on the next AHREC agenda for review at a Committee meeting. Each application will be reviewed by two Committee members prior to the meeting, and an outcome determined after Committee discussion of the application. After each AHREC meeting the Ethics Advisers will inform PIs of the Committee decision within five working days. The turnaround time for applications is usually about four weeks from the time of submission of the application.

items.title: Post-approval reporting and amendments for AHREC
items.summary: Find guidance for requesting and obtaining approval from Auckland Health Research Ethics Committee (AHREC) for amendments to ethics protocols after approval, as well as templates for final reporting.

content.value: Amendments to ethics protocols after approval
All changes to approved AHREC applications must receive approval prior to implementing changes.
The AHREC Chair approves minor amendment requests under delegation, but any major changes to a protocol will be reviewed at the next available AHREC meeting.
A request for an amendment to an approved ethics project must be made through the online Ethics RM system. To initiate an amendment in Ethics RM, a request should be sent via
Infonetica Ethics Review Manager

from the Correspondence tab to the Ethics and Integrity Team to unlock the application (see 'Submit request for original application to be unlocked' step in Infonetica Ethics RM - Amendment request guide for more details).
The Ethics RM amendment and renewal process enables specific amendment details to be captured against each applicable application question throughout the application form.
Applicants must also provide a summary of the amendments being requested at the end of the form.
All amendment requests, including applications previously approved via email, must be processed in Ethics RM.
Please provide complete information about the amendments requested, and particularly for major amendments.

Please ensure that any new or changed documents (such as Participant Information Sheets or Consent Forms) are uploaded with tracked changes. The older versions of the same documents must be deleted in
the amendment request (a copy will still be available in the initial version of the form).
A Quick Reference Guide is available to provide guidance on how to submit an Amendment Request in Ethics RM, and also for older approved email applications. Please refer to the
Infonetica Ethics RM quick reference guides
for instructions on how to use Ethics RM.

For applications initially approved via email, applicants will only be able to make minimal changes in the Ethics RM form and must describe the requested changes in detail in the Submission section of the Ethics RM form.  See further information below.

For applications initially approved in Ethics RM, specific amendment details can be captured against each applicable application question. Applicants must also provide a summary of the amendments being requested at the end of the form.
If you have any questions about the amendment request process please contact
ahrec@auckland.ac.nz
Renewal notifications

Ethics RM will send an email notification to the Principal Investigator 90 days before an ethics approval is about to expire to remind them to submit a renewal request if the research is continuing beyond the expiry date of the ethics approval (note: one three year extension is possible).
Prepare and submit the request to extend the project for a further three years as an amendment request, following the instructions above.
Final report to AHREC
Once the study has concluded, the Principal Investigator must submit a final report to AHREC.
For applications processed as PDF files, the report must be submitted as an attachment to
ahrec@auckland.ac.nz
, with the AHREC reference number and “Final Report” in the email’s subject line.
Final reports for Ethics RM applications can be submitted by creating an amendment request and attaching the report in section K of the application form.
The report will be reviewed by the Committee via the Expedited Review process. No further action will be necessary unless the Committee wishes to discuss the report at a meeting.

items.title: University of Auckland Human Participants Ethics Committee (UAHPEC) review process
items.summary: Application review pathways, submission dates and UAHPEC meeting dates

content.value: Committee Meetings and submission deadlines
Review Process
There are two pathways for review of UAHPEC ethics applications: expedited review and full review.
Expedited Review
All applications are checked against the expedited review criteria programmed into Infonetica Ethics RM.

A research study with a low risk of physical harm, psychological harm, exploitation, or other potential adverse effects will likely be reviewed via the expedited review pathway. An application will follow the expedited review pathway if all answers on the checklist questions are 'no' (see download below).

If an application qualifies for an expedited review, it will be pre-screened and reviewed by one UAHPEC member and then the UAHPEC Chair. We aim to provide an outcome to the applicant within three weeks from the date of submission.
There are no deadlines for review of low risk (expedited) applications – these are processed for review as soon as they are received by the Ethics and Integrity team.
If the application is not deemed low risk, it will be added to the next available UAHPEC agenda for review at a Committee meeting (link to submission and meeting deadlines).

NOTE: In all cases, UAHPEC determines whether an application is low risk and qualifies for expedited review.  The Committee may decide, after review of the application, that an application initially qualifying for expedited review should be reviewed at a Committee meeting
Full Review

Any research study not qualifying for an expedited review will be placed on the next UAHPEC agenda for review at a Committee meeting. Each application will be reviewed by two Committee members prior to the meeting, and an outcome determined after Committee discussion of the application.

After each UAHPEC meeting the Ethics Advisers will inform PIs of the Committee decision within five working days. The turnaround time for applications is usually about four weeks from the time of submission of the application.

items.title: Applying to UAHPEC for human ethics approval
items.summary: Guidance on creating an UAHPEC application and obtaining sign-off.

content.value: Overview
All applications to UAHPEC must be submitted online via

A Word version (see blue button above) of the UAHPEC online form is available for students to draft their application for review by their supervisor prior to transferring the information over into the Ethics RM form.
Please proofread your application and public documents carefully and ensure that someone with an excellent grasp of English edits these, if required.

The Principal Investigator (PI)/Supervisor must submit an application and request sign-off by their Academic Head. The application will only be visible to the Ethics and Integrity Team for processing once Academic Head sign-off is completed and the PI has signed (submitted) the application.
If you require support while preparing or submitting an application in the online Ethics RM system, please contact
humanethics@auckland.ac.nz
, or submit a request for technical assistance via the
Student Services
portal or the
Staff Services
portal.
Please refer to the
Infonetica Ethics RM quick reference guides
for instructions on how to use Ethics RM, or book a space in one for the fortnightly human ethics
training sessions
where the process will be explained.
Student applications
Students (including Doctoral, Masters and Honours) can create and edit an application in Infonetica Ethics RM, but the Supervisor/Principal Investigator must submit the final application.
Note:  Doctoral and Masters students automatically have access to Ethics RM but access for Honours students must be requested by the academic supervisor for each academic course.
See the Infonetica Ethics RM Quick Reference Guide‘
Create a student application
below for details on how to create and share an application form between supervisor and student.  The guide also explains how to request Honours student access to Ethics RM.
Student applications can be created in three ways:
As far as possible, all applications will be pre-screened for compliance and other suggested improvements by the Ethics Team Ethics Advisors.

In Ethics RM, an application returned for pre-screening will not be visible to the Ethics team until it is re-submitted. The Ethics Committee expects applicants to make the requested changes in a timely manner. Prior to re-submission of a pre-screened application, the application type must be changed to “Response to pre-screen” so that the application reaches the ethics team again.

The UAHPEC will not review the application until an adequate, revised application is submitted.
Sign-off from Academic Head

At the end of the application form (Section 13), the PI/supervisor will be guided to submit the form and also to request sign-off from their Academic Head once the application is ready for submission.

Applicants are responsible for following up to ensure sign-off with their Academic Head has been completed – an application will not be visible to the Ethics and Integrity Team until the required sign-off has been completed.
A l
ist of Academic Heads (or delegates)
who will provide sign-off will be available from the sign-off page in Ethics RM.
(Any updates to this list should be sent to
humanethics@auckland.ac.nz
Automatic notifications will be sent from Ethics RM throughout the submission and review process to inform applicants of the progress with the review of their application.
If you have not received confirmation that the application has been submitted within two weeks, please contact the Ethics and Integrity Team to determine the status of the application.
Pre-screening of submitted applications

Once signed-off, the application will automatically be sent on to the Ethics and Integrity Team for pre-screening.  The application may be returned to you to respond to the pre-screening comments and resubmission for inclusion in the UAHPEC meeting Agenda.
The UAHPEC expects applicants to make these requested changes in a timely manner, and reserves a right not to review an application until an adequate, revised application is submitted.

Pre-screening is a tool in which the Ethics Team can provide feedback to the applicants prior to the Committee review. Please note, pre-screening should be considered as fine-tuning of the application and is not intended for the Ethics Team to re-write an application.
In Ethics RM, an application returned for pre-screening will not be visible to the Ethics team until it is re-submitted.

Prior to re-submission of a pre-screened application, the application type must be changed to “Response to pre-screen” (in section 13 of the application form) so that the application will reach the Ethics team again.

items.title: Before applying to Auckland Health Research Ethics Committee (AHREC)
items.summary: Preparing an Auckland Health Research Ethics Committee (AHREC) application and essential reading.

content.value: Before you begin
Determine whether your application should be submitted to a
, or
If a research study is not eligible for review by an HDEC, approval must be obtained from either AHREC or UAHPEC.

AHREC reviews human health research studies conducted by staff of the Auckland DHB and CM Health, (or other DHBs that might join AHREC), or studies by University of Auckland staff and students that fall under the definition of human health research, and that are not in scope for HDEC review.
Guidelines on what is defined as human health research are available from
Human Health Research Definition Guidelines

UAHPEC will no longer accept applications for human health research studies. In addition, UAHPEC will no longer accept applications involving the use of human tissue in the research – these applications should seek AHREC approval.
Preparing an application
The AHREC Applicants' Manual outlines information essential for preparing an ethics application and give guidance about the participant documents to include in the application.

The Guiding Principles for Conducting Research with Human Participants is intended to provide further guidance for researchers.  These guidelines are approved by the University Council every three years.
Student applications
Students (including Doctoral, Masters and Honours) can create and edit an application in Infonetica Ethics RM, but only the Supervisor/Principal Investigator must submit the final application.
Note:  PhD and Masters students automatically have access to Ethics RM but access for Honours students must be requested by the academic supervisor for each academic course.
Student applications can be created in three ways:

The academic supervisor can create the shell of the application and share the application with the student:
The academic supervisor or principal investigator (PI) can first create a ‘shell’ of the application (completing minimal details - project title and PI / supervisor name) and share the application with the student for completion, using the "Roles" button in the Action menu.
Once the student has completed the application in Ethics RM, they must then request their academic supervisor or PI to review and submit their application for Academic Head sign-off.

The student can create the application in Ethics RM, transfer ownership of the application to their academic supervisor or PI and request they share the application with them. The student can initiate and complete the application form in Ethics RM noting their academic supervisor or PI as the Principal Investigator for the application.
Once complete, the student must then transfer ownership of the application to their academic supervisor or PI and request they share the application with them. (This is necessary because a student is not 
permitted to submit an application – the academic supervisor or PI is responsible for submission).

A Word version of the AHREC application form is available (see link below) for students to complete for supervisors to provide feedback on a student’s application using Word tracked changes prior to entering the application details online. Once the Word version application is finalised, the student can copy the content into the online Ethics RM form and transfer the application to their academic supervisor or PI for submission as detailed.
As far as possible, all applications will be pre-screened for compliance and other suggested improvements by the Ethics Team Ethics Advisors.

In Ethics RM, an application returned for pre-screening will not be visible to the Ethics team until it is re-submitted. The Ethics Committee expects applicants to make the requested changes in a timely manner.

Prior to re-submission of a pre-screened application, the application type in section L of the application form must be changed to “Response to pre-screen” so that the application reaches the ethics team again.  AHREC will not review the application until an adequate, revised application is submitted.
Locality approval for studies conducted at the CM Health

The study will be processed through the CM Health locality approval process in parallel with the AHREC ethics approval process. You will need to register your study directly with CM Health for the locality approval. Auckland DHB and University of Auckland researchers will need to engage with a CM Health-based associate to represent them and access the online CM Health Research Registry on their behalf. Queries can be directed to:
researchoffice@middlemore.co.nz
Locality approval for studies conducted at the Auckland DHB
The Auckland DHB Research Review Committee will be provided locality approval for research projects recruiting staff or patients from the Auckland DHB.
Process for obtaining locality approval:

Applicants must provide the AHREC application plus all supporting documents to the Auckland DHB Research Office, ideally at the same time as the submission to AHREC is made, so that any locality specific issues may be dealt with in parallel. Locality authorisation will be granted once all issues have been resolved and AHREC approval awarded.

Applicants must contact the appropriate Auckland DHB Department(s) early in the study development process to discuss the study requirements and identify the appropriate Departmental Head so that the departmental sign-off process can be facilitated.
The Auckland DHB Research Office will organise the Research Review Committee assessment if there is a DHB budget or potential operational impact.
Departmental approval must be finally requested via the online Ethics RM system.

Please ensure that a discussion with the appropriate Departmental Head(s) is started early in the application process and that they are registered with Ethics RM to prevent delaying the sign-off process. A Quick Reference Guide outlining the registration process of a person external to the University is
available
Responsiveness to Māori review
This review should be undertaken within either the University or the DHB depending on where the PI is based.
For the Auckland DHB, these reviews will be organised by the Auckland DHB Research Office for Auckland DHB employees after the application has been submitted.
University staff and students who are unfamiliar with University’s requirements may seek advice from the Office of the Tumuaki (
R2M@auckland.ac.nz
) or access the resources provided to students to facilitate this process.
Useful resources
Te Ara Tika
– Guidelines for Māori research ethics: A framework for researchers and ethics committee members
Te Mata Ira
– Guidelines for Genomic Research with Māori
He Tangata Kei Tua
– Guide for Biobanking with Māori
Achieving health equity in Aotearoa: strengthening responsiveness to Māori in health research
Kia Tika, Kia Pono - Honouring Truths

- Centering the voices and priorities of rangatahi with care experience, 'Kia Tkia, Kia Pono' is intended for use by organisations and others working across the range of sectors and services that seek to engage tamariki and rangatahi

items.title: Guidelines for research projects on COVID-19
items.summary: Before starting to work with any type of Coronavirus you must read this first, then obtain prior approval from the University Biological Safety Committee.

content.value: Researchers wanting to work with SARS-CoV-2 virus or related material should be aware of the
University policy regarding Higher risk microorganisms (HRMOs)

Before starting to work with any type of Coronavirus you must obtain prior approval from the University Biological Safety Committee (UABSC). We understand the urgency of this research and the UABSC is therefore implementing a fast-track approval process. Please find below a quick reference guide on how to get approval.

items.title: Apply to develop low risk GMOs in containment
items.summary: Procedure for making an application to the UABSC to develop low risk GMOs. Prior UABSC approval is required before any low risk GMO development can be undertaken.

content.value: Application process overview
Prior UABSC approval is required before any GMO development can be undertaken.
The University holds a low risk HSNO approval (

) to develop a wide range of low risk GMOs in containment and the UABSC oversees the management of this approval. Researchers can submit an application to the UABSC to become an Approved User of the University Wide Low Risk HSNO approval for their individual projects.
NOTE:
Any University of Auckland researcher who wishes to develop low risk GMOs must first submit an application to become an Approved User of the University Wide Low Risk HSNO approval.
Approved User status will be granted for a period of up to three years at which point Principal Investigators must apply for renewal.

It is important that prospective users of this approval ensure that any GMOs developed fall within the boundaries of this approval i.e. that the GMOs to be developed meet the definition of low risk approvals as laid out in the HSNO (Low Risk 
Genetic Modification) Regulations 2003 and that the work will be undertaken in the appropriate containment laboratory which is part of a MPI approved Containment Facility.

Researchers who are unsure if their work falls within the scope of the University Wide Low Risk HSNO approval 
should in the first instance contact the
Biological Safety Officer
How to apply to become an Approved User of the University wide HSNO approval (APP202708)
Create a new UoA Biological Safety Application - “
Application to become an Approved User of the University Wide HSNO approval (APP202708)”
using
, following the steps in the
Ethics RM -Creating an application guide
Submit the application following the steps in the Infonetica Ethics RM –
Submitting an Application – no sign-off (Biological Safety Committee applications only)
guide.
Note that only the Principal Investigator can submit the application as they will be required to agree to the terms and conditions of the application in the process of submission.
Note that only one Principal Investigator can submit the application. Other PIs with similar projects and GMOs can duplicate an approval and amend project details as applicable for their approvals.
The application must be submitted at least 10 working days before the next
UABSC scheduled meeting

Approved Users will be sent a letter outlining the boundaries of their approval within the University Wide Low Risk HSNO approval. It is the PI’s responsibility to ensure that all low risk GMO development falls within the scope of their specific approval.
Committee requests for further information

During the assessment of the application, the Committee may decide that it needs further information prior to coming to a final decision. You will be notified of what further information the Committee would like added to the application. Please be aware that the application is formally stalled once the request for information is sent.
After you have amended the application form, re-submit the form for review. Only major revisions will require full Committee re-review.

items.title: Glossary of Biological Safety Committee Terms
items.summary: Definitions and explanations of key terms used in managing biological safety.

content.value: Approved User
A principal investigator who has obtained approval from the UABSC to use the University Wide Low Risk HSNO approval for the development of low risk GMOs.
Approved user status will expire after three years unless renewed.
Category A experiments
These experiments are the lowest risk category and are defined as:
Genetic modifications using cell lines and microorganisms that are unable to cause disease and in which the nucleic acid insert will not impart any hazardous properties to the construct.
These experiments can be safely contained within laboratories meeting PC1 containment standards
Category B experiments
These experiments are of moderate risk and include
Experiments with approved host/vector systems where the insert may be expressed as a hazardous protein

Experiments using microorganisms or cell lines as hosts which are unlikely to be a serious hazard to laboratory personnel, the community or the environment and in which the insert is well characterised.
Developments involving whole animals or plants
These experiments can be safely contained under PC2 containment standards.
High risk GMOs

Higher risk GMOs are defined as any development of organisms that do not meet the requirements of Low Risk Genetic Modification as defined in the HSNO (Low Risk Genetic Modification) Regulations, 2003.
Examples include:
Genetic modification using viral vectors where the inserted DNA encodes proteins known to be involved in uncontrolled cell growth
Genetic modification with genes encoding highly toxic proteins
Genetic modification of pathogenic hosts that cause serious human, animal or plant disease.
Higher risk microorganisms
These are defined as (for the purposes of UABSC policy):
Risk Group 2, 3 and 4 micro-organisms (whether Genetically Modified Organisms (GMOs) or unmodified micro-organisms) as defined by the
Australian/New Zealand Standard “2243-3:2010 Safety in laboratories Part 3: Microbiological safety and containment”
and/or
the United States National Institute of Health “
Guidelines for Research Involving Recombinant DNA Molecules
Any microorganism that displays resistance to antibiotics and/or treatments used to clinically treat the microorganism in question.
Low risk GMOs
These are defined as Category A or Category B development in the HSNO (Low Risk Genetic Modification) Regulations, 2003.
Risk Group 1 microorganism (low individual and community risk)
A microorganism that is unlikely to cause human or animal disease.
Risk Group 2 microorganism (moderate individual risk, limited community risk)

A  microorganism that is unlikely to be a significant risk to laboratory workers, the community, livestock, or the environment; laboratory exposures may cause infections, but effective treatment and preventive measures are available, and the risk of spread is limited.
Risk Group 3 microorganism (high individual risk, limited to moderate community risk)

A microorganism that usually causes serious human or animal disease and may present a significant risk to laboratory workers. It could present a limited to moderate risk if spread in the community or the environment, but there are usually effective preventive measures or treatments available.
University Wide Low Risk HSNO approval
An HSNO approval (
) held by the university that covers the development of a wide range of low risk GMOs.

items.title: The narrative CV
items.summary: Learn about the purpose of narrative CVs, international moves to use them, and templates and exemplars for University of Auckland researchers.

content.value: What is a narrative CV?

Broadly speaking, the narrative CV allows a researcher to better represent their various contributions to research. Standard academic CVs and publication-focused metrics do not always capture this diversity of impact, engagement and/or contribution. A narrative CV provides a structured written description of a researcher's contributions and achievements that reflects a broad range of relevant skills, experiences, and competencies.

The narrative CV provides space to detail a researcher's contribution to transdisciplinary research, to broader societal engagement and knowledge exchange, to the generation and dissemination of knowledge, and to the development of research and technology impact, for example.

There is a global shift towards the use of the narrative CV. This form of CV showcases the wide range of a researcher's experiences and skills, and provides a more rounded picture of their career, achievements and contribution to research. Importantly, it is a flexible CV and can be used to suit an individual researcher and their project proposal.
Declaration on Research Assessment (DORA)
DORA
recognises the need to improve the ways in which the outputs of scholarly research are evaluated. The
declaration

was developed in the USA in 2012 and has become a worldwide initiative covering all scholarly disciplines and all key stakeholders including funders, publishers, professional societies, institutions, and researchers. DORA’s vision is to advance practical and robust approaches to research assessment globally and across all scholarly disciplines, and individuals and organisations are encouraged to sign the
declaration
Coalition for Advancing Research Assessment (CoARA)

CoARA was established in Europe in late 2022 but is global in scope. Over 500 organisations consisting of public and private research funders, universities, research centres, institutes and infrastructures, associations and alliances thereof, national and regional authorities, accreditation and evaluation agencies, learned societies and associations of researchers, have signed the
Agreement on Reforming Research Assessment

. This agreement sets a shared direction for changes in assessment practices for research, researchers and research performing organisations, with the overarching goal to maximise the quality and impact of research.
European Research Council (ERC)

The European Research Council (ERC) is one example of the move to the narrative CV. It will become a requirement for the 2024 project evaluation process. Scientific excellence remains paramount but the changes acknowledge, “the human aspect of being a researcher,” said Luke Drury, vice-president of ALLEA, the European Federation of Academies of Sciences and Humanities. “This is an important development and is expected to contribute to improving equity, inclusion, and diversity in the research community.”
Ministry of Business, Innovation and Employment (MBIE)

In Aotearoa New Zealand, MBIE developed a narrative CV in early 2023 for the Endeavour Fund. While it is not currently being universally used, its usage is increasing, and University of Auckland researchers can use this template for their applications to other University of Auckland funds or awards applications when/if required.
Examples and templates
The MBIE narrative CV template and four exemplars are attached here.
The Royal Society has created a
Résumé for Researchers
to support the evaluation of individuals’ varied contributions to research. Click the link above to read more about this tool and download a template.
The University of Glasgow has created a short (25 min)
online course

to support researchers making a narrative CV format application, and in particular for early-career researchers using the abovementioned Resume for Researchers. (Creative Commons credit: Lab for Academic Culture at the University of Glasgow.)

items.title: How to use ResearchHub
items.summary: Find introductory videos as well as tips and tricks for new and exisiting ResearchHub users on how navigate and search the ResearchHub.

content.value: Introduction

The ResearchHub aims to lower barriers to disseminating and connecting information to increase the discoverability of research support services, events, development opportunities, infrastructure, specialist software, research policies, project management procedures, funding opportunities, and more.
To learn more see the 'About the ResearchHub' page
Getting started
Whether you're a first-time visitor or a seasoned user, this section will walk you through the essentials, from navigating our diverse options to discovering the numerous features and how to sign in.
How best to navigate ResearchHub
ResearchHub navigation is multifaceted providing multiple options for navigation, allowing users to explore different aspects or areas of content based on their preferences and needs.
Tips & tricks
How to get access to content behind SSO
Troubleshooting
Can't find the information you need? Or was it hard to find?
If this is the case please raise a request via the
ResearchHub request form

In your request please provide the following;
The keywords you use in the search engine

Screenshot of the search results

items.title: Choosing indicators of impact
items.summary: Meaningful impact indicators are essential to determine if the intended impacts have occurred.

content.value: Impact indicators can help you determine whether your intended impacts have occurred. These indicators can be as varied as the impacts, and so selecting meaningful indicators is a vital step in evidencing your research impact.

There are templates and frameworks available that can assist you in identifying impact indicators. When deciding on impact indicators for reporting, it can be useful to involve relevant stakeholders, including funders, collaborators, and beneficiaries of the research. Engaging these stakeholders early can ensure that their perspectives and expectations are considered, enhancing the relevance and credibility of the chosen indicators. This process can have multiple benefits, including fostering collaborative relationships and increasing the likelihood of meaningful knowledge exchange.
What is the purpose of impact indicators?
The purpose of impact indicators may vary depending on the context and intended audience.
For example:
Funders often require researchers to demonstrate the societal or economic benefits of their work, highlighting the value generated from the investment.

Stakeholders, such as policymakers, industry professionals, and community members, may be interested in indicators that demonstrate practical applications, policy implications, or improvements in specific areas.
What type of indicators should I choose?

It is important to strike a balance between qualitative and quantitative indicators. While quantitative data can provide valuable insights, qualitative information can capture the nuances and context-specific aspects of impact.
Evidence for qualitative indicators can include case studies, testimonials, expert opinions, or narratives illustrating how the research has influenced decision-making, practice, or public awareness.
Key questions to consider when choosing impact indicators
What impact(s) have I planned for, and what benefits do my stakeholders want to see?
What will success look like? How will I know if my research has had an impact?
What evidence of that success might I be able to collect?
Resource:
https://storiesforimpact.com/toolbox/impact-indicators-list/

items.title: Planning for impact
items.summary: How to plan your potential impact and carry out a stakeholder analysis

content.value: In this article, you will find the steps you can take to plan for research impact, including mapping your stakeholders. It is best to start this process early in your research project, though you may find it useful to revisit your plan throughout your project. To learn more about planning for research impact, check out the
How to plan for research impact
This 5-step process can help you to plan your research impact pathway.
Step 1: Identify the research need
What problem, issue, or gap does your research address?
What is the magnitude of this issue, where is it felt, and by whom?
Step 2: Define your (potential) impact
Be specific and realistic about the impacts that might be able to occur!
What are the indicators that your research has made a difference?
Step 3: Map your stakeholders
Consider who might be interested in your research and why.
Prioritise stakeholders according to their interest in the issue, their alignment to your approach, and their ability to influence change.
Step 4: Develop an engagement strategy
Determine engagement activities for each stakeholder or group of stakeholders
Articulate the aim and output of each activity
Step 5: Piece together your implementation plan
Create a plan with budget, responsibilities and deadlines.
Mapping your stakeholders
Who are the stakeholders for your research? Mapping your stakeholders is essential for ensuring that you know who and how to engage with them. Try to determine the following:
Who has an interest in your research?
Who will you engage with first? The
Influence-Interest Matrix
can help you determine which stakeholders to prioritise engaging with.

Are there any potential conflicts or alliances between the stakeholders and how will you work around them? Also, consider if anyone will be negatively impacted by your research and how you will mitigate those impacts.

items.title: Specialist support for impactful research
items.summary: Access a support network of specialist staff for research impact related training, guidance, and events.

content.value: If you are designing a research project, or developing a research grant application, you will likely need a clear view of what the potential research impact might be and how this might be achieved. You may also need support in identifying and engaging non-academic research partners, including industry, policymakers, non-government organisations, iwi, and community groups.
You can contact specialists who can help you in different areas related to research impact. See below for a list of contacts for advice or support in each area.
Who to contact

items.title: Communicating your research
items.summary: Effectively communicating your research findings and knowledge, including to those outside of your field, is key in a pathway to impact.

content.value: As a University, we embrace our role as critic and conscience of society and understand the importance of making our research accessible to those beyond our immediate academic sphere. The
University's Research Impact and Engagement Framework
values whai mātauranga (seeking, creating, disseminating, and celebrating knowledge).
Openly sharing and
communicating your research
has a number of benefits, including:
Keeping your research community informed about your research
Opening up your research for collaboration
Growing awareness and support for your research
Enhancing your research reputation
Supporting the public to make informed decisions
Informing the communities your research will be affecting about your research

Communicating your research in an equitable and accessible manner can increase the potential impact your research has. Try different forms of communication and find one that suits your stakeholders and your own style. If there are situations where you are less confident, talk to collaborators or others in your team who may be able to assist.
When communicating your research, try to avoid assuming that there is a lack of knowledge within a group or community, and tailor your message to suit your audience and their interests.

If you form reciprocal relationships, you can engage with your stakeholders and achieve a flow of knowledge in both directions, growing your potential impact and increasing the odds of your research meeting the needs of your stakeholders. The impact of communicating your research goes further than just explaining it  — you can build bridges between your research and the public to create a mutual engagement.
Further resources
Science communication laundromat
- a set of tools to help you build your research communication skills
This project has ‘spun out’ of PhD research by Jo Bailey.
Find out more
The research was funded and supported by Centre of Research Excellence
Te Pūnaha Matatini
Free online science communication course
- Te Herenga Waka offers a 10-hour online course to help you develop your research communication skills
Public Health Communication Centre
(PHCC) - if your research crosses with public health or social determinants of health, consider writing a
Briefing
for the PHCC to gain a wider audience and potential media coverage of your work.
Read more about working with the PHCC in this
information for researchers

items.title: Crafting an impact narrative
items.summary: Build a robust impact narrative using meaningful indicators and evidence.

content.value: Impact narratives and narrative CVs are ways of highlighting your progress towards and achievement of impact, including the activities that contributed to the impact and your role in these activities. These narratives put your efforts into context and can be a useful way of describing your impact.
The
Researcher Impact Framework
by Giovanna Lima and Sarah Bowman (
http://www.tara.tcd.ie/handle/2262/98474
) is an excellent resource to help you craft your impact narrative. However, please note that as this is an overseas resource, it does not have our unique Aotearoa lens.
A project is underway to develop a bespoke tool that will more accurately reflect the activities and impact of our researchers; more details on this will be available soon.
Best practice examples of impact evidence

items.title: Community engagement
items.summary: Connecting with your community means gaining a more cohesive view of what they may or may not need and where your research can be useful.

content.value: Community engagement

is the interaction you have with the community with an interest in your research, or with your own research community. Depending on who your community stakeholders are, you may want to engage with community leaders, iwi or hapū. This can develop into mutually beneficial relationships between researchers and the community, where an active sharing of knowledge can take place.
Aligning with the value of Whanaungatanga in the
University's Research Impact Framework

, we are encouraged to establish community ties to understand what are the community's needs. If you engage early and widely with communities, you can increase the likelihood of your research having an impact.
Planning your community engagement:
Survey the community for feedback on projects or suggestions
Host workshops and interactive seminars to build a relationship with them and establish an open space for communication
Establish a shared language — avoid jargon to keep your audience engaged
Assess what research findings and knowledge you are presenting to the group
Evaluate what the community’s existing knowledge is around the topic of interest prior to establishing a plan for engagement
Consult local community leaders to establish how best to communicate and interact with the target audience
Taumata Teitei and Vision Mātauranga
The University has made a commitment within
Taumata Teitei

to value and protect mātauranga Māori and honour Te Tiriti o Waitangi. This means valuing mātauranga Māori alongside other knowledge systems as well as carrying out research that strives for equitable outcomes for all of Aotearoa, including tangata whenua and Pacific communities.
Vision Mātauranga
Vision Mātauranga
is policy that advocates for Māori involvement within research as well as research that is relevant and impactful on Māori within Aotearoa.
The main objectives of Vision Mātauranga is economic development, environmental sustainability, and health and social wellbeing. By
engaging with Māori

, researchers can embed Vision Mātauranga throughout their research process and therefore, find out what research questions need to be answered and what the benefits will be to Maori in Aotearoa New Zealand.
For more resources and tools to build knowledge in the area of Vision Mātauranga, visit
Examples of community engagement

items.title: What is capturing and evidencing impact?
items.summary: Learn more about the benefits of capturing and evidencing your impact.

content.value: Capturing and evidencing

your impact refers to the process of creating a record of information (such as data, quotes, reports, and other evidence) that can demonstrate the achievement of, and progress towards, outcomes and impacts. By having a plan for capturing impact, you can evaluate the robustness of your impact plan and create a well-evidenced narrative of your research impact. Impact narratives can support your track record of impactful research and be used to report on the impact of your research to your stakeholders.
How can a plan for capturing and evidencing impact help?

The impact of your research can take years to occur. Although it is not impossible to search retrospectively for impact evidence, it is much easier to proactively collect evidence as it emerges, including actively seeking testimonials from the beneficiaries of your research. This will allow you to include a wider range of evidence to support a convincing impact narrative.
Benefits of capturing and evidencing impact

Evaluation and learning: By capturing the impact of your research, you can evaluate the effectiveness of your research and assess the extent to which your intended outcomes and impacts have been achieved. It allows you to reflect on the strengths of your approach and identify areas for improvement.

Accountability and transparency: Capturing and evidencing impact enhances the transparency and accountability of your research, enabling you to provide tangible evidence of the value and societal relevance of your work, both to funders and other stakeholders. Demonstrating impact can also strengthen public trust and support for research more widely.

Track record and recognition: A well-evidenced narrative of your research impact is valuable for building a strong track record, both for yourself and your wider research team. It provides a robust account of the outcomes and impacts generated by your research, which can be used to showcase the contributions and societal benefits arising from your work, support grant applications, meet promotion criteria, and lead to other opportunities.

items.title: Industry engagement
items.summary: Engaging with industry means forming mutually beneficial collaborations to address a research need

content.value: Involving industry in your research process can bring about a number of mutual benefits, including:
An enhanced profile of the research
Access to a broader range of funding opportunities
Opportunities for research students to gain new skills
Reciprocal access to technology and expertise
Finding industry collaborators:
Professional networking:
most easily done through meeting industry representatives at conferences, workshops, and other networking opportunities.
Request for Proposals (RFP):
often companies will issue RFP’s and a proposal can be written in response, including what you are planning to achieve while in collaboration.
Social Media:
use these platforms to find companies or individuals interested in similar projects and reach out to them.
This article
provides some useful guidance on how to initiate a relationship with a potential industry partner. It includes:
Finding out about any previous, current, or planned partnerships within and beyond your department/network
Being clear about what you are seeking from the partnership and what you have to offer

Analysing where the company's priorities are by reviewing annual reports and investments to ensure your objectives line up with one another. Carrying this out prior to collaboration ensures maximum potential for a successful partnership.
Industry engagement support
The team of Directors and Business Development Managers (BDM) at UniServices bring experience, expertise and insights to:
manage relations with external investors and funders to identify current and future research needs
communicate and promote the University's research relevance and impact
build new connections and activate existing networks to connect to key industry partners and government funders
provide advice on various pathways for UoA research and service offerings to deliver impact
identify and quality potential clients to secure new sources of funding
shape the value proposition to the funder
bring together the best teams to deliver tailored solutions
develop appropriate engagement frameworks to ultimately secure new research funding
share business intelligence via regular 'Insights Newsletter'
Furthermore, the
Newmarket Innovation Precinct (NIP)

facilitates and helps to manage ongoing engagement with industry through a University-based colocation community, allowing researchers to work ‘shoulder to shoulder’ with industry. Close proximity can create stronger working relationships, generating new opportunities for you and your industry partners.

items.title: Public engagement
items.summary: Creating impact through the establishment of a well-informed, knowledgeable society

content.value: Engaging with the public is a useful way to overcome misinformation and misconceptions members of the public may have around a particular area of research. This includes not only knowledge dissemination but also actively involving stakeholders in your research process.
Public engagement has many forms and can take place on a variety of platforms:
Engaging with news and media through
press releases
, articles on blogs, radio, or
podcasts
Engaging with non-specialist audiences including
engaging the public as researchers
or through
focus groups
The Royal Society established
public engagement guidelines

for researchers and scholars which are based on three principles: society benefits from being engaged and informed, different contexts bring different obligations, and that professionalism and transparency
nurture trust in science.
Social media: a tool for public engagement

Social media has become increasingly valuable as a tool for knowledge dissemination, involving the public in your research, and communicating with directly with the public.  Utilising social platforms can be specifically helpful for the following:
Bridging the gap
: eliminating the gap between academic findings and society’s general knowledge
Instant and increased reach
: a much larger audience can be reached instantly through social media in comparison to audiences at face-to-face events or through publications
Raising awareness and promotion
: posting and sharing content about current projects may increase awareness around the research project and gives anyone seeing the content, an opportunity to reach out to collaborate
Developing conversation
: social platforms extend to individuals all over the world therefore providing the opportunity for international input into discussions and conversations around your research

items.title: Policy engagement
items.summary: Interacting with those who can influence policy may help further your impact beyond your research field and into the wider world.

content.value: Policy engagement

can be described as the interaction between researchers and the policy community. This community may include politicians, civil servants, and other stakeholders responsible for shaping the policy process.
You can find policy engagement to be helpful for the following:
Advocating or providing support for proposed policy
Highlighting an unaddressed need in the community for policymakers to focus on
Influencing the direction of policy
Securing funding from government agencies and other funders for research
Investigating whether governmental, corporate, or actions elsewhere is harming public safety or against public interest

items.title: ORCID
items.summary: Learn how to create, connect to, and maximise the benefits of your ORCID record.

content.value: An ORCID iD is a persistent identifier (a unique 16-digit number) that distinguishes you from every other researcher. It facilitates connections across all your research and professional activities. Globally recognised, and with researchers, publishers, funders, and academic societies increasingly integrating ORCID iDs into their workflows, the University encourages all members of our research community to have one.
Benefits of ORCID
Uniquely identifies you, avoiding mistaken identity.
Reliably connects to your research outputs, awards and organisational affiliations, etc.
Provides continuity across your research career - you own and control your ORCID iD, enabling it to move with you, across institutions and name changes.
Saves you time, reduces repetitive data entry and facilitates automatic updates.
Increases discoverability, providing a persistent online profile.
Create and Connect your ORCID record
By creating an ORCID iD and connecting it with the
NZ ORCID Hub

, you can grant permission to the University to use the system to authoritatively assert your relationship and read/write information (e.g., employment and education) directly to your ORCID record. You still own and control your ORCID record but enabling the University to be the source of the information, can save time and increase trust.
Please see the
NZ Orcid Sign Up Guide
for help on how to create and/or connect your ORCID record.
Maintain your ORCID record
Information that can be updated on your ORCID record includes:
Preferred name and title
Affiliation and qualifications
Research outputs
Privacy and Access
For more information on building your ORCID record and connecting your iD see the
ORCID website
Using your ORCID iD

items.title: Early Career Research Excellence Award winners and examples
items.summary: Recognising and promoting excellence and research leadership potential among emerging researchers at Waipapa Taumata Rau | University of Auckland.

content.value: Early Career Research Excellence Award winners
The
Early Career Research Excellence Awards (ECREA)

recognise and reward research excellence and leadership potential among early career researchers at the University of Auckland. The award aims to enable early career researchers to further their current research, establish stronger links with researchers in other parts of the world or embark on new fields of research. This is a University Research Committee (UARC) award. Six awards are available annually. The winners were celebrated at Te Taumata Rangahau | Celebrating Research Excellence event.
In the sections below, you can view the videos of the
2023 Early Career Research Excellence Award winners
discussing their research.
In the sections below, you can view the videos of the
2022 Early Career Research Excellence Award winners
discussing their research.

items.title: The Responsibilities of the Principal Investigator and the ethical framework at the University of Auckland
items.summary: As a Principal Investigator you are responsible for the compliance of all personnel on the approval and the reporting of animals, adverse events, and adherence to any Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs).

content.value: Compliance

The PI is primarily responsible for all work undertaken under approval of the AEC. Prior to the submission of an application, the PI must have completed the New PI training module as specified by the AEC.

In addition, all other members of a research team must attend the Module 1 - Legislation training module as specified by the AEC to ensure that they understand their legislative and institutional responsibilities.
Non-compliance

Compliance issues will be dealt with in the first instance by the AWO, who will report on the issue at the next AEC meeting. If an incident is considered to involve a serious compromise of animal welfare or breach of conditions, the AWO will report the incident to the Chair as soon as possible. Response options may include one or more of the following: requiring an amendment to an approval, temporary restrictions imposed, additional education and/or retraining, a temporary cessation of specific activities, or permanent withdrawal of approval. This is done by the AWO, Chair or delegate of the Chair.
End of Approval Reports

PIs shall submit an End of Approval Report (EOA) at the end of the 3-year approval, or at the end of any extension(s) granted. The EOA must be submitted within 3 months of the end of the project using a report in Ethics RM and will be reviewed and accepted at a subsequent AEC meeting.
Applicants will be issued with an approval letter if the report is satisfactory, or if required to make amendments to the report for re-review by the Chair.
End of approval grading

After reviewing the grading of the manipulations as reported in the EOA and those proposed in the approved application, the Animal Ethics Administrator will report any discrepancy to the AEC for discussion at the next meeting.
End of approval statistics

Submitted Animal Usage Reports are added to the AEC annual statistics report to MPI. The AEC will receive the animal use statistics for approval at the next AEC meeting as part of the end of approval report.
Animal usage return
An Animal Usage Return must be submitted at the following times:
i. When the maximum approved number of animals has been used;
ii. When the approval has been revoked by the AEC or terminated by the Principle Investigator.
iii. At the end of the original 3-year approval period;
iv. Again, for any subsequent calendar year into which the approval was extended;
Reports need to be prepared in Ethics RM and submitted by the end of January of the following year.
Sick and injured animals

Applicants must treat animals in their control with due care and consideration for their welfare and use animals in such a way as to cause them minimal stress and suffering. Sick or injured animals must be attended to immediately, including obtaining veterinary advice and/or care. The AEC can direct that sick or injured animals be properly cared for, and if appropriate, euthanised.
Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs)

The application process for approval of an SOP is the same as for research, testing and teaching applications. The approval process for a University Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) is also available on the ResearchHub.

SOPs must be reviewed at regular intervals by the owner of the SOP in consultation with the AWO to ensure that all policies and procedures are up to date. SOPs should be reviewed at least yearly and revised every three years, with an updated version submitted in Ethics RM for AEC review and inclusion in the SOP database.
Animal facility SOPs

An internal audit against all animal facility SOPs must be completed and reported annually to the AEC as part of the submission of required facility reports. Minor adjustments to a facility SOP can be reported in this audit. However, any major modification to an SOP will require prior AEC approval following the same process as submitting an amendment to an application.
Non-facility SOPs
Project SOPs associated with research or teaching should be reviewed at minimum every 3 years at the time of reapplication.
Modification to an SOP will require prior AEC approval following the same process as submitting an amendment to an application.
Adverse events

If any unexpected events occur before, during or after manipulations that affects animal welfare, it needs to be reported as soon as possible. Urgent welfare concerns must be acted upon immediately by contacting a team leader or unit manager. Expected Adverse Events are to be detailed in the animal ethics application.
Sick or injured animals

Sick or injured animals must be attended to immediately, including reporting to the facility manager and obtaining veterinary advice and/or care. The AEC can direct that sick or injured animals be properly cared for, and if appropriate, euthanised.

All deaths (animals found dead or euthanised) occurring prior to the planned end of an experiment, must be notified to the AWO (in order for a post-mortem examination to be conducted). Any welfare incident involving sick or injured animals or unexpected adverse event(s) will be reported to the next AEC meeting as part of the AWO monthly report.
Grading

The AEC determines whether the proposed impact grading listed in each application is correct based on the information published by MPI in the Animal Use Statistics report, and also based on the expertise and knowledge of the Committee and the details of the specific application.
Euthanasia for tissue collection/dissection

Euthanasia for the purposes of tissue collection or dissection requires an AEC application to be submitted to and approved by the AEC. Surplus tissues not being used by the particular research group may be made available to other research groups or used for teaching purposes.

items.title: Why and when an animal ethics approval is needed
items.summary: Information around the reasons why animal ethics approval is needed and if your project requires an AEC approval.

content.value: Why do I need Animal Ethics Committee approval?
The Animal Welfare Act 1999

The welfare of animals in New Zealand is covered by the Animal Welfare Act 1999. Part 6 of the Act covers the use of animals for Research, Testing and Teaching (RTT). This part acknowledges that compromised care and pain or distress to animals in some cases may result in significant benefits to people, other animals or the environment. However, the use of animals in RTT involves legislative obligations and responsibilities. One of the provisions of the Act is that any manipulation of a live animal for RTT is prohibited unless it has been approved by an Animal Ethics Committee (AEC).
All staff and students at the University of Auckland must have approval from the University of Auckland Animal Ethics Committee prior to starting research, testing or teaching involving animals.
The use of animals in RTT will only be approved if the AEC is satisfied that the conditions specified in the
Code of Ethical Conduct
and
Section 100
of the Act are met.
University policies and procedures
The University regards the use of animals as a justifiable and important part of current teaching and research programmes, provided alternatives are used whenever and wherever possible.
The Act requires the University to have a
Code of Ethical Conduct
The Code of Ethical Conduct is approved by the
Ministry for Primary Industries (MPI)
, and enables the University to establish an Animal Ethics Committee (AEC) to consider applications involving the use of animals for research, testing and teaching.
In conjunction with the Code of Ethical Conduct, the procedures to be followed by the AEC are specified in the
AEC Process Document
When is approval needed?
Approval from the AEC must be sought:
for any manipulation of any animal for the purpose of research, teaching or testing*
for the killing of an animal in order to undertake research or teaching on a dead animal or their tissues
for using animals in fieldwork, if the use of animals extends beyond simple observation
If animal work is undertaken in collaboration with other institutions, please contact the
Animal Ethics Administrator

to discuss which AEC should consider your application and what additional procedures may need to be followed.

Before applying, first determine whether AEC approval is required with help of the
flowchart.
If you are still not sure if AEC approval is required, please contact the Animal Ethics Administrator
*For the definition of ‘Manipulation’, ‘Animal’, ‘Research, testing and teaching’, please see the ‘Interpretation’ section on page 10-17 of the Animal Welfare Act 1999.

items.title: Outcomes and conditions for animal ethics applications
items.summary: Projects will only be approved if they are justifiable as per the Code of Ethical Conduct. The committee's decision will typically be sent within two weeks of the meeting at which the application was considered.

content.value: Meeting outcome

After the Animal Ethics Committee (AEC) meeting, the decision of the committee will be sent to you by email. Usually, the outcome is sent within two weeks (10 working days), but depending on circumstances, this may take a couple of working days longer. The outcome of the committee’s consideration generally falls in the following three categories:
Approved

- The application is approved, but minor administrative changes may be required. If any minor changes are required, a request for these changes will be forwarded to the applicant. Once the changes made are satisfactory, or if no changes were required, the status of the application will be changed to "Approved", and the Animal Ethics Administrator will send a letter of approval to the applicant in which any conditions of the approval are stated.
Conditionally approved

- The AEC has several concerns or questions that requires a clarification from you. You will need to address the AEC’s questions, amend the application accordingly, and resubmit the application. The main reviewer will review the revised application and is allowed to give approval, as appropriate (i.e. the review of the revised application does not need to wait until the next AEC meeting).
Not approved

- The AEC has major concerns and cannot approve the application in the submitted form. You will need to make major changes to the application and/or experimental design and resubmit it (before the closing date) for reconsideration by the whole committee at the next meeting.
Declined
- the application is declined. The outcome letter may be sent electronically and/or the Chair may choose to visit the applicant to clarify the AEC’s decision.
Approval

Only after all concerns and questions from the AEC and/or reviewer have been addressed satisfactorily, and the AEC is confident that the project is justifiable, as per the Code of Ethical Conduct, will it be approved. To process the application for approval, all required documentation needs to be complete.

Only after final approval has been granted can the project commence. During your project, you have to remain aware of the limitations and conditions of the approval. IDAOs need to be signed off by all personnel on the application, and the Animal Welfare Officer, before any drugs used in the management of animals begins.
Reporting
The PI is required to submit Animal Usage Returns and an End of Approval Report within 3 months of the project finishing; see
Animal Ethics Reporting
for more information.
Additional approvals or permits

Animal Ethics approval may be subject to co-existing additional approvals or permits. For example, when working with wild animals you may require DOC permits and when working with transgenic animals or pathogenic microorganisms you may require approval from The University of Auckland Biological Safety Committee (UABSC).

When working with potentially hazardous materials including transgenic animals, pathogenic microorganisms, radionuclides or irradiating equipment, teratogenic, mutagenic or cytotoxic chemicals, please discuss the requirement for approval from the UABSC or safety precautions with the Hazard and Containment Manager.

items.title: How to write and submit an animal ethics application
items.summary: You must explain why the project is justified and what the project involves for the Animal Ethics Committee to be able to determine whether the use of animals in your project is justifiable and complies with legislation.

content.value: Required information

To be able to determine whether the use of animals in a project is justifiable and compliant with legislation, the Animal Ethics Committee needs to understand what the research and/or teaching project involves. When writing the application, keep the purpose in mind - the information that you provide should allow the AEC to assess:
The expected impact on animal welfare
Whether the experimental design is likely to result in useful, relevant and sufficient data that will answer the proposed research question
How the 3Rs have been taken into account to minimise the animal welfare impact, see
Whether the investigators have the required skills to perform the work and will be trained and/or supervised appropriately
Whether the expected benefits of the research or teaching outcome justifies the use of the animals

Before you start writing the application you should be able to explain why the project is justified, and answer the following 
questions:
What are the aims of the project and what results are expected?
Why is the use of animals in the project unavoidable?
What manipulations will be performed on the animals?
How will these manipulations impact on the welfare of the animal?
What have you done to ensure that animals are replaced where possible, the methods used are refined where possible, and the number of animals used is reduced to the minimum possible?
Who will perform the manipulations? Are these people competent to do so, or do they require training and/or supervision?
Please note: It is the application as a whole that is approved. Approval is not merely permission to use a particular manipulation or a certain number of animals.
Writing an application

Please pay attention to grammar, writing style, and layout when writing the application. Keep in mind that the first section should be comprehensible to the lay members of the Animal Ethics Committee and that sections of the application may be released to the public. Before you start, see
When filling out the application form:
Read all questions and instructions carefully
Provide a relevant answer to each question
Provide sufficient detail, but do not repeat information unnecessarily
Make sure that section B is comprehensible for lay members (think 15 year old with no science background)
Use tables, flowcharts, timelines and/or pictures to clarify complex concepts or experimental designs
Refer to the instructions for
Animals used for Manipulations/Tissue Collection
Do not provide details on drug administration, when referring to the management of animals; refer to the IDAO instead (e.g. “Rats will be anaesthetised as per IDAO.”).
Review the
'Tips for writing an AEC application'
document, and if you have any questions about the application form or how to fill it out, please do not hesitate to contact the
Animal Ethics Administrator

Submission deadlines include an application pre-screening service. You will receive feedback on how to improve the application and will have a chance to make suggested changes, before it is sent to the AEC for consideration. This will help to facilitate a smooth progression of the application process and the greater likelihood of a positive outcome in a faster manner.
Application forms
Submission of a Research or Teaching Application must be made via
Teaching questionnaire and summary of responses
Additional forms (optional, as instructed in the application e-form)
Institutional Drug Administration Order (IDAO)

If the application includes the use of prescription medicines (human or animal) and/or medicines to be used for the direct management of the animals, such as anaesthetics and analgesics, please complete and forward an Institutional Drug Administration Order (IDAO). More information, as well as Instructions and a template of an IDAO form, can be found in
. If you require further assistance after consulting these documents, please contact the
Animal Welfare Officer
The IDAO does not need to accompany the application and may be sent later. However, no medicines may be used under the approval until the IDAO has been received and
signed off by the AWO
Note: Drugs that are used as experimental variables (e.g. the use of insulin in diabetes research) are not used to manage the animal, and do not require an IDAO.
Animal Welfare Monitoring records
Any manipulations in Section D.4 of the application must be recorded using an Animal Welfare Monitoring Record.
Examples of Animal Welfare Monitoring Records can be found below. These may be adapted to the specific animal/experimental requirements of your particular research project.
The Animal Welfare Monitoring Record
must be attached to your application
In many approvals, large numbers of animals are manipulated over a short period of time.

If no abnormalities are found during the monitoring, a “No abnormalities” monitoring record may be used. This confirms that the animals have been monitored and are in good health. An individual monitoring record is not required for each animal.
A template of a “No abnormalities” monitoring record can be found below.
If an abnormality is found, or an animal is showing signs of sickness or distress, an Animal Welfare Monitoring sheet must be completed additionally for this animal.
Welfare monitoring sheet (No abnormalities) – example
Welfare monitoring sheet - example 1
Welfare monitoring sheet - example 4 (Fish)
Submit your application
After completing the application, please check that all information is complete, clear, and grammatically correct. Applicants are strongly advised to ask a colleague to review the application.

After you have checked the application, you will need to submit it online to the designated person in your department for sign off. When sign off is completed, the application will automatically be sent to the Animal Ethics Administrator.
Pre-screen
Your application will be pre-screened once received. We will likely be able to provide you with valuable feedback to improve your application before official submission to the Committee.

If no changes are required, your application will automatically go through to the Committee. If changes are recommended, you will be asked to make these changes and re-submit your application through the online system.
Medicines use

If there are medicines required with this application, see Medicine use in animals section of this website for further details. Download the ‘Institutional Drug Administration Order (IDAO)’ form, and upload a word document draft to your Research or Teaching application eform. Signatures of all personnel can be obtained, after consultation with the AWO and a final version has been completed. The AWO is then able to sign the document.

Please note: For (partially) commercially funded research projects, or research projects performed by investigators from outside the University of Auckland, an application fee applies (currently, this is $2800.00 for research applications and $1500.00 for teaching applications). In addition, there will be costs for any site visit that is necessary to approve the application and/or monitor compliance of legislative responsibilities during the period of approval. Amendments to the original application, may also incur charges. Please contact the Animal Ethics Administrator for details of these charges.
Submission closing dates
Refer to the Animal Ethics Committee meeting dates for application
closing dates

. The completed application (signed by the HoD or their delegate, in the Ethics RM system) must be received by 11:59pm on the closing date. Any application received after the due date may be held until the next meeting. You will receive an automated email from the Ethics RM system confirming the submission of the application. It is best practice to assume that the application has not been submitted until this email has been received.

items.title: Animal Ethics Committee (AEC) Frequently Asked Questions
items.summary: Below is some guidance regarding the common questions and mistakes made while using Infonetica Ethics RM for Animal Ethics Approvals.

content.value: Where to go if you have any other questions not covered by this FAQ

If you have any questions regarding the submission process of an application or issues connected to Ethics RM please contact the Animal Ethics Administrator either via the “Correspondence” tab in Ethics RM or by sending an email to
animalethics@auckland.ac.nz

items.title: Apply to amend or renew approved user status
items.summary: Procedure for amending (e.g., adding new hosts, inserts or vectors) or renewing an approved user application.

content.value: Amendment request process

Approved Users that require changes to their approval will need to submit an amendment request to the UABSC. Such changes could include the addition of new hosts or a change in the scope of gene inserts. Minor amendments may not require full Committee review.
Researchers who are unsure if amendments still fall within the scope of the University Wide Low Risk HSNO approval should in the first instance contact the
Biological Safety Officer
How to submit a request

Send a request to the UABSC Administrator to unlock your Approved User form. This can be done by using the Correspondence function in Ethics RM (follow the steps in the ‘Submit a request for the application to be unlocked’ section of the
BSC - amendment request
user guide.
Submit the amendment following the steps in the
BSC -amendment request
user guide.

Approved Users will be sent a letter outlining the boundaries of your amended approval within the University Wide Low Risk HSNO approval. It is the PI’s responsibility to ensure that all low risk GMO development falls within the scope of your specific approval.
Renewal request process
