Approved User status will be granted for a period of up to three years, at which point Principal Investigators must apply for renewal.
Renewal applicants will only be required to outline any changes to their existing approval. Renewals that contain only minor changes will not require full Committee review.
Requests for renewal must be submitted in the Ethics RM software using the Amendment request process.

items.title: Essential reading before applying for an animal ethics approval
items.summary: Familiarise yourself with legislation and learn about University policies and procedures and the Animal Ethics Committee

content.value: Preparation
Familiarise yourself with legislation
Anyone working with animals
must
complete the New Animal Users Legislation Training module,
prior to the working with animals on an approved Animal Ethics Application
New Principal Investigators (PI)
must
complete the Legislation
and
the New Principal Investigator training,
prior to
submitting an Animal Ethics application
. Contact the Animal Ethics Administrator, for more information.
All personnel named on the application
must

read the current version of University of Auckland Code of Ethical Conduct to understand the legislation that the University and all investigators comply with and any IDAOs that are associated with the AEC approval:
The University of Auckland Code of Ethical Conduct
It is also recommended that all personnel on an Animal Ethics approval read the following:
The Animal Welfare Act 1999 – Part 6
NAEAC Good Practice Guide
Medicine Officers
must
read the institutional operating plan for the direct management of animals and the
in vitro
use of controlled drags and psychoactive substances:
Institutional Operating Plan for the Direct Management of Animals and the in vitro use of Controlled Drugs and Psychoactive Substances

In addition, for a better understanding of the requirements in part 6 of the Animal Welfare Act 1999, it is advised to read:

‘
The Use of Animals in Research, Testing and Teaching - Users Guide to Part 6 of the Animal Welfare Act 1999 ’
Design an ethically acceptable project

Think about how you will set up your experiments in an ethically acceptable manner. Keep the 3Rs in mind and consider alternative models and methods. Consult relevant literature and guidelines to determine which methods are considered best practice. The following information may help complete an animal ethics application.
Read the document 'Tips for writing an AEC application'.
Norecopa PREPARE Guidelines for Planning Animal Research and Testing
ANZCCART Factsheet
If you are not sure what the best methods are, consult your colleagues, animal facility staff, investigate the resources in this website or contact the
Animal Welfare Officer
for additional help.
Responsibility

The  University is conscious of its responsibilities to its staff, as well as to the wider community. Staff should take into account the increasing interest in the accountability of institutions regarding animal related research, and that the University must consciously strive to maintain its position as a trustworthy and caring member of the community. The University must be able to demonstrate that not only is all teaching and research of the highest standard, but also that adequate justification 
can be provided for the use of all animals in research, testing and teaching.

The details of animal use and approved protocols are official information in terms of the Official Information Act 1982 and members of the public are entitled to request the release of this information. Provided the request complies with the provision of the Act, and there are no grounds (see e.g. Section 9 of the Act) for withholding the information, the University is obliged to supply the requested information within 20 working days.

Current university policy is not to release information without first advising the Principal Investigator (PI). However, due to the relatively limited time allowed by the legislation to respond to requests, the University will normally be obliged to release the information requested before the PI has commented on it. For this reason it is important that PIs keep the Animal Ethics Administrator informed of their contact address before any significant period of absence from the University.

The release of information is handled by the University Counsel, the Vice-Chancellor (Operations) and Registrar, in consultation with the Chair of the AEC. All information which might be used to identify individual members of staff is currently withheld. The Act provides, however, that any person can ask the ombudsman to review the University's decision to withhold information. The regulation of animal experimentation, and the release of the associated information, is subject to change and animal users will be kept informed of significant developments.
Animal Ethics Committee

The Animal Ethics Committee (AEC) consists of representatives of the University and external members. The exact composition of the AEC and its responsibilities and rights are detailed in the following document:
The University of Auckland Code of Ethical Conduct
The AEC meets ten times per year to consider new applications and amendments, reports on projects, and any animal welfare issues.
Animal ethics organisations

Guidance for Animal Ethics Committees in New Zealand is provided by the National Animal Ethics Advisory Committee (NAEAC) (an advisory committee to the Minister for Primary Industries). In addition, the Australian and New Zealand Council for the Care of Animals in Research and Teaching (ANZCCART) is a standing committee of the Royal Society Te Apārangi that provides information for Animal Ethics Committees (AEC), scientists, teachers, regulatory authorities, granting agencies, government, animal welfare organisations, the media, and the general public. Both organisations provide good guidelines and useful links.
National Animal Ethics Advisory Committee (NAEAC)
MPI- Animals in Research
Australian and New Zealand Council for the Care of Animals in Research and Teaching (ANZCCART)

items.title: Applying for an SOP
items.summary: This page outlines all the steps that are needed to apply for an SOP.

content.value: In accordance with the
NAEAC Good Practice Guide
for the use of animals in research, testing and teaching, Standard Operating Procedures (SOP) should be developed to enable the consistent performance of routine tasks.
SOPs will be approved for a maximum of three years, at any one time. PIs should review their SOPs regularly and submit amendments for review by the AEC when changes are necessary.
Any person working with animals at the University of Auckland must be trained to competently perform study-related manipulations and must be aware of relevant SOPs, where they exist.
Prior to submitting an application for an SOP, please discuss the proposed SOP with the Animal Welfare Officer to ensure that it is suitable and does not overlap with any other existing SOPs.
When writing the SOP please make use of the standard
SOP template
and the '
Tips for Writing an SOP
' document. Using these documents will ensure that your SOP is up to the standard that is expected by the Animal Ethics Committee.

Once the SOP is written and all relevant staff have provided input, please submit it for consideration using the Infonetica Ethics RM system. When submitting, please ensure that a digital copy of the SOP is attached. If you are submitting an amendment or update to an already existing SOP, please ensure that you upload both a Word document version containing the track changes and a PDF version of the final version.

Please ensure that the SOP is submitted by or before 11:59PM on the relevant submission deadline. If it is not submitted by this time the SOP will likely need to wait to be considered at the next month's Animal Ethics Committee meeting.
Once the Committee has considered the SOP a letter will be sent to the listed owner outlining the outcome and any provisions that have been requested.

items.title: Importation of low risk GMOs
items.summary: How to initiate importation of low risk GMOs in containment.

content.value: Importation of low risk GMOs into an MPI-approved University Containment Facility requires an HSNO approval and an MPI permit.
The University holds HSNO approval which allows the import of a broad range of low risk GMOs (such genetically modified
E. coli
and cell lines) as well as other HSNO approvals for the import of animal and plant GMOs.
Investigators wishing to import low risk GMOs should in the first instance contact
containment@auckland.ac.nz

items.title: Apply to develop high risk GMOs
items.summary: Procedure for use of existing approvals to develop higher risk GMOs and how to initiate a new application. Prior UABSC approval is required before any GMO development can be undertaken.

content.value: Overview
A High risk GMO
is defined as any organism that does not meet the requirements of Low Risk Genetic Modification as defined in the HSNO (Low Risk Genetic Modification) Regulations, 2003.
Typical Higher Risk GMO applications include:
Genetic modification using viral vectors where the inserted DNA encodes proteins known to be involved in uncontrolled cell growth
Genetic modification with genes encoding highly toxic proteins
Genetic modification of RG3 hosts.

There are two pathways for obtaining approval to develop high risk GMOs. The first pathway involves applying to use one of the existing high risk HSNO approvals held by the University of Auckland. If your work does not fit within these approvals then the second pathway is to apply for a new higher risk HSNO approval from the EPA.
Existing HSNO approvals held by the University

The University of Auckland has a number of HSNO approvals for the development of specific higher risk GMOs. Researchers who wish to use these HSNO approvals must first apply to the UABSC for approval to use an Existing Approval.
Existing HSNO approvals for the development of specific high risk GMOs:
ERMA200732

– covers packaging and use of replication-defective viral vectors in specified species of cell lines and rodent tissue. This approval covers a wide range of inserts but note that genes from person of Māori descent are excluded. This approval also covers the genetic modification of some viruses. Please note that the controls on this approval are prescriptive.
– covers the production of specified cell lines with Sendai viruses with Yamanaka Factors (which includes the oncogene
c-myc
). Please note that the controls on this approval are outcome-based.

– covers packaging and use of replication-defective retroviral vectors with oncogenes in specified species of cell lines. It also covers the immortalisation of cell lines using replication-defective retroviral vectors. Genes from person of Māori descent are not excluded. Please note that the controls on this approval are outcome-based.

There are also HSNO approvals for specific species and purposes. These approvals include use and production of AAV and Retroviral vectors for neurological research, importation of Hepatitis virus B expressing cell lines and genetic modification of
Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
Further details regarding these specific approvals can be obtained from the
Biological Safety Officer
Applicants wishing to use an existing high risk HSNO approval must:
Contact the Biological Safety Officer to discuss proposed project and the relevant higher risk HSNO approval.
Create a new UoA Biological Safety Application – “
Application to use an existing HSNO approval
” using
following steps in the
Infonetica Ethics RM – Creating an application
guide.
Submit the application following the steps in the
Infonetica Ethics RM – Submitting an Application - no sign-off
(Biological Safety Committee applications only) guide.
Note that only the Principal Investigator can submit the application as they will be required to agree to terms and conditions of the application in the process of submission.
Other PIs with similar projects and GMOs can duplicate an approval and amend project details as applicable for their approvals.
The application must be submitted at least 10 working days before the next
UABSC scheduled meeting
For more information please contact the Biological Safety Officer.
HSNO applications to the EPA
In the event that the development of a GMO is not covered by an existing HSNO approval, an application will have to be made to the EPA to obtain a new HSNO approval.
The Deputy Vice-Chancellor (Research) requires that the University, UABSC, and the Operators of Containment Facilities are aware of all applications made to EPA.

Applications to EPA to develop new high risk GMOs must therefore be submitted to the UABSC in the first instance. While the UABSC is unable to provide formal assessment of the application, the Committee and Biological Safety Officer will provide advice and support for applicants.
Applicants wishing to apply for a new high risk HSNO approval from the EPA must:
Contact the Biological Safety Officer for advice on completing the application.
Create a new UoA Biological Safety Application – “
Applications to the EPA (Develop a new HSNO approval)
” using
and following steps in the
Infonetica Ethics RM – Creating an application
guide. This will allow you to submit a copy of the HSNO application for inclusion in the agenda of an upcoming UABSC meeting.
The application must be submitted at least 10 working days before the next
UABSC scheduled meeting
The UABSC will provide feedback for the applicant who will work with the Biological Safety Officer towards the final draft.
Upon satisfaction of the UABSC the application will be submitted by the Biological Safety Administrator to the EPA on behalf of the applicant.
Copy of the approval will be held by the UABSC administration when received.
Advise the UABSC of any further amendments or variations and subsequent approvals.
For more information please contact the Biological Safety Officer

items.title: Diamond Open Access
items.summary: Some journals publish high-quality, open access content without charging either the author or the reader. This is called Diamond Open Access.

content.value: What is Diamond Open Access?

In Diamond OA, there are no costs to either the author or the reader. Diamond OA journals are usually published by academic institutions, academic societies or funding organisations. The costs associated with publishing and peer-reviewing articles are typically covered by the institutions or organisations themselves rather than requiring authors to pay article processing charges (APCs). This means that both authors and readers can access and share research findings without financial barriers.

Diamond OA journals prioritise the principles of transparency, inclusivity and accessibility. They often employ rigorous peer-review processes to ensure the quality and reliability of published articles. Removing financial barriers promotes equal access to scientific knowledge for both the author and the reader.
Diamond Open Access is steadily gaining recognition and support within the academic community.  The sustainability of this model relies on institutional support and continued funding.
How do I find Diamond OA journals?
The best place to find Diamond OA journals is the
Journals without fees section

of the Directory of Open Access Journals (DOAJ), an independent, not-for-profit organisation. DOAJ's mission is to increase the visibility, accessibility, reputation, usage and impact of quality, peer-reviewed, open access scholarly research journals globally, regardless of discipline, geography or language. DOAJ is also the founding organisation of
Think. Check Submit.
DOAJ has a list of 13,000+ OA journals that do not charge APCs.
DOAJ
works very hard
to ensure that the journals included in its database are all legitimate; however, if you have concerns about a journal's quality or legitimacy, please report it to DOAJ.
Further information and related resources:
Diamond OA events from
The OA Diamond Journals Study - Science Europe

items.title: Green Open Access
items.summary: Learn how to make your work open by putting a copy into a publicly accessible online repository or archive. This pathway to open access is commonly known as Green Open Access.
keywords: ministry of business innovation and employment
ministry of business, innovation and employment

content.value: What is Green OA?

At its simplest, Green Open Access is making an earlier version of your work legally and openly available in an online repository or archive. Click on the headings below for a more in-depth explanation of each piece.
Why should I publish via Green OA?
Green OA offers many advantages to researchers. Green OA...
is
free
! It does not cost money to deposit your work into a repository or online archive.
creates
permanent copies
of your manuscripts and published works that will persist reliably into the future, even if a journal folds or a publisher stops offering online access.
leads to
increased discoverability
, which can result in greater exposure and higher citations.
helps readers
find the official, final version of your work (the direct DOI link is provided as part of the repository's metadata).
is an
equitable alternative
to Gold OA (please read
for more information).
University and funder policy compliance
Making your work Green OA is also compliant with the University of Auckland's
Open Access policy
as well as most funders' OA requirements (including
MBIE
How do I publish Green OA?

items.title: Ethical concerns about Open Access fees and APCs
items.summary: Do you have ethical concerns about the equity of Open Access fees and APCs? Learn how Green and Diamond Open Access can help address these issues.

content.value: There is a growing international trend toward Open Access (OA). Initiatives such as
cOAlition S
and funder mandates such as
MBIE
and the
Australian Research Council
are helping to drive this. However, the shift from paywalled articles to OA is a major cultural and systemic change, and therefore will take time.

The current system requiring researchers to pay OA fees and Article Processing Charges (APCs) was originally envisioned as a transitional phase to assist publishers in moving away from the traditional subscription route and toward a fully OA route. cOAlition S has announced that it will stop supporting this model
by the end of 2024
. However, the APC model has become well-established and will likely continue in some parts of the world beyond that timeframe.
Many researchers have raised ethical concerns about the APC publishing model, such as:
Publishing research is a critical, embedded part of the academic ecosystem. Many researchers feel they are therefore
forced to participate and publish

in an ethically questionable system. Researchers may also feel that the University is contributing to the problem by providing funding to help pay for APCs and paying for Open Access publishing agreements. However, all routes to OA, including APCs, lower barriers for anyone who wants to access our research. This ensures equitable access for all readers, including those beyond academia, so that research produced by the University's researchers can have the widest reach and impact possible. 

The University therefore offers multiple avenues of support to its researchers, including the Green OA route below.
Diamond OA and Green OA: more equitable alternatives to APCs

If you are a researcher with concerns about the ethics and inequities inherent in the current APC publishing model, the Diamond OA and Green OA publishing routes are a legitimate way to address these issues. Publishing via these routes:
makes your work freely available to all researchers without paying APCs and
complies with the University's
Open Access policy
and funder mandates.
To learn more about Diamond OA and Green OA and how to publish via these routes, please read:
Further reading:
Klebel, T. & Ross-Hellauer, T. (2023). The APC-barrier and its effect on stratification in open access publishing.
Quantitative Science Studies
https://doi-org.ezproxy.auckland.ac.nz/10.1162/qss_a_00245
Frank, J., Foster, R., & Pagliari, C. (2023). Open access publishing – noble intention, flawed reality.
Social Science & Medicine
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.socscimed.2022.115592

Seguya, A., Salano, V., Okerosi, S., Kim, E.K., Shrime, M.G., Viljoen, G., Fagan, J.J. (2023). Are open access article processing charges affordable for otolaryngologists in low-income and middle-income countries?
Current Opinion in Otolaryngology & Head and Neck Surgery,
Smith, E., Haustein, S., Mongeon, P.
et al.
(2017). Knowledge sharing in global health research – the impact, uptake and cost of open access to scholarly literature.
Health Res Policy Sys,
https://doi-org.ezproxy.auckland.ac.nz/10.1186/s12961-017-0235-3
Beasley, G. (2016). Article Processing Charges: A New Route to Open Access? Information Services & Use, 36(3-4), pp. 163-170. doi: 10.3233/ISU-160815

items.title: Supervision Hub
items.summary: The Supervision Hub includes key supervision resources, guides and checklists, accreditation information, development opportunities and more.

content.value: This Supervision Hub includes accreditation information, development opportunities, guides and checklists, and more. We recommend bookmarking this page for easy access.

While the policy and procedures featured are predominantly applicable to doctoral supervision, many of the practice-focused resources will be beneficial to supervisors of research students in sub-doctoral programmes.
Visit the Supervision Hub

items.title: Creating Connections Grant
items.summary: The Creating Connections Grant funds research initiatives led by doctoral candidates that aim to build inter-faculty connections throughout the University’s research community.

content.value: Doctoral candidates leading initiatives that aim to foster new connections across the University’s research community could be awarded up to $300 with a Creating Connections Grant.

The goal of this scheme is to encourage doctoral candidates to initiate and lead a range of research-related activities that will contribute to the development of supportive networks of peer researchers. Doctoral candidates may organise activities such as symposia, exhibitions, discussion groups, seminars, and visiting speakers.

Activities should be designed to build interdisciplinary networks, spanning at least two faculties. Applications are encouraged that enhance inclusiveness and target participation from a diverse group of people. Events may be arranged for face-to-face interactions, or online, in order to reach candidates who may be unable to participate in-person (e.g. candidates studying off-campus, candidates with whānau responsibilities, or part-time candidates).
Find out more and apply at
Creating Connections Grant
The Creating Connections Grant is supported by the
School of Graduate Studies

items.title: Why should I make my work Open Access?
items.summary: Learn how OA benefits individual researchers as well as institutions as a whole. University policy and many funders now require researchers to make their work OA where possible.

content.value: Open Access brings increased visibility, usage and impact to researchers and institutions. It benefits researchers, institutions, nations and society as a whole. Institutional policies and funder mandates requiring researchers to make their work open are becoming more common, both nationally and internationally.

items.title: What is Open Access?
items.summary: Learn how OA differs from traditional publishing, the different types of OA and the relevance of Creative Commons licensing to OA practices. This page also contains a glossary of common terms used when discussing OA.

content.value: The University's
Open Access policy

defines Open Access as "a set of principles and practices through which academic research outputs are made available publicly through online distribution, either via an open access journal, open access book, or inclusion in an institutional or disciplinary repository."

Open Access (OA) allows anyone, regardless of financial resources, to access peer-reviewed research articles and other scholarly materials. Research that is paywalled can create barriers for students, researchers and individuals from developing countries or under-resourced institutions. OA promotes equal opportunities for learning, research and innovation, particularly for those who do not have the means to pay for costly journal subscriptions. It also encourages greater collaboration among researchers and more rapid dissemination of knowledge, ultimately advancing scientific progress and benefiting society as a whole.
Open Access also enables authors to retain rights to their own work and determine how others use and share their work through the use of
licenses. Open access materials can include journal articles, creative works, books and book chapters, conference proceedings, theses, presentations, data, images and more.

items.title: National Science Challenges hosted by the University of Auckland
items.summary: The National Science Challenges aim to tackle the biggest science-based issues and opportunities facing New Zealand. The Challenges bring together the country’s top scientists to work collaboratively across disciplines, institutions and borders.

content.value: The
National Science Challenges (NSCs)
funded by the Ministry of Business, Innovation and Employment (MBIE). The University of Auckland hosts two of the eleven NSCs:
A Better Start
High-Value Nutrition

items.title: Openness in research
items.summary: The practice of applying principles of openness throughout the research environment to unlock barriers for research impact and engagement.

content.value: Defining openness in research
Openness in Research
or ‘Open Scholarship’ is the practice of applying principles of openness throughout the research environment.
Open access (OA)
is the practice of making published research freely available on the internet and in repositories such as
and
, the University of Auckland's institutional repositories.
Open access material includes;
Journal articles
Creative works
Books
Book chapters
Conference proceedings
Theses
Data and images
With closed research now becoming the exception, openness in research will become the default starting point for most research disciplines. Consideration must also be given to
Māori Data Sovereignty
and
The FAIR and CARE Principles
for indigenous data, where open may not always be the appropriate starting point.
Openness in animal research

has been increasing internationally for many years and has now moved firmly into NZ, with the launch of the openness agreement on animal research and teaching July 2021. The scientific community providing information about the nature, extent, and purpose of animals used in research and teaching is crucial for enhancing public understanding and confidence.
“Being open and engaged, striving to build strong, transparent and reciprocal relationships with local and global communities” - Taumata Teitei, The University of Auckland I Waipapa Taumata Rau
In 2021, the Research & Innovation (R&I) Operating Plan has included two key initiatives which will deliver the University’s aspiration towards enhancing openness in research:
Open access in research
Openness in animal research and teaching
Both initiatives have been prioritised within the 2022 Plan to support the strategic objectives for the University of Auckland in terms of greater impact, improved ranking, and global reputation.
Benefits of openness in research
By engaging with open research, greater transparency and reproducibility are applied to research work and research publications and outputs. Subsequently, open research practices:
Increase likelihood of research impact due to broader visibility of publications and outputs,
Increase exposure of research publications and outputs globally, leading to increased citations,
Mitigate issues with research reproducibility,
Create greater synergies in research generally as the need for repetition or duplication is reduced,
Improve animal and human wellbeing (with the direct positive impact on quality outputs).
Further information and resources
If you would like to know more about the existing resources and processes linked to these activities, please click on the links below:

items.title: Responsible Metrics
items.summary: The limitations of traditional metrics and using them responsibly

content.value: If you are using metrics to evaluate research, you need to ensure that the metrics you choose accurately and fairly represent impact.

Traditional metrics have limitations. It is important for researchers and research committees to acknowledge the limitations of traditional metrics and to use metrics responsibly. Below are some tips on using metrics responsibly according to four principles: using appropriate metrics, using robust metrics, giving context to metrics and being transparent about metrics used.
Resources on responsible metric use

Review of metric use in academic evaluations have received a high level of scrutiny and various institutions have developed guidelines for metric use. More information behind the tips above can be found in these resources.
The
Declaration on Research Assessment (DORA)

created in 2012 brings together a range of recommendations around metrics and scientific evaluation.

The
Leiden Manifesto (2015)
discusses 10 principles to guide research evaluation
(summary video, 4.39 minutes)
“The Metric Tide”,
a 2015 independent review into the role of metrics in research assessment proposed five basic principles for the responsible use of metrics:
Banner image: Pawel Czerwinski, Unsplash (2019)

items.title: Why do we have Vision Mātauranga and what is its relevance in a research context?
items.summary: Prior to conducting your research it is important to understand that research has had a detrimental impact on Māori.

content.value: Vision Mātauranga has relevance for all New Zealanders. Whilst the framework looks at distinctive issues, challenges and opportunities arising within Māori communities, Vision Mātauranga encourages and cultivates research outcomes that make a contribution to New Zealand as a whole. The Vision Mātauranga policy framework drives research investment decisions made by government agencies. Therefore, as a researcher, it is important to recognise how Vision Mātauranga can be incorporated and implemented throughout your research planning process.
The Principles of the Treaty & Wai 262

The identification of Treaty principles in 1988 and the Wai 262 claim lodged to the Waitangi Tribunal in 1991 began to highlight the implications of the Treaty and mātauranga in contemporary society. The Wai 262 claim addressed the ownership and use of mātauranga, cultural expressions and indigenous species of flora and fauna, all regarded as
taonga
(treasures). It also addressed the need to recognise Māori culture, identity and traditional knowledge in New Zealand's laws, and government policies and practices.
Taumata Teitei
Taumata Teitei fundamental principles of
manaakitanga, whanaungatanga and kaitiakitanga

, are based and reflect the foundational relationship with tangata whenua and Te Tiriti.  Taumata Teitei also makes a commitment to value other knowledge systems including mātauranga Māori and to develop partnerships with Māori to advance shared aims and aspirations and to develop, implement, monitor, and evaluate programmes to achieve mutual benefit. These actions can be supported through research that aligns with the Vision Mātauranga framework.
Resources
Below are some links to resources you may find useful in understanding the influence these documents have on the Vision Mātauranga policy and their relevance and importance within a research context.

items.title: Who do I engage with to get more advice about Vision Mātauranga?
items.summary: This information is intended to help identify how to get more advice.

content.value: University support

There is a variety of support available within Waipapa Taumata Rau l University of Auckland to assist with the development and planning of your research proposal. Before you engage with this support, it is important you have navigated and read the resources available within the He Korowai Mātauranga webpages. The content that sits within He Korowai Mātauranga is designed to build your capability and capacity in the area of Vision Mātauranga and Māori engagement.
Learn more about
Te Ao Māori at Waipapa Taumata Rau l The University of Auckland
Resources
Below is a tool to help you 'brainstorm' and demonstrate the strengths and identify opportunities to make your research responsive to Māori.

items.title: What is Vision Mātauranga?
items.summary: Vision Mātauranga - To envision knowledge, to think about new ways of doing things, to find answers, to solve problems.

content.value: Māori involvement in research that is relevant to Māori is advocated for via the Vision Mātauranga policy. It is not possible to unlock the Māori knowledge/dimension unless Māori people are participating. Vision Mātauranga enables opportunities for Māori leadership in research, stronger relationships with Māori and Māori as participants not just subjects.
Vision Mātauranga focuses on four main themes:
Indigenous innovation -
the development of products, processes, systems and services from Māori knowledge, resources and people.
Taiao -
Achieving sustainability through understanding iwi and hapū relationships with the environment – including kaitiakitanga or guardianship.
Hauora and oranga  -
Providing better health and social wellbeing for Māori through research that meets the distinctive needs of Māori communities.
Mātauranga -
Exploring indigenous knowledge and research, science and technology and developing a distinctive body of knowledge at the interface between indigenous and western knowledge.
Mātauranga definition
Mātauranga is a unique body of knowledge from a Māori worldview. It incorporates Māori traditional knowledge, language, practices and culture.
Resources
Below you will find the Vision Mātauranga policy and articles on mātauranga that you may find useful. There are also more resources on other pages of He Korowai Mātauranga.

items.title: Taiao
items.summary: Achieving sustainability through understanding iwi and hapū relationships with the environment

content.value: The following examples highlight research from the University of Auckland which align with the taiao theme
Assessing the net benefits of Auckland Council Stormwater projects using the Mauri Model

: This article discusses the application of the Mauri Model to Auckland stormwater projects to complement cost benefit and multicriteria analysis. This example relates to the taiao theme as the model acknowledges how values embodied in mātauranga Māori can be better recognised and engaged to facilitate better resource management.
Decision making at the Interface: Mauri and its contribution to the Rena Recovery

- This article discusses the application of the Mauri Model in assessing the impacts of the Rena disaster. This example relates to the taiao theme as it shows how the recovery of the mauri of the environment to its pre-Rena state was facilitated through combining scientific and indigenous knowledge through iwi engagement.
Matauranga Māori   in geomorphology: existing  frameworks, case studies, and recommendations for incorporating Indigenous knowledge in Earth science

: This article identifies the direct benefits of incorporating mātauranga within the field of geomorphology and reviews theoretical frameworks and models for including Māori values within research. This links to the theme of taiao as this review aims to encourage research which integrates genuine partnership with Māori in the field of geomorphology.
Kua takoto te mānuka: mātauranga Māori in New Zealand ecology

: This article discusses the importance of including mātauranga in ecological research and provides several recent exemplars of good practice, which demonstrate the development of authentic partnerships with Māori. This relates to the taiao theme as it provides examples of ecological research which has acknowledged and incorporated iwi and hapū relationships with the environment.
A geomorphic perspective on the rights of the river in Aotearoa New Zealand

: Using the case study of the Whanganui river this article discusses how mātauranga Māori can be integrated into western science for river management and the value of incorporating both knowledge systems.
He Mahere Pāhekoheko Mō Kaipara Moana–Integrated Ecosystem-Based Management for Kaipara Harbour, Aotearoa New Zealand

: This article discusses a framework of co-management called He mahere pāhekoheko mō Kaipara moana – Integrated Kaipara harbour management – this model connects and utilizes mātauranga alongside Western principles of ecosystem-based management. This example links to the taiao theme as the mahere framework positions local iwi and hapu as partners in the management of the Kaipara Harbour, a significant environmental resource.
A new look at sustainable forestry of the future: Aotearoa-New Zealand philosophy

: This article discusses how mātauranga has been incorporated in the functioning of a Māori enterprise using a case study in the forestry industry. It discusses future goals which aim to incorporate more mātauranga and iwi/hapu engagement into the functioning of the enterprise. This links to the taiao theme as it provides an example of a Māori led enterprise associated with environmental resources.
Ko te Waimāori tō tātou taonga: Septic tank mitigation in Takahiwai

: This video highlights research which investigates the impact of septic tank use on the surrounding environment at Takahiwai. The project introduces novel green chemistry methods of maintaining and monitoring septic tanks in collaboration with mātauranga Māori. The research which included a series of community wānanga and hīkoi contributes to a larger community project that is committed to mitigating health and environmental issues at Takahiwai. This project relates to the theme of taiao as it uses mātauranga Māori to mitigate environmental issues and acknowledges the relationships mana whenua have with their environment.

items.title: Mātauranga
items.summary: Exploring indigenous knowledge and research, science and technology and developing a distinctive body of knowledge at the interface between indigenous and western knowledge

content.value: The following examples highlight research from the University of Auckland which align with the mātauranga theme
He Mahere Pāhekoheko Mō Kaipara Moana–Integrated Ecosystem-Based Management for Kaipara Harbour, Aotearoa New Zealand

: This article discusses a framework of co-management called He mahere pāhekoheko mō Kaipara moana – Integrated Kaipara harbour management – this model connects and utilizes mātauranga alongside Western principles of ecosystem-based management. This links to the theme of mātauranga as the mahere model integrates Māori and western knowledge.
Whareuku

: This video highlights engineering research where muka from harakeke and mud are used to build papakainga housing on Māori land across NZ. This example relates to the mātauranga theme as it highlights the use of indigenous knowledge and technology to generate a new engineering technique at the interface between western and indigenous knowledge.
Assessing the net benefits of Auckland Council Stormwater projects using the Mauri Model

: This paper describes the development of a stormwater-specific Mauri Model assessment and its application to Auckland stormwater projects to complement cost benefit and multicriteria analysis. This example relates to the mātauranga theme as it highlights the development of a distinct body of knowledge which integrates Māori knowledge surrounding sustainability and western knowledge associated with cost benefit analyses.
Project Matauranga Rena Disaster (Using the Mauri Model)

: This video highlights the use of the Mauri Model in assessing the impacts of the Rena disaster and returning the mauri of the environment to the pre-Rena state. The Mauri Model acknowledges how sustainability values embodied in mātauranga Māori can support economic and engineering decision making. This links to the theme of mātauranga as the model has developed a distinctive body of knowledge at the interface between indigenous and western knowledge.
Ko te Waimāori tō tātou taonga: Septic tank mitigation in Takahiwai

: This video highlights research which investigates the impact of septic tank use on the surrounding environment at Takahiwai. The project introduces novel green chemistry methods of maintaining and monitoring septic tanks in collaboration with mātauranga Māori. This project relates to the theme of mātauranga as it integrates green chemistry with mātauranga to form new methods for managing septic waste.

items.title: Indigenous Innovation
items.summary: The development of products, processes, systems and services from Māori knowledge, resources and people

content.value: The following examples highlight research from the University of Auckland which align with the indigenous innovation theme
Whareuku

: This video highlights engineering research where muka from harakeke and mud are used to build papakainga housing on Māori land across NZ. This example relates to the indigenous innovation theme as it highlights the development of housing materials using Māori knowledge and resources.
A new look at sustainable forestry of the future: Aotearoa-New Zealand philosophy

: This article discusses how Maori cultural values and mātauranga have been incorporated in the functioning of a Maori enterprise using a case study in the forestry industry. It discusses future goals which aim to incorporate more mātauranga into the functioning of the enterprise. This example links to the indigenous innovation theme as it highlights how an enterprise has been established and run by Māori resources, people and knowledge.
Decision Support Tools and the Indigenous Paradigm:

This article discusses the Mauri Model and its incorporation of Māori values. The model is a method of sustainability assessment based around concepts of mauri. This links to indigenous innovation as it provides an example of a sustainability assessment methodology formed from Māori knowledge.

items.title: Deposit licence T&Cs for ResearchSpace
items.summary: This page summarises the terms and conditions that staff and students must agree to when depositing work in ResearchSpace, the University of Auckland's institutional research repository.

content.value: University of Auckland staff and students depositing work in
, the University of Auckland's institutional research repository,
must read, understand and agree to the terms of the ResearchSpace deposit licence outlined below.
Work incuded under the deposit licence
Work deposited and stored in
is restricted to Research Outputs created by members of the University of Auckland, including:
Journal articles
Conference papers
Research/technical reports
Other research materials
Theses
Any one of these works are referred to as the "Work" in the rest of this licence summary.
Your rights and conditions of deposit

By depositing the Work in the University of Auckland research repository, ResearchSpace, I grant the University of Auckland a non-exclusive licence to copy, translate to any medium or format (for the purpose of preservation or migration), and/or communicate the Work (including the abstract) worldwide in electronic format in accordance with the terms and conditions of the

items.title: The Smart Digital Lab
items.summary: The Smart Digital Lab uses emerging disruptive digital technologies and battle hardened existing technologies, to explore, solve and teach complex engineering principles and problems.

content.value:
Using advanced usability techniques, we augment people’s abilities so that experts and students alike can experience, visualise, design and construct in a way that is completely impossible in the real world. We do this primarily using intelligent digital twin simulations and gamified virtual environments. Our goal is for technology and humans to work together in
symbiosis, with the whole greater than the sum of the individual parts.
Computer Simulation and Modelling

This sub-area is focused on the development and implementation of computer modelling techniques such as discrete-event
simulation, dynamic system and agent-based modelling, to model, simulate and optimise a number of problems in construction such as resource allocation and utilisation, logistics, health and safety, social dynamics in construction
organisations, sustainable construction, production planning and control, decision–making analysis, among others. In addition, quake and tsunami evacuation (micro and macro scale) problems are modelled primarily combining multi-agent systems and machine learning.
Building Information Modelling

The purpose of this sub-area is to develop and apply Building Information Modelling (BIM)-based tools, processes, and technologies to provide solutions to some of the construction problems related to supply chain integration and collaboration, planning and control, project delivery (design, planning, construction, delivery, and maintenance), behavioural-based building design, among others.
Serious Game/Mixed Reality

This sub-area aims to apply mixed reality (e.g. VR, AR), serious games and artificial intelligence technologies to deal with a variety of engineering problems in the built environment such as project engineering and management problems, quake and tsunami evacuation (micro and macro scale), and health and safety issues.
Sustainable Construction
The aim of this sub-area is to apply computer modelling techniques to solve environmental and production problems concurrently in construction capital projects.
Occupational Health and Safety

In this subarea, different computing approaches such as serious games, virtual reality, system dynamics, artificial intelligence,
and others, are applied to investigate different occupational health and safety problems in construction projects.
Production Management and Lean Construction

This sub-area applies computer modelling techniques, artificial intelligence, multi-objective optimisation, system identification, control theory, mixed reality and serious games to production planning and control problems, lean production-driven issues in construction, decision-making, and social dynamics in construction organisations.
Digital Twinning and Lean Construction 4.0

This sub-area pays attention to the development of digital technologies and production management theory merging lean construction and industry 4.0/ Digital twin research aims to link IoT, BIM, mixed reality, machine learning, computer simulation, lean-based planning and control, and culturally-driven human computer interaction and UC-design, in order to deliver more effective capital projects. Lean Construction 4.0 pays attention to the blend of production management theory and smart/digital technologies associated with industry 4.0.
Cycle traffic safety

This sub-area aims to tackle issues that user face utilising different modes of transport as cycling. Cycling in Auckland can be a hair-raising activity with buses, bicycles, cars and pedestrians all sharing the same space. Whilst the best solution is to remove the more vulnerable to their own transport corridors, this is not always possible. In order to increase awareness, investigate current behaviours and to help train people in safe behaviours whilst riding a bicycle without subjecting them to real danger, we use the Mixed Reality bicycle, which is a combination of a virtual reality headset on a stationary bicycle simulating Auckland traffic.
Automated and remote damage assessment of assets

This sub-area is a cross-disciplinary effort combining structural engineering, construction management, computer science and mechanical engineering (robotics) disciplines. It is no surprise that many natural events such as earthquakes, extreme weather and floods cause damage to infrastructure such as bridges and buildings. However, being able to survey the structure in order to decide the extent of the damage can be dangerous, likewise being able to see the subtle telltale markers of interior damage is a skill that takes time and experience to develop. Using drones and robots with 3D scanning lidar, we first recreate the structure in 3D and then use Virtual Reality as both an assessment tool, and to train people in the process of assessment, and the problems to look out for.

items.title: Quality Evaluation (QE) overview
items.summary: The Quality Evaluation is one of the three Performance-Based Research Fund (PBRF) components, and assesses the quality of research at each Tertiary Education Organisation

content.value: The Quality Evaluation Component

Each QE assesses the quality of research conducted at Tertiary Education Organisations. Of the three Performance-Based Research Fund components, the QE has the greatest effect on the University’s revenue and reputation.
With some exceptions, each academic staff member is required to submit an
Evidence Portfolio (EP)

that records their research outputs, contribution to the research environment, and peer esteem. EPs are submitted to TEC by the University. EPs are then assessed by specialist Tertiary Education Commission peer review panels, and each EP is assigned a quality category. Every quality category, with the exception of ‘R’, contributes to the portion of PBRF funding that the University will receive for the next six years.
Why is Quality Evaluation important?

The QE component of the PBRF is a significant source of income for the University of Auckland. The majority of this funding is used to support the costs of research-based teaching at the University, particularly postgraduate teaching and supervision. The remainder is used to fund initiatives that enhance the quality of research and research-informed teaching, including:
The Research Development Fund
University of Auckland Research Committee Awards
Strategic research initiatives
Postgraduate Student Research Support Scheme (PReSS) accounts
Benefits to individual researchers
Excellent PBRF results have a positive impact on academic staff across the University. PBRF benefits individual researchers by:
providing secure funding for the University, which directly supports research-based teaching, improved research environments and doctoral student PReSS account funds
supporting the recruitment of top-quality colleagues and students by strengthening the University’s reputation
enhancing the reputation of individual researchers through peer recognition and review and improved marketability
promoting the importance of research, in turn reinforcing the value of individual researchers’ work and providing research-related career development opportunities
The 2026 QE

In 2020, the Government made the decision to delay the QE by a year due to the impact of COVID-19. As a result, the assessment period for the 2026 QE covers eight years rather than the usual six years.

The Performance-Based Research Fund (PBRF) has undergone a major review since the last QE submission in 2018, and Cabinet’s Economic Development Committee has recently approved some changes to the principles of the PBRF, the definition of research for PBRF purposes, and the mechanisms within the PBRF associated with weightings for certain staff categories and research disciplines.

The TEC has convened a Sector Reference Group (SRG) to operationalise changes to the 2026 Quality Evaluation (QE). As well as considering operational issues flowing from Cabinet's decisions and instructions, the SRG will consider a number of recommendations made by participants in the 2018 QE. The role of the SRG is to develop options, consult, and make recommendations to the TEC for changes to the design of the QE, in line with Cabinet's directions and decisions.

items.title: Backing up research data
items.summary: Regular backups are vital to prevent loss of valuable research data. This article provides some tips and resources to help you prevent data loss.

content.value: Data loss can occur due to several reasons including theft, fire, virus attacks, power outages, natural disasters, software upgrades and human error. Regular backups are important to prevent loss of valuable data.
The following are some tips and resources that you can use to protect your data:
Use a reliable backup solution for your data. Time Machine is specific to OSX, Unix/Linux users can use rsync, Windows users can use software such as EaseUS.
Develop a workflow and schedule for creating regular backups and make sure you test your backup and restore strategy occasionally.
Follow the 3-2-1 rule. Create three copies of your data using at least two different storage media and have at least one copy offsite.
Commercial cloud storage and syncing services such as Dropbox are not sufficient as a backup strategy on their own.
You can store your data on the university network drives which are backed up on tape every night in multiple physical locations.

If you use external hard drives for backing up your data, keep in mind that hard drives have a finite lifetime and can fail suddenly and without warning. Check your hard drives regularly to ensure they are working and data is accessible.
Consider what needs to be backed up. Some intermediate data might be expendable or easily regenerated saving space and time in your backup strategy.
For important files that are changing through time, consider using a version control system in addition to a backup strategy.
If you have complex or difficult research data backup requirements, please arrange a consultation about services and support that might be available to you.

items.title: The 3Rs: Replacement, Refinement, and Reduction
items.summary: Replacement, Refinement and Reduction (the 3Rs) are widely accepted ethical principles designed to minimise the impact on animal welfare while maximising the benefits of the use of animals in research, testing and teaching.

content.value: Replacement, Reduction and Refinement are widely accepted ethical principles to prevent the use of animals if possible, use the fewest number feasible and minimise the negative impact on animal welfare and maximise the positive welfare aspects. This is done while maximising the benefits of animal use in research, testing and teaching.
The 3Rs - Replacement, Refinement and Reduction - were first introduced in 1959 by Russell and Burch in their book
'The principles of humane experimental technique'
Replacement – animals are replaced by
non-living or non-sentient
models where possible.
Reduction – the
number of animals
used is reduced to the minimum required to still get useful results and maximise information gained per animal.
Refinement – the methods used are modified so that the negative impacts on
animal welfare
are minimised and positive welfare maximised.

During the development of your research protocol and the approval process through the Animal Ethics Committee, you are asked to address the 3Rs. The following information is here to help you find the appropriate strategies for your project.
Replacement

There are many research and teaching situations that require live animals to achieve reliable outcomes. Where possible we should move away from working with animals. Great advances have been made moving away from live animal models into such areas as
in vitro
and
in silico
methodologies.

When designing your new research project, you must assess the possibility of using non-sentient or non-living alternatives in the project. This is done by presenting search terms and search engines in the application to help show the AEC that there is no other reliable way to do the work proposed.

Additional information may also be provided if checks are able to be done to ensure that someone isn’t already doing a similar project. Remember that replacement can also be data previously gained, the use of human volunteers and human-oriented epidemiological approaches, etc.
Great resources for the 3Rs, including alternatives to animal experimentation, can be found at;
NC3Rs
NA3RsC
Norecopa
Canadian Council on Animal Care (CCAC)
This is a very useful
step-by-step search guide
by the CCAC to prevent the duplication of research and prevent the use of sentient animals when non-sentient alternatives are available.
Reduction

This section focuses on decreasing the number of animals used for experimentation. A reduction of animals can be achieved by removing confounding research variables, sharing animals, tissue, or data, ensuring you start off with the right number of animals and careful experimental planning. This also helps ensure the maximum amount of information per animal is gained.
There are worldwide discussions concerning the low rate of reproducibility of research, especially animal-based research.  Using pilot studies, the
PREPARE
and
ARRIVE
guidelines and
Experimental Design Assistant
(EDA) can help. There are also many other helpful resources you can access on the
NC3Rs website
Examples of reduction in animal testing
Both sexes should be used.

Using only one sex for a project leaves 50% of offspring to be euthanised if they are not required for other research projects.  In the UK, the MRC now requires both sexes to be included in research design and analysis. There is a helpful webinar you can access for information on this on the
MRC/NC3Rs webinar: Using both sexes in animal experiments webpage
Use enough animals to ensure statistical significance,

but use no more than needed. It is especially important to factor in the number of animals which might not demonstrate the desired phenotype or animals which might not make it to the study endpoint. The number of these supplemental animals will vary greatly between strains, research protocol and duration of the study.
Share animals with other researchers
to

reduce the number of animals used in research. For example, if you need to euthanise 18 month old rats to collect the eyes, you should try to find a researcher who can utilize the rest of the body or try to see if someone is euthanising rats that suit your specific research needs. If you 'scavenge' the bodies of animals which have been euthanised under another Animal Ethics Approval you do not need an Animal Ethics Approval yourself. However please double-check with the Animal Welfare Officer or Animal Ethics Coordinator before using any animals for your research.
Please notify your fellow researchers about your needs or tissues that you might have available with tissue sharing boards or by word of mouth in departments or research groups.
Refinement
Ensure that the impact on the individual animal is as small as possible to answer your research question.
Make sure that the whole life of the animal is as good as possible. Thinking about animal welfare through the
Five Domains vs the Five Freedoms
may be helpful to consider the welfare of a group of animals with a strong focus on mental well-being and positive experiences.
Reduce stress
for your animals by choosing appropriate group compositions and housing sizes as well as using enrichment, positive reinforcement, and strategies for training mice for procedures.
Get to know the animals you work with and use treats and other forms of positive reinforcement, as
this has a great impact on the reduction of stress.

Where the research question allows it, supply treats when handling animals or after procedures. The many physiological and psychological changes that stress causes are difficult to account for as research variables.
Tunnel handling

and other modified handling techniques for mice (e.g., cupping) have been proven to decrease stress. More evidence around tunnel handling is available at NC3Rs and on the Animal Health and Welfare Canvas pages on
Refined Mouse Handling.
Rat tickling
can be an effective way to reduce stress when working with rats. For more information, see the
NA3RSC rodent handling webpage
Provide appropriate anaesthesia and pain relief
before and after manipulations can also improve the animal's life experience and refine the impact of your research.
To find out more about the 3Rs and ways to implement the 3Rs principles in your research, start by visiting these websites:

items.title: Ngapouri Research Farm
items.summary: We are internationally renowned for our sheep-based biomedical, basic, and applied research. Our farm features a surgery, X-ray, indoor pens, and more, all within a purpose-built facility on 50 hectares of pasture and crops.

content.value: The University of Auckland’s Ngapouri Research Farm, near Rotorua in the central North Island, is hosted by the Liggins Institute and renowned for its sheep-based biomedical, basic, and applied research. The farm features extensive facilities, including a surgery, X-ray image intensifier, doppler ultrasound, and tissue collection areas within a purpose-built facility surrounded by 50 hectares of pasture and crops.

Available to UoA researchers and others from New Zealand or overseas, the farm supports an extended breeding season for pregnancy research and longitudinal studies, with on-site maintenance of animals between interventions. Its geothermal rural location makes it ideal for soil ecology, wetland management, geology, climate change, and pest animal management research.

The farm has hosted numerous national and international collaborations, demonstrating the staff's expertise, academic links, and excellent facilities. Led by Dr. Mark Oliver, the on-site team received high commendation in the 2018 University of Auckland Vice-Chancellor’s Excellence Awards for their commitment to health, safety, and wellbeing. Dr. Oliver also won a NAEAC 3 Rs award in 2009 for improving sheep welfare in research.
Visit our
Ngapouri Case Studies
pages to read about our research on maternal and fetal nutrition, hydrocephalus, hearing loss and animal feed development.

items.summary: The Imaging Centre offers diverse technologies, from basic to advanced instruments like electron microscopy, atomic force microscopy, and x-ray crystallography, supporting researchers' needs.

content.value: The Imaging Centre is a core facility enabling researchers to access a diverse range of technologies from basic light microscopes to state-of-the-art automated instruments. Our services and equipment support electron microscopy, atomic force microscopy, light microscopy, histology, x-ray crystallography.

Histology: Paraffin and frozen sections and staining
X-ray Crystallography: Structural characterisation of proteins
Data Analysis Software: Packages for all techniques

items.title: Nuclear Magnetic Resonance Centre
items.summary: The University of Auckland's Nuclear Magnetic Resonance Centre provides access to both solid-state and solution-state NMR instrumentation.

content.value: Nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy is one of the main techniques used to obtain physical, chemical, electronic and structural information about molecules. The University of Auckland's NMR centre provides access to both solid-state and solution-state NMR instrumentation.

items.title: Health Data Platform
items.summary: The Health Data Platform, a University of Auckland initiative, offers secure access to linked national health data (e.g., hospitalizations, mortality, medication dispensing).

content.value: The Health Data Platform is a University of Auckland service providing secure access to linked routinely collected national health data (e.g. hospitalisations, mortality, medication dispensing) in a format that is ready for analysis for research or teaching projects with ethics approval.  The service is operated by the Schools of Medicine and Population Health in the Faculty of Medical and Health Sciences. Our services are available for University of Auckland (or affiliated) staff and students.
Our principles are:
Excellence in data science and health research
Ethical and safe practice
Efficient re-use of health data
Our Health Data Platform is suitable for:
University of Auckland (or affiliated) staff and students
Research and teaching activities with ethics approval
Projects requiring routinely collected health data collated and managed within the
National Collections by Te Whatu Ora
(e.g. hospitalisations (NMDS), mortality, medication dispensing)
Instruments, services and training
Services
Extracting and linking data to generate relevant cohorts and variables for a user’s project
Developing and maintaining clinically validated definitions of core variables for re-use across projects
Identifying relevant history or outcomes for clinical studies (e.g. from a trial, survey, registry) by linking with routinely collected health data
Be part of the Beta test
Would you like to be part of our beta phase?

We are still developing our digital interface, but if you are already interested in using our service during this phase, please send a 1-page summary (2 pages max) of the project or projects you are doing with a variable list and linkage requirements to
healthdata@auckland.ac.nz
. We will acknowledge your contribution to our Beta phase on our website’s news section.
If you would like to submit a proposal please include:
Study objectives
Study design (trial, observational, other)

Timeframe - of participant recruitment, and of the linked information on history and/or outcomes that are needed. eg. Readmission for problems x, y, z at least one year after the end of study recruitment.
Whether you have ethics permission to link to national data
If it is research still in the process of planning please provide a sketch of your thinking as well.
Accessing our services
If you are interested in using our service, please fill in the project proposal form or contact us on
healthdata@auckland.ac.nz

The BIRU has a range of instruments that support widefield, confocal, light sheet and super-resolution microscopy. Our flow cytometry lab provides access to analysers as well as standard fluorescence and spectral cell sorting technologies.

items.title: Auckland Genomics
items.summary: Auckland Genomics provide comprehensive DNA/RNA sequencing services, project planning, training, consultation, workshops, data delivery, basic bioinformatics, and advanced equipment access for global researchers.

content.value: We offer a wide range of NextGen DNA/RNA sequencing (NGS), Sanger sequencing and gene expression services for New Zealand and international researchers. We provide expertise in planning and completing projects involving all types of DNA/RNA sequencing, microarrays and nucleic acid analysis. We also offer bespoke training, consultation on experimental design and analysis, and workshops, data delivery and basic bioinformatics support, and access to a range of advanced equipment.

Metagenomic sequencing using short and/or long reads.

Plasmid and amplicon sequencing.
Gene Expression Microarrays.
Sanger DNA Sequencing, DNA Fragment Analysis and Genotyping using capillary electrophoresis.
Consultation, collaboration, experimental design, some data analysis.

items.title: The research is clear, why aren't things changing?
items.summary: Ceridwyn Roberts, science communicator and Fellow of the Office of the Prime Minister's Chief Science Advisor, will join us to look at how mission-led science communication and engagement goes beyond simply explaining research. (Scheduled 16 Oct, 2024).

content.value: There is a common belief that if someone truly understands scientific findings and the consequent impact on humanity, they will immediately change their behaviour. Unfortunately, this is rarely the case. When science is "mission-led" or a collaborative, transdisciplinary, multi-organisational approach to solving ‘big picture’ problems, how do we go about creating impact? This webinar will look at mission-led science communication and engagement and how it goes beyond explaining research, instead aiming to help people respond to science with meaningful action. Using her recent report for the Prime Minister's Chief Science Advisor as a starting point, Ceridwyn will explore best practice of the communication and engagement involved in mission-led science across the Aotearoa New Zealand science system.
The webinar will be held via Zoom and will include a Q&A session. Register now to reserve your spot in the audience, and to receive the link to the webinar recording afterward.

Designing research posters

items.title: Data carpentry
items.summary: Online workshop providing introductory skills to organise, clean, and analyse tabular data designed for research students and researchers with no prior experience.

content.value: Please join the Centre for eResearch
mailing list
to be notified of other upcoming digital research skills events.
Data Carpentry
teaches core skills for working with data in an effective and reproducible way. Applications are open to all University staff and postgraduate students.

Workshops are two-to-three day (in-person) or four-to-five half-day (online) hands-on workshops that cover handling data through the whole data lifecycle from collecting through cleaning to analysis and visualisation. Participants are encouraged to help one another and to apply what they have learned to their own research problems.
There are a number of certified Carpentry Instructors at the University of Auckland who run workshops throughout the year, sometimes in partnership with
or as part of

Lessons are provided with an astronomy, ecology, genomics, social sciences or geospatial flavour, depending on the dataset carried through the workshop. Although each flavour has domain-specific applications, the ecology and social sciences lessons both contain broadly transferable skills for working with tabular data.
By the end of this workshop, participants will be able to:
Keeping spreadsheets tidy
Explain the benefits of applying Tidy Data principles to research projects and data.
Identify common formatting issues using features within spreadsheet software.
Solve problems posed by dates and automatic data validation.
Apply Tidy Data principles to prepare transparent and reproducible research data.
Data Cleaning with OpenRefine
Explain the benefits of using OpenRefine to clean and format datasets.
Use the transform, filter, and sort data features to work with datasets.
Validate data by looking up terms from an external database or trusted source.
Export, save, and reuse data cleaning steps on another dataset.
Data Analysis and Visualisation with R
Explain the advantages of programming languages for analysing research data.
Build and modify plots to visualise tabular data.
Explore tabular datasets using vectors, data frames, and functions.
Import, manipulate, and export datasets and figures.
All the Data Carpentry lesson materials are freely available online and reusable under a Creative Commons Attribution license.

Workshop participants need to bring a Mac, Linux, or Windows computer or laptop (not a tablet, Chromebook, etc.) with some software packages installed. The setup instructions are available on the Data Carpentry web pages and are provided to workshop participants beforehand. Participants are also required to abide by The Carpentry's
Code of Conduct
Learners wishing to engage with Data Carpentry workshops are encouraged to come to
HackyHour
to meet others and join the community at the University of Auckland.
is a similar workshop that focuses more on general research programming skills, rather than domain-specific data wrangling and analysis skills.

We offer practical advice and link to University services and support to enable researchers to align their practices with policy, while navigating complex issues such as ethics, sovereignty, security, and sharing data.

items.summary: Networking events organised for researchers by central and faculty based research services teams

content.value: The Research and Innovation Office (RIO)

, faculty based FIRST teams, as well as early career researcher committees organise cross-department and cross-faculty collaboration events to encourage networking, new collaborations, and research planning and ideation.

These types of events are for early career researchers, researchers new to NZ, or researchers new to a specific funder. They are also for established researchers looking to add an interdisciplinary or multi-disciplinary element to their research. 

Check the Researcher Development calendar for upcoming cross-faculty collaboration events or reach out to RIO, your local faculty FIRST team, or early career researcher committee or society if you'd like to participate or help organise an event.

items.title: Making sense of the Treaty in a Research Context (Part 1)
items.summary: Do you want to build your knowledge in Responsiveness to Māori within your research?

content.value: Do you want to build your knowledge in Responsiveness to Māori in your research? This webinar will provide a general overview of the Treaty of Waitangi as it relates to research. The content focuses on why it was written, what it says, what went wrong and where we are today.
The seminar is a good fit for you if:
1. Have a general understanding of the Treaty of Waitangi. Those without any experience of study of the Treaty of Waitangi should consult resources before attending. Consult resources:
https://teara.govt.nz/en/te-tiriti-o-waitangi-the-treaty-of-waitangi
2. Are encountering the relationship between the Treaty and doing research for the first time, whether you are new to New Zealand or not.
3. You would like a refresher of Treaty foundations and how it relates to research.

Join us for this informative session presented by Christine Herzog who has facilitated more than a thousand Treaty and related workshops, for central and local government departments and other large institutions, for community groups, and for the general public. She has also undertaken consultancy and research relating to application of the Treaty in organisations. She was a founding member of Auckland Project Waitangi and continues to be active in Tamaki Treaty Workers. Christine supported Ngāti Tamaoho Trust, a Waiohua hapu, through eight years of their Treaty claims negotiations and is now kaiwhakahaere of Te Tai-awa o te Ora Trust, a kaupapa Māori social services organisation based in south Auckland. For any questions, please contact: researcherdevelopment@auckland.ac.nz

items.title: Putting the Treaty into Practice in a Research context (Part 2)
items.summary: Explore the application of the main Treaty concepts (voluntary, mutually beneficial decision-making relationships) to the major stages of research (choosing the topic, literature review, research design, collecting information, analysis and dissemination).

content.value: Do you want to go more in depth with your knowledge of Responsiveness to Māori within your research? This webinar explores the application of the main Treaty concepts (voluntary, mutually beneficial decision-making relationships) to the major stages of research (choosing the topic, literature review, research design, collecting information, analysis, and dissemination).
This seminar is right for you if:
1) You have attended Making Sense of the Treaty of Waitangi in a Research Context - Part 1 (recommended but not obligatory).
2) You have confidence in the foundations of your Treaty knowledge as it applies to research, and eager to deepen your understanding and how to apply it.

Join us for this informative session presented by Christine Herzog who has facilitated more than a thousand Treaty and related workshops, for central and local government departments and other large institutions, for community groups, and for the general public. She has also undertaken consultancy and research relating to application of the Treaty in organisations. She was a founding member of Auckland Project Waitangi and continues to be active in Tamaki Treaty Workers. Christine supported Ngāti Tamaoho Trust, a Waiohua hapu, through eight years of their Treaty claims negotiations and is now kaiwhakahaere of Te Tai-awa o te Ora Trust, a kaupapa Māori social services organisation based in south Auckland.
For any questions, please contact: researcherdevelopment@auckland.ac.nz

items.title: Introductory Good Clinical Practice (GCP) training day
items.summary: Training to support researchers meet the GCP training requirements under the National Ethics Advisory Committee (NEAC) Standards for Health and Disability Research and Quality Improvement (2019) and the University’s Human Health Research Risk Framework.

content.value: GCP training is a requirement

If you are a University staff or student directly involved in the conduct, oversight, or management of clinical trials you are required to undertake GCP training prior to the commencement of such activity and maintain competency through refresher GCP training every three years.  Refer to the
Human Health Research Risk Management framework
for more information.
University GCP training meets ICH GCP training requirements
The University has partnered with
Green Lane Coordinating Centre
to develop its own Introductory GCP Training.   This training meets the minimum requirements for
International Council for Harmonisation
(ICH) GCP Investigator Site Personnel Training identified by TransCelerate Biopharma as necessary to enable mutual accreditation of GCP training among trial sponsors.
Upon training completion, staff and students will receive a
certificate of completion
GCP training topic areas
The training is delivered as a 6-hour face-to-face seminar covering:
History of Clinical Research
Clinical Trial Overview
Ethics Committees Overview
Informed Consent Regulations & Standards
Regulatory Documentation Requirements
Source Records and Document Systems.

Professor Natalie Walker,
School of Population Health

items.title: Supervision: Masters and small research projects
items.summary: An overview of supervising students undertaking small research projects.

content.value: Supervising masters by research or small honours projects can be difficult because it is time-bound and writing needs to be managed along with the project. In this seminar, experienced academics respond to prompts about their strategies, and there is the opportunity to ask questions.
