Supervision
This workshop is organised by the
School of Graduate Studies

items.title: Orientation to Doctoral Education Policy and Process (ORIDOC)
items.summary: An introduction to the policy and process governing the supervision and examination of doctoral candidates at the University of Auckland.

content.value: Prior to supervising postgraduate students, staff (employed after 1 February 2001) must attend Orientation to Doctoral Education Policy and Process (ORIDOC). This is a two-hour introduction to the policy and process environment governing the supervision and the examination of doctoral candidates at the University of Auckland.

During the ORIDOC seminar, the Dean of Graduate Studies takes you through the University of Auckland’s expectations, emphasising what is significant and answering your questions. ORIDOC is crucial for supervisory practice and mandatory for those new to supervision, with recommendation that all supervisors refresh their institutional knowledge every five years.
Participants will receive access to resources and key policy documents.
Find out more about supervision accreditation, training and resources at
Supervision
This workshop is organised by the
School of Graduate Studies

items.title: Supporting student mental health and wellbeing
items.summary: Find out how to support student mental health and wellbeing in this interactive discussion with neuroscientist and psychologist Dr Desiree Dickerson

content.value:
As supervisors it’s our job to ensure that the candidates we support have the proper guidance and help when they need it.

Dr Desiree Dickerson will discuss ideas to keep in mind:
What we mean by mental health, including knowing the warning signs
How you can help candidates, including how to check in when something is wrong
Helping candidates to thrive, including the power of feedback and the importance of belonging
You will learn about tools and techniques to support candidates. Upon completion, you will receive a guide outlining the key topics and strategies.
Find out about supervision training, accreditation and resources at
Supervision
This workshop is organised by the
School of Graduate Studies

items.title: Introduction to Python
items.summary: Online workshop providing an introduction to the Python programming language designed for research students and researchers with no prior research computing experience.

content.value: Applications for Introduction to Python, 2-3 September, are now closed. Sign up to the Centre for eResearch mailing list for updates on upcoming workshops.

Python is a general purpose programming language that can be used to perform a wide range of tasks. Python is routinely used by the research community for data science, machine learning, building websites, scraping data from the web, interfacing with microcontrollers, and automating tasks.
This introductory Python workshop teaches hands-on programming skills. Participants are encouraged to help one another and to apply what they have learned to their own research problems.
Current workshop content includes:
Python Fundamentals
Summarising and plotting tabular data
Repeating Actions with Loops
Creating Functions
Defensive Programming
The lesson is freely
available online
and reusable under a Creative Commons Attribution license.
Workshop participants need to bring a Mac, Linux, or Windows laptop (not a tablet, Chromebook, etc.). Further instructions will be provided as part of the workshop.
Participants wishing to engage with other learners are encouraged to come to
HackyHour
to join the University of Auckland community.

items.title: Doctoral Morning Tea
items.summary: Meet your peers, make connections and learn from those who have come before you in these social sessions for PhD and named doctorate candidates.

content.value: The Doctoral Morning Tea is an opportunity for doctoral candidates from across the University to connect with one another, develop their networks and develop new insights into key doctoral topics.
Sessions may be held in-person or online, and may feature a panel of current students discussing their experiences or an external speaker sharing their knowledge. Past topics include:
Making the most of your doctorate
Cross-cultural communication
International candidate life
Research storytelling for quick pitches
Proactive career management
Find out what's coming up at
Doctoral Morning Tea

items.title: Introduction to machine learning
items.summary: Online workshop providing an introduction to machine learning using python designed for postgraduate research students and researchers with no prior machine learning experience.

content.value: Applications for Introduction to Machine Learning (29 October - 1 November) are now open.

Machine learning is a set of computational methods used to find patterns in data, often with the goal of prediction or classification. For example, machine learning can be used to predict the cost of something given certain economic conditions, or to classify images into different groups based on their content.

This hands-on workshop takes place over four half-days and provides an introduction to common methods and terminologies in machine learning research, and the first steps in applying deep learning to a dataset. Participants are expected to have basic familiarity with the Python programming language (to a level provided by
This workshop packages two community-developed lessons hosted by The Carpentries:
Introduction to Machine Learning with Scikit Learn
Introduction to deep-learning

Workshop participants need to bring a laptop with a Mac, Linux, or Windows operating system (not a tablet, Chromebook, etc.) with some software packages installed. Setup instructions will be provided to workshop participants beforehand.
Learners wishing to engage with these lessons and training are encouraged to join the
HackyHour
community to get advice and meet other people at the University of Auckland working with data and code.

items.title: Shut up and write!
items.summary: A online and in-person events providing researchers a regular time and space to do some writing in a social environment. Using the Pomodoro technique (25-minute writing sprints with short coffee/social breaks in between) to help you focus your writing.

content.value: Shut up and write! sessions use the Pomodoro technique (25-minute writing sprints with short coffee/social breaks in between) to help you focus your writing, overcome procrastination and build good writing habits. These sessions are particularly useful for all those difficult tasks you’ve been putting off. You decide what you’ll work on during the session. It could be a publication, abstract, part of your thesis, some data analysis or anything else that’s going to help you complete your thesis or communication your research.
Learn more about
Shut up and write!
and the
Pomodoro technique
Resources:
Pomodoro timer online

items.title: Qualitative research methods course
items.summary: This is an in-person course providing practical experience in the appraisal and use of qualitative research methods in research, including design, conduct, analysis and interpretation.

content.value: Course overview

In this course we aim to develop practical experience in the appraisal and use of qualitative research methods; the intent is for you to develop the skills to be a 'critical consumer' and a 'rigorous producer' of qualitative research. We develop a holistic understanding of qualitative research, including rigour, ethics, research questions, and the design, conduct, analysis and interpretation of research studies, as well as issues around (and creative approaches to) disseminating research.

We will explore a variety of methodological approaches which fall under the 'qualitative research' umbrella. Students are required to write weekly synopses of specified readings and prepare an annotated bibliography examining the use of a specific methodological approach in qualitative health research. There is a strong emphasis in these on developing your critical reading and reflective writing skills.

The course includes a lot of peer feedback and incremental learning (for example, presentations on your annotated bibliography topic to small groups of peers, peer feedback on a draft, and opportunities to revise earlier work).
Workload expectations
Students are expected to spend a minimum of 10 hours per week involved in the study, this includes;
For this course, you can expect 5x 5-hour blocks of lectures.
At least 2 hours of reading per week and thinking about the content.
At least 5 hours per week of work on assignments.
Fees
Course fees are the responsibility of the individual. For more information on how the University can support you with fee payment please see the
study and learning page on the staff intranet.
Enrolment
Research staff
wanting to enrol in this course will have an undergraduate degree and permission from the course director.
For further programme advice please contact
fmhs@auckland.ac.nz
PhD students
wanting to enrol
should reach out to the School of Graduate Studies who can advise on how to apply for and enrol in the course.
For further guidance please contact
doctoraladvice@auckland.ac.nz
How to apply
To apply, please go to the
apply now University of Auckland page
and select
"Start your application for admission".
Application instructions
If this is your first time using the application portal you will be asked to input some personal details and education history.
Under "Which programme are you applying for?" select
Certificate.
Under programme select
Certificate of Proficiency.
Under Major/ specialisation select
Medical and Health Sciences.
You will then need to select the start term,
Semester one.
Under intended courses select
Population health.
Under the course, title search and select
POPLHLTH 704 - Undertaking Qualitative Health Research.
If you experience any difficulties in accessing the Application for Admission system, or in completing or submitting your doctoral application, contact our
Support Team
or contact
fmhs@auckland.ac.nz
For more information on other courses available at the University of Auckland please see the
Course Outlines website.

items.title: Piki Ake: Preparing Māori doctoral and masters students for an academic career
items.summary: The Piki Ake transition programme prepares Māori doctoral and masters students for an academic career pathway.

content.value: The Piki Ake transition programme seeks to redesign the trajectory for Māori researchers across New Zealand’s eight universities. The programme is designed to prepare and support Māori postgraduate students interested in an academic career within Aotearoa New Zealand universities.

Students will begin to  build a research toolkit, explore effective teaching pedagogy, begin to build  a service portfolio, and explore support networks. The programme is delivered online, with six self-directed learning modules and two online blended wānanga components.
Learn more and explore eligibility requirements at
Piki Ake
If you'd like to take part,
express your interest

items.title: Online ethics training modules
items.summary: It is recommended that you complete these modules prior to creating your human ethics application to gain a thorough understanding of the ethical issues related to research involving human participants.

content.value: Four of the modules listed below have a quiz component that automatically generates a certificate of completion when 80% or more correct answers have been provided to aid self-learning. The certificate will be emailed to the individual undertaking the modules.
Available modules:
Introduction to Human ethics
How to write an ethics application
Anonymity and Confidentiality
Conflict of Interest
Consent
Methodologies - covers interviews, focus groups, questionnaires, use of VR/AG
Māori and Indigenous Cultures
Research involving social media platforms – including online recruitment
Research involving database repositories
Research involving creative practice
If there are any elements of the modules you are having difficulty with and would like to discuss in more detail, feel free to request a meeting with an ethics adviser via
humanethics@auckland.ac.nz

items.title: Research ethics training video
items.summary: A training video is provided which discusses research ethics principles, ethics application pathway and navigation of the Infonetica Ethics RM platform for submitting a human ethics application

content.value: The Ethics and Integrity Team invites researchers who plan to apply for human ethics approval to watch a training video that covers the following topics:
The history of ethics
The key ethical principles that guide research involving human participants
What the committee looks for in an ethics application
The steps and requirements for creating and submitting an ethics application using the Infonetica Ethics RM platform
Who is the online training session for?
The training session is for all students and academics who intend to submit a human ethics application.
Please see the
research ethics training video available on Stream to view the video

items.title: Introduction to the command line
items.summary: An online introductory workshop to navigating a filesystem and automating repetitive tasks using the command line.

content.value: Introduction to the command line (Thursday 19 September, 10am-3pm) is open for applications now. Places are limited.
The command line can be used by researchers to:
Navigate files and directories in a faster and more efficient way.
Perform an action or set of actions on a large number of files at once.
Chain commands together into complex workflows that can be saved and rerun on sets of files.
Access and use high performance computing services such as those provided by
More efficiently use virtual machines.
The command line (sometimes referred to as the
shell
Unix shell,
terminal,
or
bash

) provides an interactive programming interface on Linux, Mac and Windows operating systems, and is a different approach to that offered by a GUI (Graphical User Interface). Use of the command line is fundamental to a wide range of research computing processes.

This workshop is delivered online over approximately 5 hours (including a 45 minute break in the middle) by experienced staff and students from the University of Auckland, University of Otago, and University of Canterbury. The curriculum is provided online
here

items.summary: This interactive workshop will help you develop the comprehensive literature searching skills required for systematic-type reviews. The next workshop in November is online.

content.value: Looking to master literature searches for research synthesis?

This 2 hour online workshop from Te Tumu Herenga | Libraries and Learning Services is ideal for anyone involved in evidence synthesis, from beginners to those seeking to enhance their search skills. Join us to confidently design and execute literature searches that meet the highest standards of systematic reviews.
This workshop will help you:
Develop effective search strategies for systematic reviews.
Identify and use relevant databases and sources.
Manage and refine your search results efficiently.

items.title: School of Graduate Studies Research Showcase
items.summary: A celebration of the breadth and depth of the University’s postgraduate research.

content.value: The School of Graduate Studies (SGS) Research Showcase brings together doctoral candidates from across the University and celebrates their research.
The event encourages our doctoral researchers to creatively communicate their research and its impact to a broad audience.
Participants can submit entries to one (or both) of the categories:

In addition to the possibility of winning prestige and prizes, the SGS Research Showcase is a unique opportunity for doctoral researchers to:

items.title: Three Minute Thesis (3MT) competition
items.summary: Could you present your 80,000-word PhD thesis in less than 180 seconds? The 3MT competition is an unmissable opportunity to refine your research elevator pitch, enhance your presentation skills and drive the impact of your research.

content.value: The Three Minute Thesis (3MT) is an academic research communication competition developed by The University of Queensland (UQ), Australia. It is an exciting, fast-paced event that is held annually in more than 900 universities in 85 countries. In a 3MT competition, doctoral candidates take up the challenge of sharing the story of their research with a general audience in under three minutes, supported by nothing more than a single, static slide.

Entries for the next University of Auckland 3MT competition will open in early 2025 for all currently enrolled doctoral candidates. We invite you to get involved to build your skills, confidence and connections across the research community. To watch recordings of previous winners and find out more about heat dates, how to register, how to prepare and how the competition works, visit
https://www.auckland.ac.nz/3mt

items.title: How are policy decisions made?
items.summary: Sir Ashley Bloomfield, Professor at the University of Auckland's School of Population Health, joined us for the inaugural Research Impact for Public Good webinar to discuss how policy decisions are made. (Recorded 24 July, 2024).

content.value: S
ir Ashley Bloomfield joined us on 24 July 2024 for our first
Research Impact for Public Good
webinar, where he

shared insights on policy making from his 25 years of public sector experience, discussing how publicly funded research should benefit the public and how this often occurs through influencing--directly or indirectly--political and policy decisions.

items.title: Research impact consultation sessions
items.summary: Te Tari Rautaki Rangahau, Matatika (Office of Research Strategy and Integrity) offers in-person and online research impact sessions for individuals and larger groups.

content.value: Te Tari Rautaki Rangahau, Matatika (Office of Research Strategy and Integrity)

offers individual research impact consultations and larger group training sessions to plan for research impact through the Research Impact Team. Tell us your requirements, audience, and any specific questions, and we will get back to you to organise a session.

items.title: Unlocking the challenge of writing audience-focused evidence-based impact narratives webinar
items.summary: Webinar recording discussing best practice in writing audience-focused evidence-based impact narratives. (Recorded, 31st October 2023).

content.value: Dr. Giovanna de Moura Rocha Lima discussed the
Researcher Impact Framework

, a tool designed to support researchers in identifying, recognising, and valuing the multiple activities of their scholarly life. In it, scholarly activities and their outputs are aligned to their potential relevant societal outcomes and impact areas, tied to potential impact indicators to be used by researchers, all underpinned by values.

items.title: Kai and Kōrero at the Library
items.summary: A postgraduate reception hosted by Te Tumu Herenga | Libraries and Learning Services.

content.value:
At Te Tumu Herenga | Libraries and Learning Services, we believe in fostering a supportive and engaging community for our postgraduate students.
That's why we're excited to invite you to our special event, “Kai and Korero at the Library.”
What to expect:
Great food:
Enjoy a delightful spread of refreshments and light bites.
Unstructured conversation:
Engage in relaxed, open dialogue with fellow postgraduates.
Share your experiences:
Bring your thoughts about your student journey so far and share your valuable experiences.
Help us help you:
Share your insights on how we can better support you in your academic career.
Connect and network:
Build connections with peers who share your academic journey.
This is a wonderful opportunity to unwind, connect with your fellow students, and contribute to shaping the future of support and resources available to you.
To ensure that we have an accurate headcount for catering purposes, we request you to kindly register your attendance by using the Eventbrite registration.

items.title: Research Bazaar (ResBaz)
items.summary: A week-long online series of digital research skills workshops designed for researchers and research students across Aotearoa.

content.value: What is ResBaz (Research Bazaar)?
ResBaz Aotearoa is a free, online event offering 45+ digital research skills workshops

designed to upskill and build connections across the research community. The workshops are diverse—everything from programming in Python to designing better posters—and participants are free to pick the workshops they’re interested in. In 2023, over 1,400 individuals made over 5000 session registrations for the 45+ workshops on offer.
Who is ResBaz for?
Everyone in the Aotearoa research community is invited, including:
academic/researcher staff
research students
those in research support roles.
Who hosts ResBaz?
The University of Auckland has hosted an annual ResBaz since 2016, moving to an online, national-level format in 2020.

ResBaz Aotearoa is delivered in collaboration between the University of Auckland, Victoria University of Wellington, University of Otago, University of Canterbury, Plant & Food Research, and the MBIE-funded Beyond Prediction programme.

Workshops are designed for the Aotearoa New Zealand research community and are delivered by academic and professional staff from universities and Crown Research Institutes, postgraduate students, and other volunteers.

items.title: NVivo Core Skills
items.summary: This introductory course will provide an overview of the software, and teach the basics of setting-up and working in an NVivo project.

content.value: is data analysis software designed for researchers working with qualitative information, such as interviews, documents, survey data and webpages.

This ‘NVivo Core Skills’ course covers the basics of NVivo, and is ideal for those who are new to the software. We’ll cover NVivo from start to finish, walking you though how to set up a project and work with data (including a variety of coding techniques).
More advanced features such as queries, reporting and visualizations will also be briefly introduced.
Key content:
Navigating around the NVivo interface
Setting up and working with NVivo projects, including saving and backing up
Preparing, importing, and working with data (specifically PDFs and Word documents)
Coding data in NVivo, and choosing a coding technique that is fit for purpose
Using memos as a way of recording important project related information
Creating folders and utilising them to tailor the scope of queries
Performing keyword searches and understanding how these apply to the data analysis process
Using reporting tools to extract key data and other project related information.

items.title: Mastering the art of impact communication: a step-by-step approach webinar
items.summary: Webinar recording for individuals and organisations looking to enhance their understanding and skills around articulating impact, both prospectively and retrospectively (Recorded, 15th August 2023).

content.value: Dr. Tamika Heiden,

Founder of the Research Impact Academy, discussed powerful strategies and tools for successfully conveying impact stories, and shared how to harness the power of language, navigate the nuanced world of indicators and evidence, and structure communication to create compelling narratives that resonate with audiences.
Click to view the webinar recording

items.title: Research to Innovation Hatchery Programme
items.summary: A 12-week programme designed to amplify your impact by exploring the tangible potential of your work if it's unleashed through commercialisation.

content.value: Applications for the second 2024 cohort (August-November) are now open.  Aplications close August 4th.

Imagine transforming your research into a force that drives real-world change. The Research to Innovation Hatchery is designed to amplify your impact by exploring the tangible potential of your work if it’s unleashed through commercialisation. This programme will equip you with essential knowledge, skills, and capabilities in knowledge mobilisation and entrepreneurship, propelling your research to new heights.

Explore how you might empower your research to contribute to the world’s environmental, social, and economic prosperity through entrepreneurship. By participating in the Research to Innovation Hatchery, you’ll learn how to turn your research into actionable, impactful solutions through commercialisation. Open doors to new opportunities for your future projects and career.
Make a lasting difference with your research. Join the Research to Innovation Hatchery and become a catalyst for change.

items.title: Writing a data management plan workshop
items.summary: In-person/online workshop guiding a research group through the process of creating a data management plan.

content.value: If you want to create a data management plan (DMP) and do not know where to start or what to include, the Centre for eResearch offers a tailored DMP workshop for research groups. In the session, we go through the various components of the University's DMP, offer best practice examples and section-by-section advice for creating your initial DMP. Once created, you can add to and edit your DMP, often with input from your collaborators or supervisor, as you progress through your research data lifecycle.
Resources

items.title: Workshop: Pathways to Open Access @ UoA
items.summary: This workshop teaches researchers how to make their work Open Access (OA) and what University support is available. It also covers the University's OA Policy and how to comply, as well as the basics of copyright and Creative Commons licensing.

content.value: This workshop is for researchers who have prior knowledge and experience with the academic publishing process. If you are new to publishing (e.g. PhD students and early career researchers), we recommend you attend the
before attending this workshop.
This workshop will help you:
Understand why Open Access (OA) is important & relevant to you as a researcher at this University
Navigate the available pathways to OA & related funding/support opportunities that are available at this University
This workshop addresses the following topics:
What is OA?
Why should I make my work OA?
Benefits to authors & institutions
Policy & funder requirements
How do I make my work OA?
Open Access publishing agreements
Open Access Support Fund
Green OA
Ethical questions and concerns about the different OA routes
Basics of copyright & Creative Commons licensing
Watch the
workshop recording
(SSO required)

items.title: Introduction to high performance computing
items.summary: A short introduction to the basics of using the national High Performance Computing resources, run by NeSI.

content.value: NeSI hosts a
weekly “Introduction to Computing on the NeSI Platforms” session

for researchers new to NeSI (or existing users who would like a refresh). They are also open to anyone interested in learning more about High Performance Computing (HPC) using NeSI, prior to getting a NeSI account.
These information sessions aim to help you get started on the systems and are typically two hours long. At these sessions, we give an overview of:
NeSI systems and the HPC platforms' capabilities
the available software and environment modules
some best practice tips for using the platforms
common commands for submitting, scheduling, and optimising your jobs on the system

These sessions are offered free of charge and hosted online at 1:00 pm on Wednesdays (except public or University holidays). Participants must book in advance to attend. To receive the Zoom video conference link for these sessions, please
contact NeSI Support

items.title: Service Essentials virtual walking tour
items.summary: Get your walking shoes on and join teams across the University as they host a tour of the content on their visual management boards.

content.value: This tour showcases visual management boards from teams across the University. You will gain ideas about how your team can incorporate improvements to the customer experience into everyday work.

This tour welcomes all staff, regardless of job title. It is suitable for teams who are already using Service Essentials, or those considering Services Essentials for the first time - whether in a virtual or physical setting.
Teams are using Service Essentials to manage and improve service and operational effectiveness, displaying improved:
Visibility over workflow and progress toward operational and strategic objectives
Collaboration and engagement with their teams
Attendees are encouraged to ask questions and engage in the conversation with hosts.

items.title: Medtech-iQ Tāmaki Makaurau networking events
items.summary: Find events that bring together the local MedTech ecosystem as an opportunity to network, share our knowledge, and build the community here in Tāmaki Makaurau.

content.value: Medtech-iQ Tāmaki Makaurau hosts regular networking events to bring together our local ecosystem and to hear from some of our key industry players. These events are open to everyone - researchers, clinicians, industry, start-up enablers and more.

items.title: Open Access Week events 2023
items.summary: Check out the recordings from Open Access Week 2023! Events included short lunchtime kōrero sessions on predatory publishing, open research, Diamond OA and Mātauranga Māori, and in-depth panels with global experts hosted by Open Access Australasia.

content.value: It's that time of the year when Open Access enthusiasts and experts come together to share their experiences, address your queries, and help pave your path toward embracing openness in research. On October 24th, we kick off International Open Access Week. The theme this year is Community over Commercialization.
Lunchtime Kōrero Sessions: 24-26 October, 12-12:45pm NZDT

We warmly invite you to join our series of concise talks organised by the dedicated Open Access team at Waipapa Taumata Rau. These sessions promise to offer valuable insights, broaden your horizons, and perhaps challenge some common misconceptions about Open Access. Click on the sessions below for session details and registration.
These short talks complement a wider
series of events
organised by Open Access Australasia - see below for details.
Open Access Workshop: Tuesday, 24 October, 1-2pm NZDT
We also invite you to attend the Library’s new online

. This session is great for all staff and early career researchers who would like to know more how to make research open, as well as the various Open Access financial support options available through University.
Register here
Open Access Panel Discussions - Open Access Australasia
Questions?
If you have any questions regarding these sessions, or wider questions regarding Open Access, please get in touch with the Library via
Ask Us

items.title: Online training for Faculty Ethics Advisers
items.summary: Training modules for faculty-based Ethics Advisers who assist researchers manage ethical requirements which arise from their research involving human participants.

content.value: The role of a Faculty Ethics Adviser is meant to be assisting researchers to identify and work out how to manage ethical requirements and issues which may arise for their research. Such assistance is based on the understanding the Ethics Adviser has of both ethical requirements of research and the nature of research and research methods in the disciplines in their faculty.

The online training modules provide an introduction to the ethics committees, what research requires ethics approval, the work that should be done before an application is made, the provision of ethical advice, the application process, and privacy law (especially in relation to the Privacy Act 2020).

items.title: Introduction to research impact (RSD001)
items.summary: This new online module covers the basics of research impact, including how to plan for research impact and developing an implementation plan.

content.value: This short course has been developed by
Te Tari Rautaki Rangahau, Matatika (Office of Research Strategy and Integrity)

, to cover the foundations of research impact and developing a plan for research impact. The content is appropriate for all researchers, both those new to research impact and those wishing to refresh their skills or meet funding round requirements.
After completing this course you should be able to:
Understand what research impact is and the importance of planning to maximise impact
Describe the result-chain framework and be familiar with the research impact terminology
Identify a research need and define the potential impact of your research
Identify potential stakeholders of your research
Describe the purpose of engaging with each of your stakeholders
Construct an implementation plan for your research

items.title: Co-designing stakeholder hui and other engagement methodologies

offers support including advice on co-designing stakeholder hui and other engagement methodologies through the Research Impact Team. Tell us your requirements, audience, and any specific questions, and we will get back to you to organise a session.

items.title: "Fast track your impact" seminar
items.summary: A recorded session held by international expert in research impact (Prof Mark Reed) on practical research impact tools.

items.title: "Has the tide turned towards responsible metrics in research?" seminar
items.summary: A recorded session held by international expert in research impact (Prof James Wilsdon) on the opportunities and problems of research metrics.

items.title: Workshop: Raising your research profile
items.summary: This workshop gives an overview of the different types of researcher profiles and social media platforms. We'll discuss ways to determine which of these will help build your professional profile, promote your research and achieve your career goals.

content.value: Trying to work that academic hustle, but don’t know how to get your name out there?
Wondering about the best way to promote your research or track your publications?

In this workshop, we’ll discuss the reasons why research profiles are important, look at the different types of profiles and their purposes, and brainstorm some strategies to help you manage your online identities. This will help doctoral candidates and early career researchers (ECRs) set the stage for their future research career.

items.title: Academic Career Advancement Programme
items.summary: The Academic Career Advancement Programme (ACAP) gives mid-phase doctoral candidates a head start in their academic future.

content.value: The ACAP (formerly DALI) involves a series of regular seminars over two semesters, with a focus on careers in academia, teaching, and research.

Candidates are subject to a competitive selection process where priority is given to mid-phase doctoral students who have completed their provisional goals, though, due to the high proportion of applications, meeting this criteria does not guarantee you a place.

Tuition is funded by the Academic Career Advancement Award. Please note that your supervisor will need to endorse your application and will be notified when you apply for the programme through the Scholarships Office.
The ACAP has two major elements:
Orientation morning

is an opportunity for participants to get to know each other. Held during Orientation Week, it provides an introduction to the programme and prepares participants for their role in the regular seminars.
Regular seminars
are co-facilitated by participants and will cover key aspects of academic careers such as research, teaching and professionalism. Where relevant, careers external to academia will also be discussed.
Find details and apply at
Academic Career Advancement Programme
This programme is organised by the
School of Graduate Studies

items.title: Preparing for your examination
items.summary: Planning to submit your thesis within the next 6 months? Learn more about what you need to prepare for thesis submission and your final oral examination.

content.value: If you're preparing to submit your thesis and would like to know more about the upcoming examination process, this workshop will explain all.
We will:
Demystify the doctoral examination process
Discuss what examiners expect and how they examine your theses
Find out more and book at
Doctoral workshops

This workshop is aimed at doctoral candidates who will be submitting their theses within the next six months. All doctoral candidates are welcome to attend, however, it may be most beneficial for those who are intending to submit their theses within the next six months.

items.title: Addressing Bullying, Harassment and Discrimination for leaders
items.summary: The Addressing Bullying, Harassment and Discrimination – for leaders is a 4 hour workshop created in collaboration with an industry expert.

content.value: The University is committed to a safe, inclusive and equitable environment supporting this with processes, policy, guidelines and learning programmes.
The Addressing Bullying, Harassment and Discrimination – for leaders is a 4 hour workshop created in collaboration with an industry expert.
Learning focus:
Building a shared understanding of what constitutes Bullying, Harassment and Discrimination
Raising awareness of the processes, policies and guidelines in place to keep our community safe
Increasing confidence for our staff to recognise unacceptable behaviour
Provide guidance on appropriate actions that can be taken including reporting and responding to disclosures

items.title: SPSS Core Skills
items.summary: This course will introduce participants to the core functions of the SPSS software.

content.value: SPSS is used extensively by academic researchers as a tool for quickly analysing quantitative data.

This ‘SPSS Core Skills’ course will help you get to grips with the basics of this user-friendly software. You’ll learn how to successfully set-up SPSS data files, run statistical analyses (including graphs), and manipulate files and variables.
No statistical knowledge is required for this course as the focus of the session will be on the software rather than statistical theory.
Key content:
Creating a new data set and entering data into SPSS
Importing data from sources such as Microsoft Excel
Defining variable properties, including value labels and missing value codes
Performing data transformations e.g. compute and recode variables
Calculating descriptive statistics and other statistical procedures
Brief introduction to charts and graphs

items.title: Workshop: Literature review: Finding information
items.summary: Learn how to search efficiently and effectively to find the information your need for your research project.

content.value: This workshop covers how to develop an effective search strategy, use advanced search techniques in multidisciplinary databases (Google Scholar, Scopus and the Library Catalogue). Learn how to save searches and set up email alerts to make sure you are staying up to date with the literature.

Finding information
For subject specific advice:
Subject guides
or

items.summary: Online canvas course covering safe handling of unsealed radioisotopes and disposal, also contains theory, operation and safety requirements  for equipment emitting ionising radiation.

Isotope-specific instructions for the safe handling of unsealed radioisotopes.
Safety instruction for the operation of equipment that emits ionising radiation, including X-ray diffraction, DEXA, PIXImus, and the AMI HTX equipment.

items.summary: Learn how to critically evaluate what you read, organise your ideas and start writing your literature review.

content.value: This workshop looks at the purpose of the literature review and outlines some of the strategies you need to effectively read and critically evaluate large amounts of scholarly material. Discover strategies for writing your literature review and synthesising the literature into your thesis.

Literature review

items.title: Workshop: Abstract writing
items.summary: An in-person workshop where researchers can learn how to write an effective abstract for conferences, events and publications.

content.value: Learn about the central elements that are part of an effective abstract. This workshop will focus on clarifying the main elements of an abstract and working on a draft. The workshop will provide an overview of some practical ideas that may be applicable to writing abstracts for conference and paper submissions. If you have an interesting idea or a draft, bring it along!
See our online resources:
Abstract writing

content.value: The Doctoral Induction is compulsory for all candidates enrolled in a PhD or named doctorate. At the Doctoral Induction, you'll network with other new doctoral candidates and get vital information that will help you during your first year.

items.title: Preparing for your confirmation review
items.summary: Find out how to prepare for your confirmation review (or provisional year review). Aimed at those within 3-9 months of starting their doctorate.

content.value: Find out what you need to do to prepare for your confirmation review (or provisional year review).

This workshop is aimed at doctoral candidates who have been in the programme for at least three months. It is most beneficial for candidates within nine months of starting their doctorate. Candidates should have a good idea of their project plans, after discussions with their supervisory team.
In this workshop we will:
Demystify the confirmation review process
Analyse the confirmation review milestones
Identify potential challenges in the provisional year and explore strategies for overcoming them
Hear from a panel of current candidates who have been confirmed into the doctoral program and academics who have acted as a Confirmation Review Committee member.

Although aimed at doctoral candidates within 3-9 months of starting their doctorate, all doctoral candidates in their provisional year are welcome to attend. Suitable for candidates on the current and the 2016 PhD Statutes.
Find out more about this and other candidature-focused workshops at
Doctoral workshops

School of Graduate Studies

items.title: Word Thesis Formatting

items.title: Laser safety awareness training
items.summary: To enable staff and students to understand the risks associated with high risk lasers, and to inform participants of effective laser risk control measures.

content.value: By the end of this session participants will be able to:
State how to access the University’s laser safety information.
Describe the obligations and actions that apply to an individual’s specific role or level of training.
Describe the basic anatomy of the eye.
Describe the properties of laser light.
Identify classes of laser.
Identify common laser risk control measures.
Describe the actions to be carried out in the event of lasers causing eye injury or suspected eye injury.

items.title: Containment Course

content.value: This course is run on Canvas. It includes recommended readings and a graded quiz.

items.title: Hacky hour
items.summary: An online community where researchers seek advice and share their experiences relating to digital research skills.

content.value: Inspired by ResBaz Melbourne, join the growing community at The University of Auckland to share skills and knowledge across disciplinary boundaries.
With support from the
Centre for eResearch
, Hacky Hour is the place to meet your research colleagues and knowledgeable folk from around the University who can help you with your research or technical questions.

Hacky Hour connects researchers from across disciplines who use similar digital research tools or are looking to upskill their digital scholarship practice. It is a space for peer-to-peer training and a network which works together to solve problems and learn new skills.

Hacky Hour is an open and inclusive environment, all are welcome to participate. Bring along your research questions, technical problems, the latest tools to share or show, or things to hack on - and we look forward to seeing you there!

Cloud storage with data stored in Sydney, Australia.
Collaborative document editing and record keeping with Dropbox

Choosing data storage

items.title: Research Drive
items.summary: Research Drive storage provides a safe and secure network accessible space to store and collaborate on your research data and digital creative works.

content.value: Benefits
University-managed storage service for research data and creative works.
Approved for use with internal and sensitive data, in compliance with the
Research Data Management Policy
and
guidance
Files or data are held on-campus, backed up regularly, and replicated across multiple university data centres.
Access can be shared with University staff and students, and external collaborators.
Accessible on and off-campus.
Go to the
page to compare with other University storage options.
Requesting a Research Drive
Research data storage is provided on a project-by-project basis in alignment with the University's
Research Data Management Policy
The request form is accessible to staff and doctoral candidates and asks for the following:
Project metadata, including title, abstract, end date, and Field of Research code(s)
Data classification
(e.g., ethics, security) requirements
Access requirements
Estimated storage space
Other postgraduate students or collaborators need the UoA-staff Principal Investigator or supervisor to request storage access on their behalf.
Using a Research Drive
A Research Drive is ideal for storing data that is active or being worked on. Those with read/write (edit) access to the Research Drive will be able to add files and create subfolders.

Each Research Drive is set up with Vault and Archive subfolders. Use these subfolders when files and data become less active as part of an efficient and sustainable approach to data storage. Files in both subfolders can be slower to access depending on their number and size.
The
Vault
folder is connected to object storage and costs less for the University to provide than disk storage. It is ideal for data that you need to keep but want to access only occasionally.
The
Archive
folder is connected to tape storage. This is ideal for data that is no longer active or being worked on, but that needs to be
retained
long term.  Files moved into the Archive folder and have not been accessed for 21 days will migrate to tape storage and not count against the quota of the Research Drive.
Help

items.title: Support with internal research funding and awards
items.summary: A mix of in-person and online support for researchers to apply for and manage internal research funding and awards in accordance with applicable policy and system requirements.

content.value: Service overview

Faculty and Institute Research Services Teams (FIRST) in each Faculty and Large-Scale Research Institute (LSRI) are available to support researchers to apply for and manage internal research funding and awards.
Available services
These FIRST services include:
supporting researchers to navigate University and faculty/LSRI guidelines and application requirements for internal funding and awards
supporting researchers to develop and manage budgets for internal funding and awards
providing the information and documentation required by Research Operations Centre (ROC) for
project activation

FIRST aims to respond to acknowledge all email queries received within two business days and will then assign a Research Programme Coordinator or Research Programme Manager to provide the research service as required.

items.title: Nectar virtual desktop
items.summary: Access a virtual computer in the cloud to free up your laptop or desktop.

content.value: Researchers can use the

virtual desktop service when they need access to more powerful computing hardware for their research, or to free up their regular machine while running long compute jobs. After signing in via Tuakiri with University of Auckland credentials, researchers are provided with a virtual desktop instance running their choice of several Linux operating systems. Software can be installed via the operating system’s package manager. Researchers can transfer files onto the virtual machine via ‘drag and drop’.
See the
overview page
for current information about virtual hardware allocations and time frames.
See the
virtual desktop service tutorial
to learn how to manage and use the service.
The Nectar Research Cloud virtual desktop service, and data uploaded to it, is hosted in Australia.

items.title: Self-service virtual machines
items.summary: Self-service virtual machines support computationally-intensive research while requiring active management from the researcher.

content.value: Self-service virtual machines provide computational resources to speed up research analyses, facilitate innovative methods, support long-running tasks, or free up your desktop or laptop to do other activities.
Benefits
C
ontrol over software and user management.
Able to work with external collaborators.
Access to GPUs: available hardware is outlined
here
Access to Windows and Linux environments.
Limitations
Requires active management of data, security, users, and software.
Requires proficiency in using the command line for accessing Linux virtual machines.
Requires an understanding of how to manage virtual machines on the public cloud.
Requires renewal at end of allocation period to avoid automated offboarding process.
Data back up
is the researcher's responsibility.
Request a self-service virtual machine
Request a self-service virtual machine by logging in to the
Nectar Research Cloud dashboard
with your University credentials via Tuakiri. Select ‘Allocations’ from the left-hand menu and ‘New Request’.
Before requesting a self-service virtual machine, an optional consultation can be used to:
Ensure that a self-service virtual machine is right for you by understanding the nature of the work you're doing.
Identify appropriate hardware settings (CPU, GPU, and RAM).
Understand your software requirements (operating system, preinstalled software).
Establish data storage requirements.
Help
User documentation for self-service virtual machines is provided by Nectar Research Cloud
here
. See the
Cloud Starter Series
for a collection of useful tutorials to get started.

items.title: FMHS biostatistical support
items.summary: Schedule a virtual or face-to face consultation with biostatisticians within the Faculty of Medical and Health Sciences (FMHS) to discuss your research problems at the design, analysis or interpretation phase.

content.value: With expertise in research methods and health sciences, the biostatistics consulting team supports researchers within the Faculty of Medical and Health Sciences (FMHS) with the highest quality biostatistical advice and research collaboration.
This service is open to all staff and graduate students within the Faculty of Medical and Health Sciences (FMHS) to provide advice and assistance with:
The design of research projects, including the preparation of grant proposals
Choice and application of statistical methods
Data visualisation and presentation
Reporting and interpretation of results
Conducting of more complex analyses can also be provided in some cases
To learn more about the services provided or to request a consultation please go to the
FMHS biostatistical support webpage

items.title: Surgical Trials Unit
items.summary: The Surgical Trials Unit supports early-stage, focused on first-in-human validation and proof-of-concept studies designed to test new diagnostic tools, medical devices and pharmaceuticals.

content.value: Multi-faceted trials unit spanning laboratory science to engineering science with focus on improved outcomes for surgical patients.
The
Surgical Trials Unit
(STU) undertakes clinical and translational research related to surgical disease and sits at the interface between our science programs and clinical practice.

We provide support for investigator initiated and company sponsored studies and clinical trials across a wide range of surgical diseases, ranging from abdominal conditions (eg Acute pancreatitis, GI cancers) postop complications, surgical procedures, trauma, critical illness, urology and applied surgery and metabolism.

Hosted at the Surgical and Translational Research Centre (STaR Centre), we collaborate closely with academics across the University of Auckland, and clinicians at Auckland City Hospital. We also have strong scientific and clinical; national and international connections, where we can leverage world leading expertise.
We provide a wide range of support including:
Study setup
Protocol Development
Regulatory documents (Participant Information Sheet, Case Report Forms, etc.)
Ethics application and submission
Study conduct
Study set up at ADHB
Patient screening and recruitment
Data collection and management
Sample collection and processing
Protocol amendment; annual progress reports
Study close out
Other
Trained clinical trials assistant(s)/research nurse
Site file maintenance (e.g. delegation logs, adverse events, etc.)
Scientific, statistical, and clinical input to optimise study design/outputs
Types of studies
Medical device/medical technology evaluation
Drug evaluation
RCTs
Audits
Observational studies; case-control studies
Pre-clinical to clinical studies
How the STU works

The STU team is overseen by an academic surgeon who is responsible for leadership and maintaining an overview of STU’s
activities and its research management. The team consists of Clinical Research Coordinator, Clinical Research Nurses, Clinical Trials Assistants. The STU is a research platform, part of the STaR Centre.
Data Security
STU documentation and data is maintained in a secure, online, access-controlled format.

items.title: Faculty of Medical and Health Sciences Clinical Research Centre
items.summary: These excellent facilities are available to staff and postgraduate students in the Faculty to carry out research involving human participants, as long as appropriate ethics approvals are in place.

content.value: In the early years of the School of Medicine, clinical research predominantly took place in hospitals. However, in the last couple of decades, there have also been areas around the Faculty where clinical research has been carried out. With the Faculty rebuild in 2012, a formal Clinical Research Centre was established.
The Clinical Research Centre, set up specifically for researchers with 17 bookable rooms each with a bed, chairs, desk and a computer, is located on the
Lower Ground floor (LG) of Building 507
We also have shared equipment that everyone can use, including:
Stadiometer
Scales
BP monitors
ECG machines
Centrifuges
Fridges
Freezers: -20°C and -80°C
Linen
Kitchen
Locked drug storage room
Phlebotomy room
Benefits for Researchers:
Using spaces like the CRC allows opportunities for researcher to network and support one another
Study participants can use the basement parking facilities in 507

items.title: New Zealand Government Electronic Tenders Service (GETS)
items.summary: GETS is free service designed to promote open, fair competition for New Zealand Government contract opportunities.

content.value:
GETS is a web based service which allows you to view current tenders, subscribe to notices, download tender documentation and where allowed, submit your response online.

The GETS system provides two services:
Tender advertising service:
a single website for public sector organisations (the purchasing organisation) to advertise contract opportunities to interested suppliers.
eTender functionality:

that allows suppliers to electronically (through GETS) ask questions and submit responses and proposals to advertised contract opportunities. However, a public sector organisation must elect to enable GETS eTender functionality. Suppliers must follow the instructions in the RFx documents relating to how to ask questions and submit responses.

items.title: Te Ira Kāwai - Auckland Regional Biobank
items.summary: The Auckland Regional Tissue Bank supports researchers in their endeavors to advance medical knowledge, providing tissue and resources for facilitating research projects.

content.value: Te Ira Kāwai - Auckland Regional Biobank (ARB) is a partnership between the University of Auckland and all three of the Auckland metropolitan hospitals under a regional umbrella of shared governance, systems, processes and a single ethics approval. The ARB is an initiative that is part of the
Auckland Academic Health Alliance
The ARB supports researchers in their endeavours to advance medical knowledge, providing tissue and resources for facilitating future research projects.
ARB can provide a wide range of critical support including:
Provision of existing tissue
Sourcing and storage of specific new tissue
Support in obtaining ethical consent
Advice on cultural matters and engaging with Māori and Pacific people
The ARB also has the ability to tailor tissue collection to suit research needs so researchers are encouraged to contact the tissue bank very early in their planning.
Researchers should contact ARB early in their project planning, before requesting samples, to ensure their needs can best be met.
Supporting information about tissue banking and guides for tissue donors, researchers, and health professionals are available on the
ARB website.
ARB facilities are located at the University of Auckland's Faculty of Medical and Health Sciences opposite Auckland Hospital in Grafton, as well as at Middlemore and North Shore Hospitals.

items.title: Systematic Review Support
items.summary: Face to face and online support for staff and postgraduate students undertaking a systematic review.

content.value: Te Tumu Herenga | Libraries and Learning Services provides support to staff and postgraduate students undertaking a systematic review. We offer face to face consultations to help support you in the process of creating a systematic search for your review.
If this is your first time conducting a systematic review or if you are conducting systematic review as part of your coursework/assignment, we ask that you:
Work
through our online
systematic review library guide

before contacting us for further support. The online systematic review guide aims to inform on the systematic review process and methodology and provides guidance on constructing a search strategy which is appropriate for a systematic review.
If you are not familiar with searching in Medline and your topic is related to medicine, pharmacology, or psychology, we recommend you attend our
Medline (Ovid) workshop
(a
recording of the Medline (Ovid) workshop
is available for on-demand viewing).
Staff and postgraduate students are entitled to:

Up to 3 consultations, including a 15-minute consultation at the outset to determine project scope, timeline, and understanding of methodology. An in-depth consult to discuss and develop your search strategy with the option for a follow up consult if needed.
Additional tailored feedback and advice on your search strategy up to two times following the searching consult.
Contact us.

items.title: Web dropoff box
items.summary: The web dropoff Box allows easy sharing of large files which would be difficult to transfer via e-mail.

content.value: The Web DropOff Box service uses a secure protocol to transfer large files which would otherwise be difficult to send. All uploaded files are checked for malware and can be encrypted for added security. Users upload the file to share, and provide the email address of the recipient. The recipient is then notified and provided with a link to download the file. Currently, the maximum supported file size for upload is 2GB.
Only one file can be uploaded and sent at a time. If you have multiple files, consider creating a ZIP archive first, containing all the files you want to send.

The Web DropOff service can also be used by collaborators from outside the University to transfer files to you. External collaborators can only send files to recipients with an auckland.ac.nz domain email address.
Files are held on the Web DropOff service for two weeks, after which time they are automatically deleted.
If you need to send larger amounts of data,
or
might be a better fit.

items.title: Access GPUs for machine learning
items.summary: The CeR provides advice and access to computational resources and software for machine learning workflows.

content.value: Machine learning is a subfield of artificial intelligence (A.I.) encompassing a range of algorithms that are used to generate models directly from data.
Recent advances have been enabled by access to large amounts of data and
deep neural networks

which are able to perform non-linear modelling tasks efficiently on high-performance devices normally used for rendering graphics (GPUs). Examples of machine learning applications include image processing, natural language processing, and autonomous agents.
For anyone new to machine learning, we recommend some starting resources to learn key concepts and the technologies involved: the
Machine Learning Crash Course by Google
and
Kaggle Data Science Education

Developing machine learning models can be computationally intensive. Once you have an understanding of how machine learning can be used for your research, you may be interested in where you can develop your models efficiently.

Public services normally have an associated cost that is not covered by the University. University services are free of charge but may have constraints on the type and quantity of hardware available as well as the duration of your projects.

The Centre for eResearch is available to help you develop machine learning solutions as part of their research consultancy services. Researchers are welcome to discuss their needs and request advice, although any dedicated development work will usually involve cost recovery.
Public Services
University of Auckland Service
Associated Services
correctly is particularly important if you have large amounts of data or sensitive information. You can consult the Centre for eResearch who can provide advice to support your project.

items.title: Visualisation and immersive technologies

content.value: Our expertise

We provide technical advice and support for visualisation and immersive technologies to help bring research data to life. We can partner with researchers to support research projects that require more in-depth analytics and customised solutions through our

to arrange a demonstration or book the spaces.

items.title: Statistical data
items.summary: Use data from Statistics New Zealand (Stats NZ) to create customised tables from official statistics.

content.value: Where can I find statistical data?
For a list of key databases, websites and other resources on statistics, see
Statistics and numeric data

Stats NZ has a lot of data available on their website, mostly as simple tables with a few variables. If you need help in finding official statistics or formulating your request, Stats NZ are willing to discuss all requests and will do their best to ensure that the information is supplied. This service is free. Contact
Stats NZ
What if the statistical data I need is not publicly available?
When the statistical data required is not easily accessible or you need to explore further the relationship between variables in available datasets, Stats NZ can create
customised datasets
specific to your needs.
Customised data requests service is exclusively available to New Zealand Universities through an agreement between the Council of New Zealand University Librarians (CONZUL) and Stats NZ.

The University of Auckland has an annual allocation of hours that may be used for requests by staff and students. This applies to all datasets produced by Stats NZ for which customised tables can be prepared.
How do I request specialised data?
If you need customised statistical data, confidentialised (CURFs) or synthetic (SURFs) unit records, email the University contact officer
Anne Chen
at
anne.chen@auckland.ac.nz
Check out this free web tool to create data tables, from Stats NZ:

items.title: Research Professional
items.summary: Research Professional provides researchers in all disciplines with up-to-date coverage of the latest developments on funding agencies, government departments, newsworthy people, funding opportunities and trends globally.

content.value: Research Professional includes every funding opportunity from data sets that researchers at The University of Auckland can apply for and none of the ones that they couldn't apply for making the tool 'simpatico'.
The database has been tailored to suit researchers' needs and ensures that they deliver to us not only a huge, diverse database of funding opportunities but also one that is reliable and relevant.
Accessing the site
You can start browsing
www.researchprofessional.com

from any computer on campus at your university or offsite. Researchers will be able to browse news and funding content freely on the home page but will be prompted to enter their UPI and password if attempting to save work or access any personalised information.
There are brief tutorials on this
End User Functionality Training webpage

that cover how to log in (for onsite access and creating an account), Searching for Funding, Saving Searches and Creating Email Alerts, Funding Calendars, Email Alerts and Your Profile, Interacting with Funding Opportunities, Research Professional News, and for (Administrative Users) Our Institution. None of the tutorials are no longer than 4 minutes.

items.title: Media productions
items.summary: We are dedicated professionals who produce and provide support and advice creating video and photography content, including promotional material, news stories, recordings, live streaming, and more. We offer media solutions to support your research.

content.value:
Media Productions can offer media solutions to support your research, teaching and learning. Media Productions photographers can cater for all photography needs, from large scale events to individual portraits, or photos of your 
facilities or research projects.
Services offered include:
Still photography
Film production, including an on location film unit
TV studio
Animation and computer graphics, including production of digital content, both 2D and 3D
Storytelling and visualisation, including assistance to develop narratives for impact and communication
Media training
Event livestreaming

Comprehensive media training can be provided to University staff utilising the in-house TV studio, crew, playback facility and audio studio. This service guides staff in developing skills for speaking in front of cameras and for dealing with the press and media. It can maximise the impact of any media project and is strongly recommended for anyone involved.
The on-location film unit can record or livestream events, and produce videos for publications or teaching, including training videos.
Other types of filming include: interviews, promotional videos, panel discussions, and pieces to camera.

The Media Productions website contains comprehensive information on what to expect when undertaking a media productions project, including advice, guidelines, FAQs, and details on the process involved.
Undertaking a media production project requires time and planning. See the
advice and guidelines
on the Media Productions website for helpful information on things to consider ahead of discussing projects.

items.title: Nectar BinderHub
items.summary: Access a service to turn a public code repository into an interactive, reproducible computational environment.

content.value: Researchers can use the Nectar BinderHub service to package up a remote Git repository and turn it into an interactive Jupyter notebook for displaying code and output. BinderHub uses Docker to reproduce a Jupyter environment based on a dependency file which lists the packages (and their versions) used in the original analysis. The environment comes with a reusable link you can share with others, who can then interact with your notebook.
Your data, code, and computational environment files need to be in a version-controlled remote repository, such as GitHub or GitLab.
For more information, and to see current virtual hardware allocations and timeframes, see
here
The Nectar Research Cloud BinderHub service, and data uploaded to it, is hosted in Australia.

items.title: Nectar JupyterHub
items.summary: Access a virtual Jupyter Notebook to write code without having to install and maintain your own Jupyter environment.

content.value: Researchers can use the Nectar Research Cloud
Jupyter Notebook service

when they want to jump straight into programming rather than spend time installing and maintaining software dependencies. Researchers can choose from multiple programming environments including Python, Julia, and R, with popular scientific packages pre-installed.

items.title: Research programming and workflow development
items.summary: The Centre for eResearch can partner with research groups to develop analytical software or workflow for research.

content.value: The Centre for eResearch can partner with research groups to develop analytical software or workflow needed for research projects.
Development work typically proceeds using an agile approach, moving forward in quick steps, with stakeholders fully engaged.
Development work may include, but is not limited to:
Simulations and modelling

items.title: High performance computing
items.summary: Using High Performance Computing (HPC) resources and data analytics services, you can investigate large, unique, or complex projects with greater ease, accuracy, and improved time-to-science.

content.value: New Zealand eScience Infrastructure (NeSI) is a powerful fit-for-purpose platform of shared HPC resources and data analytics services. Using NeSI, you can:
access high-capacity CPUs, GPUs and high memory nodes
work interactively using Jupyter Notebooks, containers, and virtual lab environments
bring your own code or access NeSI's extensive software library -- already built and compiled, ready for you to use
scale your code and expand your projects

NeSI provides tools and services to help you get your data onto the HPC platform, store it close to the compute, process and analyse your datasets, visualise the results, and share it with colleagues.

NeSI's Long-Term Data Storage service is in an Early Access Programme (EAP) phase with a cohort of selected users. If you require long-term storage following computational analysis of your data, you will need to transfer and store it using university-provided
options.

items.title: Institutional Figshare
items.summary: The University's research data repository is an online and self-service digital publishing platform where researchers can preserve and share their research data and artefacts.

content.value: Publishing research data on Figshare

Institutional Figshare is the University's research data repository, an online self-service publishing and discovery platform where researchers can preserve and share their digital research data and artefacts. Hosted by the University of Auckland, files uploaded to our institutional Figshare are stored on-campus within University-managed storage.

Researchers can publish and preserve research data and digital creative works, including figures, datasets, images, and videos. Researchers upload files via the Figshare web interface, creating a research data record with descriptive metadata.

items.title: Instrument data service
items.summary: Face to face consultations with facilities managers who are interested in using the instrument data service to document, store, archive, and transfer data generated by their research instruments.

content.value: The instrument data service is being piloted by several instrument facilities in 2024. Facility managers interested in adding their instruments to the service should contact the team.

The Centre for eResearch provides an instrument data service for facilities to store and archive research data generated by instruments in a central place. Researchers can track data associated with different experiments and projects, and transfer a copy of the data to a University-managed storage service (such as
or

The instrument data service supports facility managers to organise, track, and audit usage of their instruments. A raw copy of the data is always preserved on the service, and this copy cannot be edited or changed. This means researchers will always have access to a copy of the raw data for the purposes of transparency, reproducibility, or verifying provenance. The service also makes it easy for researchers to attach a variety of
metadata
to their data files and projects, all of which becomes searchable from inside the service.

Researchers log in to the instrument data service webpage with their University credentials to see a dashboard which shows their data. Individual data files are grouped into datasets, which are grouped into experiments, which are grouped into projects. Access can be defined at any of these levels. For example, if you are granted access to a project, then you are automatically granted access to all of the experiments, datasets, and data files within that project, unless access is specified separately for any of these levels. Access can be provided to individuals or groups of individuals. Data files can also be made accessible to anyone on the service, but if access is controlled then only a metadata record will be shown.
Training resources for facility managers and researchers are planned. If you are a facility manager interested in adding your instruments to the service please contact
Chris Seal

items.title: Co-locations at Newmarket Innovation Precinct (NIP)
items.summary: Newmarket Innovation Precinct (NIP) supports researchers through co-location to commercialise their research and connects a community of industry, government and academia to encourage collaboration, R&D and knowledge exchange.

content.value: NIP is a multidisciplinary, industry-facing R&D community based on Khyber Pass Rd, Grafton, hosted by the
University of Auckland’s Faculty of Engineering.

NIP aims to connect companies facing technical challenges with world-class experts who are committed to having a real-world impact. NIP benefits from a highly connected and accessible location, large postgraduate research student population and specialised technical engineering infrastructure and expertise.
Who can use NIP?

Researchers who intend to commercialise their research via a spin-out company or who want to collaborate on site, working ‘shoulder to shoulder’ with industry partners for commercial R&D purposes can utilise university infrastructure and co-location spaces at NIP.

The NIP team can support UoA researchers in finding office or laboratory space and can connect researcher staff and students to develop their university-industry relationships. Alongside support and investment opportunities available through UniServices, NIP is a mechanism through which the university encourages the commercialisation of research, retains teaching and research expertise and builds our credibility as an entrepreneurial university.
Why use NIP for your commercial research?

Co-location fosters close university-industry relationships, supports the growth of entrepreneurship among staff and students and encourages life-long learning among industry and university employees.
For researchers looking to start up their own businesses, NIP can offer vital infrastructure with the convenience of remaining physically close and/or connected to the University.
Offers a local innovation community that generates a range of opportunities for university researchers and students, company founders and employees.
Encourages collaboration through networking events and sector-specific infrastructure tours, and ideation workshops.
Services provided at NIP

NIP is a collaborative work environment which benefits both UoA researchers as well as external industry, government or research partners. We encourage researchers to discuss NIP with their industry partners and find opportunities for collaboration and commercialisation.
Services provided;
Facilitated Industry-researcher introductions
for the purposes of exploration and discovery (research alignment, research infrastructure and specialised equipment), student projects and internships.
Open plan office spaces and lab-based colocation spaces
for companies at our Newmarket Campus (and within Faculty of Engineering at City Campus, where we have an alignment of research interests).
NIP managed industry membership
options for the purposes of developing and supporting an industry-researcher collaborative working environment (industry visitor onboarding, inductions and hot-desk services).
Access to specialist lab equipment and expertise
for NIP industry members where there is a clear intent to develop wider research opportunities.
Learn more about NIP services
To learn more about NIPs service options and co-locations, contact NIP via email at
nip@auckland.ac.nz
or via their
enquiry form
Find funding and industry partners for your research
For researchers requiring seed funding or looking to establish industry partnerships in a specific sector, please get in touch with
UniServices
for support.

items.title: Researcher development
items.summary: Supporting career planning and development through excellent researcher training and capability opportunities.

content.value: Welcome to the researcher development hub

Continuing professional development is essential to attain the knowledge, skills, and capabilities you need to progress from post-graduate studies to independently conducting research and leading research teams. Online, face-to-face and self-directed development opportunities from across the University are brought together under the capability topics below, which you can explore as they become relevant to your career stage and career aspirations.

researcher development opportunities calendar

content.value: The Research & Innovation (R&I) strategic portfolio includes several

which broadly fall into four

items.title: He Korowai Mātauranga
items.summary: He Korowai Mātauranga brings together a collection of resources that researchers and research support teams can use to build knowledge in the area of Vision Mātauranga at  Waipapa Taumata Rau.

content.value:
He Korowai Mātauranga is a body of work that provides Waipapa Taumata Rau, The University of Auckland researchers and research support staff with resources and tools to build knowledge in the area of Vision Mātauranga. He Korowai Mātauranga will enable the
interweaving of two knowledge systems - Mātauranga Māori and Western Science.

He Korowai Mātauranga translates to “the cloak of knowledge”.  Traditionally, korowai are woven from harakeke, worked into muka (strands) and adorned with hukahuka (tassels)
and huruhuru (feathers). Using the imagery of the interconnected muka we have broken down the approach to Vision Mātauranga into four muka:
What is Vision Mātauranga?
Why do we have Vision Mātauranga and what is its relevance in a research context?
How can Vision Mātauranga be understood and applied to research?
Who do I engage with to get more advice about Vision Mātauranga?
He Korowai Mātauranga will grow in content as we build resources and tools to support the needs of researchers and Māori.
