items.title: Research impact and engagement
items.summary: Resources, articles, and training opportunities to support you in generating impact from your research.

content.value: What is Research Impact?
Research Impact is "
The contribution that research and creative practice makes to society, the environment and the economy

". It embraces the diverse ways in which knowledge and outputs generated by research benefits individuals, whānau, communities, organisations, Aotearoa New Zealand and the world. You can think of research impact as
your research making a difference to people's lives

Impact from your research might be seen immediately or it can take years; the contribution of your research and changes to society, the environment, or the economy may have implications for generations to come. Waipapa Taumata Rau is committed to achieving impact from our research as outlined in the
UoA
Research Impact and Engagement Framework
and
Taumata Teitei
vision 2030 and strategic plan 2025
The Research Impact and Engagement Guide
Haere mai!
The
research impact team

has created this guide to help you understand research impact and find resources, tools, and training to support your research impact aspirations. You can navigate this guide in a linear fashion from start to finish — or you can explore the articles and content that is most relevant to you as a researcher and where you are in your research journey.
Click on the cards below to learn more about each aspect of research impact. If you have suggestions for improvements to this guide, please fill in this
feedback survey

Contract negotiation is managed by the Research Grants & Contract Team, who each look after a portfolio of contracts within a Faculty. To discuss your requirements and progress your request for a contract, subcontracts or variation, please contact FIRST, who will submit a

to your Contract manager  who will be in contact if any further information is required. If you have any other contracting queries, please contact your Contracts Manager.

Your Research Grants & Contract Manager will be able to provide advice and guidance regarding contractual matters, including Intellectual Property rights, Confidentiality and Publications to ensure the best outcomes for all parties. items.title: University of Auckland Human Participants Ethics Committee (UAHPEC)

content.value: The University of Auckland Human Participants Ethics Committee's (UAHPEC) primary purpose is to ensure that research involving human participants conducted by members of the University community complies with the highest ethical standards.
UAHPEC's key function is to review, and, where satisfied that it is appropriate, approve submitted research for compliance with ethical principles.
Learn more about the purpose, function and membership of the University of Auckland Human Participants Ethics Committee (UAHPEC).

Applications will only be included on the agenda if they meet a sufficient standard, ensuring that the Committee has all necessary information to adequately review applications and make informed decisions.
The submission deadline refers to the time by which the applications must be received to a sufficient standard. Applications below this standard will not be placed on the agenda.

items.summary: Useful resources and advice to help you to plan the management of research data.

content.value:
Data management planning is best started in the early stages of a research project, but it is never too late to develop a data management plan. You will need to consider a variety of issues and topics in order to plan for the management of research data, so use the below pages to start or add to the process.

Researchers are responsible for creating and maintaining a DMP for sensitive or restricted data from the 1st July 2023 under the Waipapa Taumata Rau, University of Auckland Research Data Management Policy.

Research data management policy guidance

items.title: Organise and describe research data
items.summary: Advice for organising your data including tips for folder structures, file naming, and versioning.

content.value: Organising your data files and folders will make it easier for you to work with your research data and save you time. Describing your data with accurate metadata and READMEs will help you and your collaborators to understand what you did and why. This is especially useful when you need to come back to your research project after a period of time, for example, to answer reviewer queries or provide copies of the data when publishing.

content.value: Research is often a collaboration across institutional and international boundaries. It is important to consider how your collaboration will affect how research data will be managed, and how it may change the legal, funder, and institutional obligations you may have. The best time to plan, discuss, and establish an agreed
data management plan

items.title: Human ethics - Research involving human participants
items.summary: Information, training and application guidance for researchers requesting ethics approval for research or course-based projects involving human participants from UAHPEC, HDEC or AHREC.

content.value: Find the right ethics committee for your research

Research conducted by staff and students involving human participants (including teaching sessions, laboratories, anonymous questionnaires and research carried out as part of taught coursework) must receive ethics approval from one of the following ethics committees (unless an exemption applies):
The University of Auckland Human Participants Ethics Committee (UAHPEC)
– if not eligible for review by an HDEC or AHREC;
The Auckland Health Research Ethics Committee (AHREC)

- for human health research not eligible to be reviewed by an HDEC, and conducted by staff members of Te Toka Tumai Auckland, Te Whatu Ora Counties Manukau and Te Whatu Ora Waitematā, or staff or students of the University of Auckland;
Health and Disability Ethics Committees (HDECs)
- all health and disability research in scope for HDEC review must be submitted to an HDEC for review.

items.title: Equity and inclusion in research
items.summary: The University supports inclusive and equitable research.

content.value: Every research or evaluation project is unique in its approach. Therefore, state

Andrews,
Parekh and Peckoo
, there can be no universal prescriptive formula for how to embed equity perspective in research. However, a
critical thinking
approach and incorporating foundational principles can guide each research project to intentionally address equity at different stages of the research process.
Awareness of potential
biases
WEIRD
perspectives, and
inequities
that have been embedded into systems over many years can be addressed and counteracted.
Developing capability

Equity-related training is available to staff via Career Tools on the intranet, for example, Unconscious bias, Te Tiriti and Cultural competency and LEAD: Build equity and reduce bias, and more. The Equity Office Te Ara Tautika can offer tailored training for researchers on topics such as,
Unconscious bias
, What is equity?, Managing inclusive workplaces, and Inclusive recruitment.

items.title: Researcher profiles and IDs
items.summary: This resource hub will help you use researcher profiles and IDs to build your online professional presence.

content.value: Online Profiles

Creating and maintaining professional online profiles can enhance your visibility, credibility and networking opportunities. Well-managed researcher profiles allow you to showcase your research achievements, connect with peers, and discover potential collaborators and funding opportunities. See
or attend

Researcher IDs

or

items.title: Research & innovation stakeholders and governance
items.summary: The governance arrangements and stakeholders for each R&I Portfolio initiative.

content.value: Here you will find information on the governance and stakeholder arrangements for the Research & Innovation strategic portfolio. Most projects in the portfolio are governed by the Research & Innovation Steering Committee, which is chaired by the Deputy Vice-Chancellor (Research) as the programme Sponsor. Some projects, including those which span multiple portfolios, may have different steering committee structures that are described on the individual project pages.
Additionally, academic and professional staff advisors are engaged from across the University, along with Reference Groups, to help ensure the successful delivery of project outcomes.
Steering committee and reference groups | Research & innovation

items.title: Open Access
items.summary: Learn about what Open Access (OA) is, why and how to make your work open and how to comply with the University's OA policy and other funder OA mandates.

content.value: Open Access (OA) is a set of principles and practices through which academic research outputs are made available publicly through online distribution, either via an OA journal, OA book, or inclusion in an institutional or disciplinary repository. The two institutional repositories at the University of Auckland are
and

Open Access allows anyone to access peer-reviewed research articles and other scholarly materials for free. Research that is paywalled (i.e. you must pay to read it) can create barriers for students, researchers, and individuals from developing countries or under-resourced institutions. Open Access promotes equal opportunities for learning, research and innovation, particularly for those who cannot pay for costly journal subscriptions. It also encourages greater collaboration among researchers and more rapid dissemination of knowledge, ultimately advancing scientific progress and benefitting society as a whole.
Open Access also enables authors to retain rights to their own work and determine how others use and share their work through the use of
licenses. Open access materials can include journal articles, creative works, books and book chapters, conference proceedings, theses, presentations, data, images and more.

items.title: The publishing process
items.summary: This resource hub will help you navigate the academic publishing process, including journal selection, peer review and copyright.

content.value: Academic publishing is the process of making research findings available to the public through published works such as academic journals, books, conference proceedings, and dissertations. The goal of academic publishing is to disseminate new knowledge, promote scientific progress and facilitate scholarly communication.

Academic publishing allows researchers to share their findings with a wider audience, receive feedback from peers and contribute to the body of knowledge in their respective fields. The publication of research findings helps to establish a researcher's reputation and credibility in their field of study.

items.title: Health and Disability Ethics Committee (HDEC)
items.summary: Find information about the Pre-submission approval form required by the University before submitting your application for HDEC approval, and eligibility for submitting a HDEC application.

content.value: The function of the Health and Disability Research Committee's (HDEC's) is to secure the benefits of health and disability research by ensuring that such research meets established ethical standards. To learn more, please go to the
Health and Disability Research Committee's (HDEC's) website
Health and disability research in New Zealand
must

If considered to be out of scope for HDEC review, human health research studies of University of Auckland staff and students must be submitted for review by the
Auckland Health Research Ethics Committee (AHREC)
unless an exemption applies.

items.title: University of Auckland Biological Safety Committee (UABSC)
items.summary: The University of Auckland Biological Safety Committee (UABSC) assesses Hazardous Substances and New Organisms (HSNO) applications and provides advice and policy on matters of biological safety at the University.

content.value: The Hazardous Substances and New Organisms Act 1996 (HSNO Act) requires all development, importation and field trials of Genetically Modified Organisms (GMOs) to have prior approval from the Environmental Protection Authority (EPA).

The University of Auckland Biological Safety Committee UABSC was established by the University Council to oversee the research activities that fall under the HSNO Act 1996.  The UABSC provides guidance to researchers and a mechanism for obtaining the required approvals to develop and import GMOs as well as overseeing the use of higher-risk microorganisms.
Learn more about the terms of reference and composition of the committee on the
University of Auckland Biological Safety Committee page
Quick reference guides for biological safety-related submissions in Ethics RM can be found on
Infonetica Ethics RM quick reference guides on Course-Builder.
The University of Auckland Biological Safety Committee meets on the first Monday of every month to review biological safety applications.
Download the full list of 2024 meeting dates and deadlines.

items.title: Metrics
items.summary: Research metrics are used as an indicator of research impact. There are a variety of metrics and metric tools that attempt to quantify the impact of researchers, publications or research data/outputs.

content.value: Metrics quantify the impact of researchers, publications or research data by considering factors such as citation, distribution, collaboration, adoption and other forms of impact.
See
to learn more about metrics and
for using them.
Which metrics are right for you?
Different outputs and some of their associated metrics are outlined below. Where available, the relevant sources for these metrics are provided. The
Metrics Toolkit
provides more information on these and other metrics as well as how to use them to support evidence of impact.

items.title: Foundations of research impact
items.summary: Start here to gain an overview of the first steps to take when embarking on a journey of expanding your research impact capabilities.

content.value: What are the first things I need to know about research impact?

While your research may have unintended impacts that you did not plan for when your first started your research, it is best to deliberately plan for and map out your intended research impact. By planning for the potential impact you'd like your research to have, you can define your potential impact, articulate the meaningful actions you need to undertake to achieve it, and prioritise who you need to engage with to maximise your research impact.

Your research impact plan will be as unique as your research. There may be multiple impacts and pathways to achieving impact. The change from your research might not be seen immediately, but the impact may have implications for years to come. Planning early for research impact is the best way to ensure your research makes a difference to the world.

Click on the cards below to learn more about the importance of research impact, how to plan for research impact, and meeting impact criteria in funding applications. For further support, contact the Research Impact team at
researchimpact@auckland.ac.nz

items.title: Capturing and evidencing your impact
items.summary: Through choosing meaningful impact indicators, you can track your research impact and see real-world change.

content.value: Capturing and evidencing your impact is important for creating a well-evidenced narrative of your research impact.

Click on the cards below to learn more about aspects of capturing and evidencing impact, including creating meaningful impact indicators. For further support with choosing impact indicators, evidencing your impact, or articulating your impact, you can contact the Research Impact Team at
researchimpact@auckland.ac.nz

items.title: Animal ethics - Research and teaching involving animals
items.summary: Find out what you need to know about working with animals at the University of Auckland. This area provides insight into the preparation of Animal Ethics applications as well as information required during and after the research project.

content.value: The University of Auckland is committed to the concept of the 3 Rs: reduction, replacement and refinement in the use of animals for research and teaching. Careful planning of experiments and manipulations is required to ensure that the minimum numbers of animals are worked with (in line with the objectives of the experiment), that replacement of animals by non-sentient or non-living alternatives are used when appropriate, and that all approved techniques are designed to minimise harm to the animals.

This platform is designed to provide information on animal ethics, health and welfare topics related to the University of Auckland Code of Ethical Conduct (CEC) and the Animal Welfare Act 1999, specifically
Part 6: Use of Animals in research, testing and teaching

These requirements can be daunting and we appreciate that this is a field that many of you have not been intimately involved with prior to starting your research here at the UoA. To help ensure that the University is meeting all of its legal obligations, and assist you with producing excellent research we are aiming to have created some compulsory and some elective training modules.
For further guidance on applying for animal ethics using Ethics RM please read
'Animal Ethics - Submitting an Application for Sign Off'

We have curated what we believe to be the key resources you need to successfully navigate the improve the research space, however, if you want to explore all content relevant to this research stage please apply the
"improve the research" filter.

items.title: Doctoral resources
items.summary: Discover research-specific resources relevant to you as a doctoral researcher.

content.value: Welcome to the doctoral resource space!
Here, we have curated a selection of resources to assist you in effectively navigating the ResearchHub articles most helpful to you as a doctoral candidate.
Trouble getting access?
In some instances, some students are unable to access ResearchHub content behind Single-Sign-On (SSO). If you are having access issues please raise a request via the
ResearchHub request form
and provide the URL of the page you attempting to access.
ResearchHub resources
Below you will find a selection of resources that may be relevant to you as a doctoral researcher. However, we encourage you to explore the diverse range of resources available on the
ResearchHub
to explore any additional research-related topics you may have an interest in.

items.title: Publishing Guide
items.summary: Here you will find resources to support you all stages of the academic publishing cycle, including the publishing process, Open Access, researcher profiles and IDs, metrics, depositing your thesis and more.

content.value: This guide contains resources to support researchers across the University who are publishing their research, including postgraduates, PhDs, early career researchers, and academics at the middle and later stages of their careers.
For queries about any of these topics, please submit a request to the Library via
Ask Us

items.title: How can Vision Mātauranga be understood and applied to research?
items.summary: Empower Māori knowledge. Empower Māori people. Empower Māori resources

content.value: When developed well, research projects that embed Vision Mātauranga from the outset can clearly demonstrate how Māori will directly prosper from the research. Regardless of what the prosperity gains are, it is important that Māori benefit from the outcomes of the  research activity and that this is clearly articulated. To do this well requires early engagement with Māori to help define the problem that the research seeks to address.
Levels of Māori Engagement
Most government research funding agencies classify research involving Māori into five categories. These are:
Research with no specific Māori component
Research specifically relevant to Māori
Research involving Māori
Māori-centered research
Kaupapa Māori research

It can be difficult to know where your research may sit within these categories. The last two categories tend to be the domain of Māori researchers as this research requires projects to be Māori led and to  undertake Kaupapa Māori methodologies and analysis. The other three categories can be harder to define. It is generally acknowledged that the majority of research undertaken within Aotearoa New Zealand very rarely has no specific Māori component.  The majority of research undertaken within Aotearoa New Zealand has relevance for Māori.  Category two and three requires researchers to consider what the potential impacts of the research are for Māori and the role mātauranga Māori (Māori traditional knowledge, language, practices and culture) might play in the research.
Research projects
The following is a collection of research projects which align with the four Vision Mātauranga themes.
Hauora and Oranga: improving health and social wellbeing.
Read more about
Taiao: achieving environmental sustainability through Iwi and hapū relationships with land and sea.
Read more about
Indigenous Innovation: contributing to economic growth
Read more about
Mātauranga: exploring indigenous knowledge
Read more about
Resources
The following resources may be useful in helping you apply Vision Mātauranga to your research.

items.title: National Research Collaborations
items.summary: Cross-institutional collaborations, funded by the New Zealand central government over multiple years.

content.value: There are two types of National Research Collaborations: the
National Science Challenges (NSCs)
funded by the Ministry of Business, Innovation and Employment (MBIE); and
Centres of Research Excellence (CoREs)
funded by the Tertiary Education Commission (TEC). Each of these National Research Collaborations is hosted by a research institution in New Zealand.

items.title: Performance-Based Research Fund (PBRF)
items.summary: The Performance-Based Research Fund (PBRF) process is managed by Tertiary Education Commission (TEC) who assess the research performance of tertiary providers in New Zealand and allocates funding based on performance.

content.value: Overview

The Performance Based Research Fund is a bulk funding mechanism, administered by the Tertiary Education Commission, designed to encourage and reward high-quality research, and research-led teaching, across all subject areas and types, in degree-granting Tertiary Education Organisations (TEOs).

The PBRF does not fund or purchase research directly but supports research, including post-graduate teaching and supervision and supports a wide range of different research that provides economic, social, cultural and environmental benefits to New Zealand.
A capped funding pool of $315 million per year, the PBRF employs both peer review processes and performance measures. There are three different components within the PBRF:

The Quality Evaluation (QE) component (55% of the fund) is based on a periodic assessment of the research performance of staff at eligible TEOs. TEOs present staff research in Evidence Portfolios that are assessed for quality by expert peer review panels.

The Research Degree Completions (RDC) component (25% of the fund) is an annual measurement of the number of PBRF-eligible postgraduate research-based degrees completed at participating TEOs. This helps to capture the connection between research staff and research training.
The External Research Income (ERI) component (20% of the fund) is an annual measurement of the amount and type of income received by participating TEOs from external sources for research purposes.

The PBRF has been in operation since 2003, and the next round of the QE component is scheduled for 2026. The University currently receives approximately $94M per annum from the PBRF Fund, of which approximately $45M is generated through the QE component.
